Text

CHAPTER I. The birth of [the Prince]236-the prince and [the Pauper]237-the pauper . In [the ancient city of]238-the ancient city of [London]1-london , on a certain autumn day in the second quarter of the sixteenth century , [a boy]239-a boy was born to [a poor family of the name of Canty]240-a poor family of the name of canty , who did not want [him]239-a boy . On the same day [another English child]241-another english child was born to [a rich family of the name of Tudor]242-a rich family of the name of tudor , who did want [him]239-a boy . [All England]243-all england wanted [him]239-a boy too . [England]2-england had so longed for [him]239-a boy , and hoped for [him]239-a boy , and prayed [God]87-god for [him]239-a boy , that , now that [he]239-a boy was really come , [the people]244-the people went nearly mad for joy . [Mere acquaintances]245-mere acquaintances hugged and kissed [each other]246-each other and cried . [Everybody]247-everybody took a holiday , and high and low , rich and poor , feasted and danced and sang , and got very mellow ; and [they]247-everybody kept this up for days and nights together . By day , [London]1-london was a sight to see , with gay banners waving from [every balcony]248-every balcony and [housetop]249-housetop , and splendid pageants marching along . By night , [it]1-london was again a sight to see , with [its]1-london great bonfires at every corner , and [its troops of [revellers]251-revellers]250-its troops of revellers making merry around [them]247-everybody . There was no talk in all [England]2-england but of [the new baby]252-the new baby , [Edward Tudor]88-edward tudor , [Prince of [Wales]3-wales , who lay lapped in silks and satins , unconscious of all this fuss , and not knowing that [great lords]253-great lords and [ladies]254-ladies were tending [him]252-the new baby and watching over [him]252-the new baby]89-prince of wales , who lay lapped in silks and satins , unconscious of all this fuss , and not knowing that great lords and ladies were tending him and watching over him -- and not caring , either . But there was no talk about [the other baby]255-the other baby , [Tom Canty]90-tom , lapped in [his]90-tom poor rags , except among [the family of paupers whom [he]90-tom had just come to trouble with [his]90-tom presence]256-the family of paupers whom he had just come to trouble with his presence . CHAPTER II . [Tom]90-tom ’s early life . Let [us]257-us skip a number of years . [London]1-london was fifteen hundred years old , and was [a great town]258-a great town -- for that day . [It]1-london had [a hundred thousand inhabitants]259-a hundred thousand inhabitants -- [some think double as many]260-some think double as many . [The streets]261-the streets were very narrow , and crooked , and dirty , especially in the part where [Tom Canty]90-tom lived , which was not far from [London Bridge]4-london bridge . [The houses]262-the houses were of wood , with the second story projecting over the first , and the third sticking [its]263-its elbows out beyond the second . The higher [the houses]262-the houses grew , the broader [they]262-the houses grew . [They]262-the houses were skeletons of strong criss - cross beams , with solid material between , coated with plaster . The beams were painted red or blue or black , according to [the owner]265-the owner ’s taste , and this gave [the houses]262-the houses a very picturesque look . The windows were small , glazed with little diamond - shaped panes , and they opened outward , on hinges , like doors . [The house which [[Tom]90-tom ’s father lived in]268-tom ’s father lived in]267-the house which tom ’s father lived in was up [a foul little pocket called [Offal Court]18-offal court , out of [Pudding Lane]6-pudding lane]269-a foul little pocket called offal court , out of pudding lane . [It]267-the house which tom ’s father lived in was small , decayed , and rickety , but [it]267-the house which tom ’s father lived in was packed full of [wretchedly poor families]270-wretchedly poor families . [[Canty]90-tom ’s tribe]271-canty ’s tribe occupied [a room on the third floor]272-a room on the third floor . [The mother]273-the mother and [father]274-father had a sort of bedstead in the corner ; but [Tom]90-tom , [[his]90-tom grandmother]275-his grandmother , and [[his]90-tom two sisters]276-his two sisters , [Bet]91-the lady elizabeth and [Nan]92-nan , were not restricted -- [they]271-canty ’s tribe had all the floor to [themselves]271-canty ’s tribe , and might sleep where [they]271-canty ’s tribe chose . There were the remains of a blanket or two , and some bundles of ancient and dirty straw , but these could not rightly be called beds , for they were not organised ; they were kicked into a general pile , mornings , and selections made from the mass at night , for service . [Bet]91-the lady elizabeth and [Nan]92-nan were fifteen years old -- [twins]277-twins . [They]277-twins were [good - hearted girls]278-good - hearted girls , [unclean]279-unclean , clothed in rags , and profoundly ignorant . [[Their]277-twins mother]280-their mother was like [them]277-twins . But [the father]281-the father and [the grandmother]282-the grandmother were [a couple of fiends]283-a couple of fiends . [They]277-twins got drunk whenever [they]277-twins could ; then [they]277-twins fought [each other]246-each other or [anybody else who came in the way]285-anybody else who came in the way ; [they]277-twins cursed and swore always , drunk or sober ; [John Canty]93-john canty was [a thief]286-a thief , and [[his]93-john canty mother]287-his mother [a beggar]288-a beggar . [They]277-twins made [beggars of [the children]290-the children]289-beggars of the children , but failed to make [thieves]291-thieves of [them]290-the children . Among , but not of , the dreadful rabble that inhabited [the house]292-the house , was [a good old priest whom [the King]294-the king had turned out of [house]295-house and [home]296-home with a pension of a few farthings]293-a good old priest whom the king had turned out of house and home with a pension of a few farthings , and [he]293-a good old priest whom the king had turned out of house and home with a pension of a few farthings used to get [the children]290-the children aside and teach [them]290-the children right ways secretly . [Father Andrew]94-father andrew also taught [Tom]90-tom a little Latin , and how to read and write ; and would have done the same with [the girls]298-the girls , but [they]277-twins were afraid of the jeers of [[their]277-twins friends]299-their friends , who could not have endured such a queer accomplishment in [them]277-twins . [All Offal Court]300-all offal court was just [such another hive as [[Canty]90-tom ’s house]302-canty ’s house]301-such another hive as canty ’s house . Drunkenness , riot and brawling were the order , there , every night and nearly all night long . Broken heads were as common as hunger in [that place]303-that place . Yet [little Tom]90-tom was not unhappy . [He]90-tom had a hard time of it , but did not know it . It was the sort of time that [all the Offal Court boys]304-all the offal court boys had , therefore [he]90-tom supposed it was the correct and comfortable thing . When [he]90-tom came [home]296-home empty - handed at night , [he]90-tom knew [[his]90-tom father]306-his father would curse [him]90-tom and thrash [him]90-tom first , and that when [he]90-tom was done [the awful grandmother]307-the awful grandmother would do it all over again and improve on it ; and that away in the night [[his]90-tom starving mother]308-his starving mother would slip to [him]90-tom stealthily with any miserable scrap or crust [she]308-his starving mother had been able to save for [him]90-tom by going hungry [herself]308-his starving mother , notwithstanding [she]308-his starving mother was often caught in that sort of treason and soundly beaten for it by [[her]308-his starving mother husband]309-her husband . No , [Tom]90-tom ’s life went along well enough , especially in summer . [He]90-tom only begged just enough to save [himself]90-tom , for the laws against [mendicancy]310-mendicancy were stringent , and the penalties heavy ; so [he]90-tom put in a good deal of [his]90-tom time listening to [good Father Andrew]94-father andrew ’s charming old tales and legends about giants and fairies , [dwarfs and genii]311-dwarfs and genii , and [enchanted castles]312-enchanted castles , and [gorgeous kings]313-gorgeous kings and [princes]314-princes . [His]90-tom head grew to be full of these wonderful things , and many a night as [he]90-tom lay in the dark on [his]90-tom scant and offensive straw , tired , hungry , and smarting from a thrashing , [he]90-tom unleashed [his]90-tom imagination and soon forgot [his]90-tom aches and pains in delicious picturings to [himself]90-tom of the charmed life of [a petted prince in [a regal palace]316-a regal palace]315-a petted prince in a regal palace . One desire came in time to haunt [him]90-tom day and night : it was to see [a real prince]317-a real prince , with [his]90-tom own eyes . [He]90-tom spoke of it once to [some of [[his]90-tom Offal Court comrades]319-his offal court comrades]318-some of his offal court comrades ; but [they]318-some of his offal court comrades jeered [him]90-tom and scoffed [him]90-tom so unmercifully that [he]90-tom was glad to keep [his]90-tom dream to [himself]90-tom after that . [He]90-tom often read [the priest]320-the priest ’s old books and got [him]90-tom to explain and enlarge upon them . [His]90-tom dreamings and readings worked certain changes in [him]90-tom , by - and - by . [His]90-tom dream - [people]321-people were so fine that [he]90-tom grew to lament [his]90-tom shabby clothing and [his]90-tom dirt , and to wish to be clean and better clad . [He]90-tom went on playing in the mud just the same , and enjoying it , too ; but , instead of splashing around in [the Thames]7-the thames solely for the fun of it , [he]90-tom began to find an added value in it because of the washings and cleansings it afforded . [Tom]90-tom could always find something going on around the Maypole in [Cheapside]8-cheapside , and at the fairs ; and now and then [he]90-tom and [the rest of [London]1-london]322-the rest of london had a chance to see a military parade when [some famous unfortunate]323-some famous unfortunate was carried prisoner to [the Tower]19-the tower , by land or [boat]324-boat . One summer ’s day [he]90-tom saw poor [Anne Askew]92-nan and [three men]325-three men burned at the stake in [Smithfield]10-smithfield , and heard [an ex - Bishop]326-an ex - bishop preach a sermon to [them]325-three men which did not interest [him]90-tom . Yes , [Tom]90-tom ’s life was varied and pleasant enough , on the whole . By - and - by [Tom]90-tom ’s reading and dreaming about princely life wrought such a strong effect upon [him]90-tom that [he]90-tom began to _ act _ [the prince]236-the prince , unconsciously . [His]90-tom speech and manners became curiously ceremonious and courtly , to the vast admiration and amusement of [[his]90-tom intimates]328-his intimates . But [Tom]90-tom ’s influence among [these young people]329-these young people began to grow now , day by day ; and in time [he]90-tom came to be looked up to , by [them]329-these young people , with a sort of wondering awe , as [a superior being]330-a superior being . [He]90-tom seemed to know so much ! and [he]90-tom could do and say such marvellous things ! and withal , [he]90-tom was so deep and wise ! [Tom]90-tom ’s remarks , and [Tom]90-tom ’s performances , were reported by [the boys]331-the boys to [[their]331-the boys elders]332-their elders ; and these , also , presently began to discuss [Tom Canty]90-tom , and to regard [him]90-tom as [a most gifted and extraordinary creature]333-a most gifted and extraordinary creature . [Full - grown people]334-full - grown people brought [their]334-full - grown people perplexities to [Tom]90-tom for solution , and were often astonished at the wit and wisdom of [his]90-tom decisions . In fact [he]90-tom was become [a hero to all who knew [him]90-tom except [[his]90-tom own family]336-his own family]335-a hero to all who knew him except his own family -- these , only , saw nothing in [him]90-tom . Privately , after a while , [Tom]90-tom organised [a royal court]337-a royal court ! [He]90-tom was [the prince]236-the prince ; [[his]90-tom special comrades]339-his special comrades were [guards]340-guards , [chamberlains]341-chamberlains , [equerries]342-equerries , [lords]343-lords and [ladies in waiting]344-ladies in waiting , and [the royal family]345-the royal family . Daily [the mock prince]346-the mock prince was received with elaborate ceremonials borrowed by [Tom]90-tom from [his]90-tom romantic readings ; daily the great affairs of [the mimic kingdom]347-the mimic kingdom were discussed in the royal council , and daily [[his]90-tom mimic highness]348-his mimic highness issued decrees to [[his]90-tom imaginary armies]349-his imaginary armies , [navies]350-navies , and viceroyalties . After which , [he]90-tom would go forth in [his]90-tom rags and beg a few farthings , eat [his]90-tom poor crust , take [his]90-tom customary cuffs and abuse , and then stretch [himself]90-tom upon [his]90-tom handful of foul straw , and resume [his]90-tom empty grandeurs in [his]90-tom dreams . And still [his]90-tom desire to look just once upon [a real prince , in the flesh]351-a real prince , in the flesh , grew upon [him]90-tom , day by day , and week by week , until at last it absorbed all other desires , and became the one passion of [his]90-tom life . One January day , on [his]90-tom usual begging tour , [he]90-tom tramped despondently up and down [the region]352-the region round about [Mincing Lane]11-mincing lane and [Little East Cheap]12-little east cheap , hour after hour , bare - footed and cold , looking in at [cook - shop]353-cook - shop windows and longing for the dreadful pork - pies and other deadly inventions displayed there -- for to [him]90-tom these were dainties fit for [the angels]354-the angels ; that is , judging by the smell , they were -- for it had never been [his]90-tom good luck to own and eat one . There was a cold drizzle of rain ; the atmosphere was murky ; it was a melancholy day . At night [Tom]90-tom reached [home]296-home so wet and tired and hungry that it was not possible for [[his]90-tom father]306-his father and [grandmother]357-grandmother to observe [his]90-tom forlorn condition and not be moved -- after [their]358-their fashion ; wherefore [they]358-their gave [him]90-tom a brisk cuffing at once and sent [him]90-tom to bed . For a long time [his]90-tom pain and hunger , and the swearing and fighting going on in [the building]359-the building , kept [him]90-tom awake ; but at last [his]90-tom thoughts drifted away to [far , romantic lands]360-far , romantic lands , and [he]90-tom fell asleep in [the company of jewelled and gilded princelings who live in [vast palaces]362-vast palaces , and had [servants]363-servants salaaming before [them]363-servants or flying to execute [their]363-servants orders]361-the company of jewelled and gilded princelings who live in vast palaces , and had servants salaaming before them or flying to execute their orders . And then , as usual , [he]90-tom dreamed that _ [he]90-tom _ was [a princeling]364-a princeling [himself]90-tom . All night long the glories of [[his]90-tom royal estate]365-his royal estate shone upon [him]90-tom ; [he]90-tom moved among [great lords]253-great lords and [ladies]254-ladies , in a blaze of light , breathing perfumes , drinking in delicious music , and answering the reverent obeisances of [the glittering throng]368-the glittering throng as it parted to make way for [him]90-tom , with here a smile , and there a nod of [his]90-tom princely head . And when [he]90-tom awoke in the morning and looked upon the wretchedness about [him]90-tom , [his]90-tom dream had had its usual effect -- it had intensified the sordidness of [his]90-tom surroundings a thousandfold . Then came bitterness , and heart - break , and tears . CHAPTER III . [Tom]90-tom ’s meeting with [the Prince]236-the prince . [Tom]90-tom got up hungry , and sauntered hungry away , but with [his]90-tom thoughts busy with the shadowy splendours of [his]90-tom night ’s dreams . [He]90-tom wandered here and there in [the city]370-the city , hardly noticing where [he]90-tom was going , or what was happening around [him]90-tom . [People]321-people jostled [him]90-tom , and [some]372-some gave [him]90-tom rough speech ; but it was all lost on [the musing boy]373-the musing boy . By - and - by [he]90-tom found [himself]90-tom at [Temple Bar]13-temple bar , [the farthest from [home]296-home [he]90-tom had ever travelled in that direction]374-the farthest from home he had ever travelled in that direction . [He]90-tom stopped and considered a moment , then fell into [his]90-tom imaginings again , and passed on outside the walls of [London]1-london . [The Strand]376-the strand had ceased to be [a country - road]377-a country - road then , and regarded [itself]376-the strand as [a street]378-a street , but by a strained construction ; for , though there was [a tolerably compact row of houses on one side of [it]376-the strand]379-a tolerably compact row of houses on one side of it , there were only [some scattered great buildings on the other]380-some scattered great buildings on the other , these being palaces of [rich nobles]381-rich nobles , with ample and beautiful grounds stretching to the river -- grounds that are now closely packed with grim acres of brick and stone . [Tom]90-tom discovered [Charing Village]14-charing village presently , and rested [himself]90-tom at [the beautiful cross built there by [a bereaved king of earlier days]383-a bereaved king of earlier days]382-the beautiful cross built there by a bereaved king of earlier days ; then idled down [a quiet , lovely road]384-a quiet , lovely road , past [[the great cardinal]385-the great cardinal ’s stately palace]386-the great cardinal ’s stately palace , toward [a far more mighty and majestic palace beyond -- [Westminster]15-westminster]387-a far more mighty and majestic palace beyond -- westminster . [Tom]90-tom stared in glad wonder at the vast pile of masonry , the wide - spreading wings , the frowning bastions and turrets , the huge stone gateway , with [its]388-its gilded bars and [its]388-its magnificent array of colossal granite lions , and other the signs and symbols of [English royalty]389-english royalty . Was the desire of [his]90-tom soul to be satisfied at last ? Here , indeed , was [[a king]390-a king ’s palace]391-a king ’s palace . Might [he]90-tom not hope to see [a prince]392-a prince now -- [a prince of flesh and blood]393-a prince of flesh and blood , if [Heaven]95-heaven were willing ? At each side of the gilded gate stood a living statue -- that is to say , [an erect and stately and motionless man - at - arms , clad from head to heel in shining steel armour]394-an erect and stately and motionless man - at - arms , clad from head to heel in shining steel armour . At a respectful distance were many [country folk]395-country folk , and [people from [the city]370-the city]396-people from the city , waiting for any chance glimpse of [royalty that might offer]398-royalty that might offer . [Splendid carriages]399-splendid carriages , with [splendid people]400-splendid people in [them]399-splendid carriages and [splendid servants outside]401-splendid servants outside , were arriving and departing by several other noble gateways that pierced [the royal enclosure]402-the royal enclosure . Poor little [Tom]90-tom , in [his]90-tom rags , approached , and was moving slowly and timidly past [the sentinels]403-the sentinels , with a beating heart and a rising hope , when all at once [he]90-tom caught sight through the golden bars of a spectacle that almost made [him]90-tom shout for joy . Within was [a comely boy , tanned and brown with sturdy outdoor sports and exercises , whose clothing was all of lovely silks and satins , shining with jewels]404-a comely boy , tanned and brown with sturdy outdoor sports and exercises , whose clothing was all of lovely silks and satins , shining with jewels ; at [his]404-a comely boy , tanned and brown with sturdy outdoor sports and exercises , whose clothing was all of lovely silks and satins , shining with jewels hip a little jewelled sword and dagger ; dainty buskins on [his]404-a comely boy , tanned and brown with sturdy outdoor sports and exercises , whose clothing was all of lovely silks and satins , shining with jewels feet , with red heels ; and on [his]404-a comely boy , tanned and brown with sturdy outdoor sports and exercises , whose clothing was all of lovely silks and satins , shining with jewels head a jaunty crimson cap , with drooping plumes fastened with a great sparkling gem . [Several gorgeous gentlemen]405-several gorgeous gentlemen stood near -- [[his]404-a comely boy , tanned and brown with sturdy outdoor sports and exercises , whose clothing was all of lovely silks and satins , shining with jewels servants]406-his servants , without a doubt . Oh ! [he]404-a comely boy , tanned and brown with sturdy outdoor sports and exercises , whose clothing was all of lovely silks and satins , shining with jewels was [a prince]392-a prince -- [a prince]392-a prince , [a living prince]409-a living prince , [a real prince]317-a real prince -- without the shadow of a question ; and the prayer of [the pauper - boy]411-the pauper - boy ’s heart was answered at last . [Tom]90-tom ’s breath came quick and short with excitement , and [his]90-tom eyes grew big with wonder and delight . Everything gave way in [his]90-tom mind instantly to one desire : that was to get close to [the prince]236-the prince , and have a good , devouring look at [him]236-the prince . Before [he]90-tom knew what [he]90-tom was about , [he]90-tom had [his]90-tom face against the gate - bars . The next instant one of [the soldiers]413-the soldiers snatched [him]90-tom rudely away , and sent [him]90-tom spinning among [the gaping crowd of country gawks and [London]1-london idlers]414-the gaping crowd of country gawks and london idlers . [The soldier]415-the soldier said,-- “ Mind [thy]90-tom manners , [thou young beggar]3045-thou young beggar ! ”[415-the soldier] [The crowd]416-the crowd jeered and laughed ; but [the young prince]417-the young prince sprang to the gate with [his]417-the young prince face flushed , and [his]417-the young prince eyes flashing with indignation , and cried out,-- “ How dar’st [thou]90-tom use [a poor lad]3046-a poor lad like that ? How dar’st [thou]90-tom use [[the King]294-the king [[my]418-you father]3049-my father ’s meanest subject]3048-the king my father ’s meanest subject so ? Open the gates , and let [him]3046-a poor lad in ! ”[418-you] [You]418-you should have seen [that fickle crowd]419-that fickle crowd snatch off [their]419-that fickle crowd hats then . [You]418-you should have heard [them]419-that fickle crowd cheer , and shout , “ Long live [the Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3050-the prince of wales ! ”[419-that fickle crowd] [The soldiers]413-the soldiers presented arms with [their]413-the soldiers halberds , opened the gates , and presented again as [the little Prince of [Poverty]16-poverty]421-the little prince of poverty passed in , in [his]421-the little prince of poverty fluttering rags , to join hands with [the Prince of [Limitless Plenty]17-limitless plenty]422-the prince of limitless plenty . [Edward Tudor]88-edward tudor said-- “ [Thou]3051-thou lookest tired and hungry : [thou’st]3051-thou been treated ill . Come with [me]88-edward tudor . ”[88-edward tudor] [Half a dozen attendants]423-half a dozen attendants sprang forward to -- [I]0-my do n’t know what ; interfere , no doubt . But [they]423-half a dozen attendants were waved aside with a right royal gesture , and [they]423-half a dozen attendants stopped stock still where [they]423-half a dozen attendants were , like so many statues . [Edward]88-edward tudor took [Tom]90-tom to [a rich apartment in [the palace]425-the palace]424-a rich apartment in the palace , which [he]88-edward tudor called [[his]88-edward tudor cabinet]426-his cabinet . By [his]88-edward tudor command a repast was brought such as [Tom]90-tom had never encountered before except in books . [The prince]236-the prince , with princely delicacy and breeding , sent away [the servants]428-the servants , so that [[his]236-the prince humble guest]429-his humble guest might not be embarrassed by [their]428-the servants critical presence ; then [he]236-the prince sat near by , and asked questions while [Tom]90-tom ate . “ What is [thy]236-the prince name , [lad]3052-lad ? ”[236-the prince] “ [Tom Canty]90-tom , an ’ it please [thee]236-the prince , [sir]3053-sir . ”[236-the prince] “ ‘ Tis an odd one . Where dost live ? ”[236-the prince] “ In [the city]370-the city , please [thee]236-the prince , [sir]3053-sir . [Offal Court]18-offal court , out of [Pudding Lane]6-pudding lane . ”[236-the prince] “ [Offal Court]18-offal court ! Truly ’ tis [another odd one]3056-another odd one . [Hast parents]3057-hast parents ? ”[236-the prince] “ [Parents]3058-parents have [I]236-the prince , [sir]3053-sir , and a grand - dam likewise that is but indifferently precious to [me]236-the prince , [God]87-god forgive [me]236-the prince if it be offence to say it -- also [twin sisters]3060-twin sisters , [Nan]92-nan and [Bet]91-the lady elizabeth . ”[236-the prince] “ Then is [thy]236-the prince grand - dam not over kind to [thee]236-the prince , [I]236-the prince take it ? ”[236-the prince] “ Neither to any other is [she]236-the prince , so please [your]236-the prince worship . [She]236-the prince hath a wicked heart , and worketh evil all [her]236-the prince days . ”[236-the prince] “ Doth [she]236-the prince mistreat [thee]236-the prince ? ”[236-the prince] “ There be times that [she]236-the prince stayeth [her]236-the prince hand , being asleep or overcome with drink ; but when [she]236-the prince hath [her]236-the prince judgment clear again , [she]236-the prince maketh it up to [me]236-the prince with goodly beatings . ”[236-the prince] A fierce look came into [the little prince]430-the little prince ’s eyes , and [he]430-the little prince cried out-- “ What ! Beatings ? ”[430-the little prince] “ Oh , indeed , yes , please [you]236-the prince , [sir]3053-sir . ”[236-the prince] “ _ Beatings_!--and [thou]236-the prince so frail and little . Hark [ye]236-the prince : before the night come , [she]236-the prince shall hie [her]236-the prince to [the Tower]19-the tower . [The King]294-the king [my]236-the prince father”--[236-the prince] “ In sooth , [you]236-the prince forget , [sir]3053-sir , [her]236-the prince low degree . [The Tower]3064-the tower is for [the great alone]3065-the great alone . ”[430-the little prince] “ True , indeed . [I]236-the prince had not thought of that . [I]236-the prince will consider of [her]236-the prince punishment . Is [[thy]236-the prince father]3066-thy father kind to [thee]236-the prince ? ”[236-the prince] “ Not more than [Gammer Canty]96-gammer canty , [sir]3053-sir . ”[236-the prince] “ [Fathers]3068-fathers be alike , mayhap . [Mine]236-the prince hath not [a doll]3069-a doll ’s temper . [He]3066-thy father smiteth with a heavy hand , yet spareth [me]430-the little prince : [he]3066-thy father spareth [me]430-the little prince not always with [his]3066-thy father tongue , though , sooth to say . How doth [[thy]236-the prince mother]3070-thy mother use [thee]236-the prince ? ”[430-the little prince] “ [She]3070-thy mother is good , [sir]3053-sir , and giveth [me]236-the prince neither sorrow nor pain of any sort . And [Nan]92-nan and Bet are like to [her]3070-thy mother in this . ”[236-the prince] “ How old be these ? ”[236-the prince] “ Fifteen , an ’ it please [you]3053-sir , [sir]3053-sir . ”[430-the little prince] “ [The Lady Elizabeth]91-the lady elizabeth , [[my]236-the prince sister]3073-my sister , is fourteen , and [the Lady Jane Grey]97-the lady jane grey , [[my]236-the prince cousin]3074-my cousin , is of [mine]236-the prince own age , and comely and gracious withal ; but [[my]236-the prince sister]3073-my sister [the Lady Mary]98-the lady mary , with [her]98-the lady mary gloomy mien and -- Look [you]3053-sir : do [[thy]236-the prince sisters]3076-thy sisters forbid [[their]3076-thy sisters servants]3077-their servants to smile , lest the sin destroy [their]3076-thy sisters souls ? ”[236-the prince] “ [They]3076-thy sisters ? Oh , dost think , [sir]3053-sir , that _ [they]3076-thy sisters _ have [servants]363-servants ? ”[430-the little prince] [The little prince]430-the little prince contemplated [the little pauper]432-the little pauper gravely a moment , then said-- “ And prithee , why not ? Who helpeth [them]3076-thy sisters undress at night ? Who attireth [them]3076-thy sisters when [they]3076-thy sisters rise ? ”[236-the prince] “ None , [sir]3053-sir . Would’st have [them]3076-thy sisters take off [their]3076-thy sisters garment , and sleep without -- like the beasts ? ”[236-the prince] “ [Their]3076-thy sisters garment ! Have [they]3076-thy sisters but one ? ”[236-the prince] “ Ah , good [your]3053-sir worship , what would [they]3076-thy sisters do with more ? Truly [they]3076-thy sisters have [not two bodies each]3081-not two bodies each . ”[236-the prince] “ It is a quaint and marvellous thought ! [Thy]3053-sir pardon , [I]236-the prince had not meant to laugh . But [[thy]3053-sir good Nan]3082-thy good nan and [thy]3053-sir Bet shall have raiment and lackeys enow , and that soon , too : [[my]236-the prince cofferer]3083-my cofferer shall look to it . No , thank [me]236-the prince not ; ’ tis nothing . [Thou]3053-sir speakest well ; [thou]3053-sir hast an easy grace in it . Art learned ? ”[236-the prince] “ [I]236-the prince know not if [I]236-the prince am or not , [sir]3053-sir . [The good priest that is called [Father Andrew]94-father andrew]3085-the good priest that is called father andrew taught [me]236-the prince , of [his]3085-the good priest that is called father andrew kindness , from [his]3085-the good priest that is called father andrew books . ”[236-the prince] “ Know’st [thou]3053-sir the Latin ? ”[236-the prince] “ But scantly , [sir]3053-sir , [I]236-the prince doubt . ”[236-the prince] “ Learn it , [lad]3052-lad : ’ tis hard only at first . The Greek is harder ; but neither these nor any tongues else , [I]236-the prince think , are hard to [the Lady Elizabeth]91-the lady elizabeth and [[my]236-the prince cousin]3074-my cousin . [Thou]3053-sir should’st hear [those damsels]3089-those damsels at it ! But tell [me]236-the prince of [[thy]3053-sir [Offal Court]3091-offal court]3090-thy offal court . Hast [thou]3053-sir a pleasant life there ? ”[236-the prince] “ In truth , yes , so please [you]3053-sir , [sir]3053-sir , save when [one]3093-one is hungry . There be Punch - and - Judy shows , and monkeys -- oh [such antic creatures]3094-such antic creatures ! and so bravely dressed!--and there be plays wherein [they]3095-they that play do shout and fight till [all are slain]3096-all are slain , and ’ tis so fine to see , and costeth but a farthing -- albeit ’ tis main hard to get the farthing , please [your]3053-sir worship . ”[236-the prince] “ Tell [me]236-the prince more . ”[236-the prince] “ [[We]3097-we lads of [Offal Court]3091-offal court]3098-we lads of offal court do strive against each other with the cudgel , like to the fashion of [the ‘ prentices]3100-the ‘ prentices , sometimes . ”[236-the prince] [The prince]236-the prince ’s eyes flashed . Said he-- “ [Marry]99-marry , that would not [I]236-the prince mislike . Tell [me]236-the prince more . ”[236-the prince] “ [We]3097-we strive in races , [sir]3053-sir , to see who of [us]3097-we shall be fleetest . ”[236-the prince] “ That would [I]236-the prince like also . Speak on . ”[236-the prince] “ In summer , [sir]3053-sir , [we]3097-we wade and swim in [the canals]3103-the canals and in [the river]3104-the river , and each doth duck [[his]236-the prince neighbour]3105-his neighbour , and splatter [him]3105-his neighbour with water , and dive and shout and tumble and-- ”[236-the prince] “ ‘ Twould be worth [[my]236-the prince father]3049-my father ’s kingdom but to enjoy it once ! [Prithee]100-prithee go on . ”[236-the prince] “ [We]3097-we dance and sing about the Maypole in [Cheapside]8-cheapside ; [we]3097-we play in the sand , each covering [[his]236-the prince neighbour]3105-his neighbour up ; and times [we]3097-we make mud pastry -- oh the lovely mud , it hath not its like for delightfulness in all [the world!--we]3108-the world!--we do fairly wallow in the mud , [sir]3053-sir , saving [[your]3053-sir worship]3110-your worship ’s presence . ”[236-the prince] “ Oh , [prithee]3111-prithee , say no more , ’ tis glorious ! If that [I]236-the prince could but clothe [me]236-the prince in raiment like to thine , and strip [my]236-the prince feet , and revel in the mud once , just once , with none to rebuke [me]236-the prince or forbid , meseemeth [I]236-the prince could forego the crown ! ”[236-the prince] “ And if that [I]236-the prince could clothe [me]236-the prince once , [sweet sir]3112-sweet sir , as [thou]236-the prince art clad -- just once-- ”[236-the prince] “ Oho , would’st like it ? Then so shall it be . Doff [thy]236-the prince rags , and don these splendours , [lad]3052-lad ! It is a brief happiness , but will be not less keen for that . [We]437-the two will have it while [we]437-the two may , and change again before any come to molest . ”[236-the prince] A few minutes later [the little Prince of Wales]434-the little prince of wales was garlanded with [Tom]90-tom ’s fluttering odds and ends , and [the little Prince of Pauperdom]435-the little prince of pauperdom was tricked out in the gaudy plumage of [royalty]436-royalty . [The two]437-the two went and stood side by side before a great mirror , and lo , a miracle : there did not seem to have been any change made ! [They]437-the two stared at [each other]246-each other , then at the glass , then at [each other]246-each other again . At last [the puzzled princeling]440-the puzzled princeling said-- “ What dost [thou]236-the prince make of this ? ”[440-the puzzled princeling] “ Ah , good [your]236-the prince worship , require [me]440-the puzzled princeling not to answer . It is not meet that [one of [my]440-the puzzled princeling degree]3114-one of my degree should utter the thing . ”[440-the puzzled princeling] “ Then will _ [I]440-the puzzled princeling _ utter it . [Thou]236-the prince hast the same hair , the same eyes , the same voice and manner , the same form and stature , the same face and countenance that [I]440-the puzzled princeling bear . Fared [we]437-the two forth naked , there is none could say which was [you]236-the prince , and which [the Prince of]3115-the prince of [Wales]3-wales . And , now that [I]440-the puzzled princeling am clothed as [thou]236-the prince wert clothed , it seemeth [I]440-the puzzled princeling should be able the more nearly to feel as [thou]236-the prince didst when [the brute soldier]3116-the brute soldier -- Hark [ye]236-the prince , is not this a bruise upon [your]236-the prince hand ? ”[440-the puzzled princeling] “ Yes ; but it is a slight thing , and [your]236-the prince worship knoweth that [the poor man - at - arms--]3117-the poor man - at - arms-- ”[440-the puzzled princeling] “ Peace ! It was a shameful thing and a cruel ! ”[430-the little prince] cried [the little prince]430-the little prince , stamping [his]430-the little prince bare foot . “ If [the King]294-the king -- Stir not a step till [I]430-the little prince come again ! It is a command ! ”[430-the little prince] In a moment [he]430-the little prince had snatched up and put away an article of national importance that lay upon a table , and was out at the door and flying through [the palace grounds]442-the palace grounds in [his]430-the little prince bannered rags , with a hot face and glowing eyes . As soon as [he]430-the little prince reached the great gate , [he]430-the little prince seized the bars , and tried to shake them , shouting-- “ Open ! Unbar the gates ! ”[430-the little prince] [The soldier that had maltreated [Tom]90-tom]443-the soldier that had maltreated tom obeyed promptly ; and as [the prince]236-the prince burst through the portal , half - smothered with royal wrath , [the soldier]415-the soldier fetched [him]236-the prince a sounding box on the ear that sent [him]236-the prince whirling to [the roadway]446-the roadway , and said-- “ Take that , [[thou]3119-thou beggar ’s spawn]3120-thou beggar ’s spawn , for what [thou]3119-thou got’st [me]415-the soldier from [[his]430-the little prince Highness]3121-his highness ! ”[415-the soldier] [The crowd]416-the crowd roared with laughter . [The prince]236-the prince picked [himself]236-the prince out of the mud , and made fiercely at [the sentry]449-the sentry , shouting-- “ [I]415-the soldier am [the Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3050-the prince of wales , [my]415-the soldier person is sacred ; and [thou]3119-thou shalt hang for laying [thy]3119-thou hand upon [me]415-the soldier ! ”[415-the soldier] [The soldier]415-the soldier brought [his]415-the soldier halberd to a present - arms and said mockingly-- “ [I]415-the soldier salute [[your]415-the soldier gracious Highness]3123-your gracious highness . ”[415-the soldier] Then angrily--“Be off , [thou]3119-thou crazy rubbish ! ”[415-the soldier] [Here]451-here [the jeering crowd]452-the jeering crowd closed round [the poor little prince]453-the poor little prince , and hustled [him]453-the poor little prince far down [the road]454-the road , hooting [him]453-the poor little prince , and shouting-- “ Way for [[his]236-the prince Royal Highness]3124-his royal highness ! Way for [the Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3050-the prince of wales ! ”[452-the jeering crowd] CHAPTER IV . [The Prince]236-the prince ’s troubles begin . After hours of persistent pursuit and persecution , [the little prince]430-the little prince was at last deserted by [the rabble]457-the rabble and left to [himself]430-the little prince . As long as [he]430-the little prince had been able to rage against [the mob]458-the mob , and threaten it royally , and royally utter commands that were good stuff to laugh at , [he]430-the little prince was very entertaining ; but when weariness finally forced [him]430-the little prince to be silent , [he]430-the little prince was no longer of use to [[his]430-the little prince tormentors]459-his tormentors , and [they]459-his tormentors sought amusement elsewhere . [He]430-the little prince looked about [him]430-the little prince , now , but could not recognise [the locality]460-the locality . [He]430-the little prince was within [the city of]461-the city of [London]1-london -- that was all [he]430-the little prince knew . [He]430-the little prince moved on , aimlessly , and in a little while [the houses]262-the houses thinned , and [the passers - by]463-the passers - by were infrequent . [He]430-the little prince bathed [his]430-the little prince bleeding feet in [the brook which flowed then where [Farringdon Street]20-farringdon street now is]464-the brook which flowed then where farringdon street now is ; rested a few moments , then passed on , and presently came upon [a great space with only [a few scattered houses]466-a few scattered houses in [it]465-a great space with only a few scattered houses in it]465-a great space with only a few scattered houses in it , and [a prodigious church]467-a prodigious church . [He]430-the little prince recognised [this church]468-this church . Scaffoldings were about , everywhere , and swarms of [workmen]469-workmen ; for [it]468-this church was undergoing elaborate repairs . [The prince]236-the prince took heart at once -- [he]236-the prince felt that [his]236-the prince troubles were at an end , now . [He]236-the prince said to [himself]236-the prince , “ It is [the ancient Grey Friars ’ Church]3126-the ancient grey friars ’ church , which [the king]294-the king [[my]236-the prince father]3049-my father hath taken from [the monks]3129-the monks and given for [a home for ever for [poor and forsaken children]3131-poor and forsaken children]3130-a home for ever for poor and forsaken children , and new - named [it]467-a prodigious church [Christ ’s Church]21-christ ’s church . Right gladly will [they]3132-they serve [the son of [him]294-the king who hath done so generously by [them]3132-they]3133-the son of him who hath done so generously by them -- and the more that [that son]3134-that son is [himself]3134-that son as poor and as forlorn as any that be sheltered [here]451-here this day , or ever shall be . ”[236-the prince] [He]236-the prince was soon in the midst of [a crowd of boys who were running , jumping , playing at ball and leap - frog]471-a crowd of boys who were running , jumping , playing at ball and leap - frog , and otherwise disporting [themselves]471-a crowd of boys who were running , jumping , playing at ball and leap - frog , and right noisily , too . [They]471-a crowd of boys who were running , jumping , playing at ball and leap - frog were all dressed alike , and in the fashion which in that day prevailed among [serving - men]472-serving - men and ‘ prentices{1}--that is to say , [each]473-each had on the crown of [his]473-each head a flat black cap about the size of a saucer , which was not useful as a covering , it being of such scanty dimensions , neither was it ornamental ; from beneath it the hair fell , unparted , to the middle of the forehead , and was cropped straight around ; a clerical band at the neck ; a blue gown that fitted closely and hung as low as the knees or lower ; full sleeves ; a broad red belt ; bright yellow stockings , gartered above the knees ; low shoes with large metal buckles . It was a sufficiently ugly costume . [The boys]331-the boys stopped [their]331-the boys play and flocked about [the prince]236-the prince , who said with native dignity-- “ [Good lads]3136-good lads , say to [[your]3136-good lads master]3137-your master that [[Edward]87-god Prince of [Wales]3-wales]89-prince of wales , who lay lapped in silks and satins , unconscious of all this fuss , and not knowing that great lords and ladies were tending him and watching over him desireth speech with [him]87-god . ”[236-the prince] A great shout went up at this , and [one rude fellow]476-one rude fellow said-- “ Marry , art [thou]89-prince of wales , who lay lapped in silks and satins , unconscious of all this fuss , and not knowing that great lords and ladies were tending him and watching over him [[his]87-god grace]3138-his grace ’s messenger , [beggar]3139-beggar ? ”[476-one rude fellow] [The prince]236-the prince ’s face flushed with anger , and [his]236-the prince ready hand flew to [his]236-the prince hip , but there was nothing there . There was a storm of laughter , and [one boy]478-one boy said-- “ Didst mark that ? [He]478-one boy fancied [he]478-one boy had a sword -- belike [he]478-one boy is [the prince]236-the prince [himself]236-the prince . ”[478-one boy] This sally brought more laughter . [Poor Edward]101-poor edward drew [himself]101-poor edward up proudly and said-- “ [I]101-poor edward am [the prince]236-the prince ; and it ill beseemeth [you]478-one boy that feed upon [the king]294-the king [[my]101-poor edward father]3049-my father ’s bounty to use [me]101-poor edward so . ”[101-poor edward] This was vastly enjoyed , as the laughter testified . [The youth who had first spoken]479-the youth who had first spoken , shouted to [his]479-the youth who had first spoken comrades-- “ [Ho , swine]3144-ho , swine , [slaves]3145-slaves , [pensioners of [[his]294-the king grace ’s princely father]3147-his grace ’s princely father]3146-pensioners of his grace ’s princely father , where be [your]478-one boy manners ? Down on [your]478-one boy marrow bones , all of [ye]478-one boy , and do reverence to [his]294-the king kingly port and royal rags ! ”[479-the youth who had first spoken] With boisterous mirth [they]480-their dropped upon [their]480-their knees in a body and did mock homage to [[their]480-their prey]481-their prey . [The prince]236-the prince spurned [the nearest boy]483-the nearest boy with [his]236-the prince foot , and said fiercely-- “ Take [thou]483-the nearest boy that , till the morrow come and [I]236-the prince build [thee]483-the nearest boy a gibbet ! ”[236-the prince] Ah , but this was not a joke -- this was going beyond fun . The laughter ceased on the instant , and fury took its place . A dozen shouted-- “ Hale [him]294-the king forth ! To [the horse - pond]3148-the horse - pond , to [the horse - pond]3148-the horse - pond ! Where be the dogs ? Ho , there , Lion ! ho , Fangs ! ”[236-the prince] Then followed such a thing as [England]2-england had never seen before -- [the sacred person of [the heir to the throne rudely buffeted by plebeian hands , and set upon and torn by dogs]485-the heir to the throne rudely buffeted by plebeian hands , and set upon and torn by dogs]484-the sacred person of the heir to the throne rudely buffeted by plebeian hands , and set upon and torn by dogs . As night drew to a close that day , [the prince]236-the prince found [himself]236-the prince far down in [the close - built portion of [the city]370-the city]487-the close - built portion of the city . [His]236-the prince body was bruised , [his]236-the prince hands were bleeding , and [his]236-the prince rags were all besmirched with mud . [He]236-the prince wandered on and on , and grew more and more bewildered , and so tired and faint [he]236-the prince could hardly drag one foot after the other . [He]236-the prince had ceased to ask questions of [anyone]489-anyone , since [they]489-anyone brought [him]236-the prince only insult instead of information . [He]236-the prince kept muttering to [himself]236-the prince , “ [Offal Court]3091-offal court -- that is the name ; if [I]236-the prince can but find it before [my]236-the prince strength is wholly spent and [I]236-the prince drop , then am [I]236-the prince saved -- for [[his]236-the prince people]3151-his people will take [me]236-the prince to [the palace]425-the palace and prove that [I]236-the prince am [none of [theirs]3151-his people]3153-none of theirs , but [the true prince]3154-the true prince , and [I]236-the prince shall have [mine]236-the prince own again . ”[236-the prince] And now and then [his]236-the prince mind reverted to [his]236-the prince treatment by [those rude [Christ]102-christ ’s Hospital boys]490-those rude christ ’s hospital boys , and [he]236-the prince said , “ When [I]236-the prince am [king]3155-king , [they]490-those rude christ ’s hospital boys shall not have bread and shelter only , but also teachings out of books ; for a full belly is little worth where the mind is starved , and the heart . [I]236-the prince will keep this diligently in [my]236-the prince remembrance , that this day ’s lesson be not lost upon [me]236-the prince , and [[my]236-the prince people]3156-my people suffer thereby ; for learning softeneth the heart and breedeth gentleness and charity . ”[236-the prince] { 1 } The lights began to twinkle , it came on to rain , the wind rose , and a raw and gusty night set in . [The houseless prince]491-the houseless prince , [the homeless heir to the throne of [England]2-england]492-the homeless heir to the throne of england , still moved on , drifting deeper into the maze of squalid alleys where the swarming hives of poverty and misery were massed together . Suddenly [a great drunken ruffian]493-a great drunken ruffian collared [him]236-the prince and said-- “ Out to this time of night again , and hast not brought a farthing [home]296-home , [I]493-a great drunken ruffian warrant [me]493-a great drunken ruffian ! If it be so , an ’ [I]493-a great drunken ruffian do not break all the bones in [thy]493-a great drunken ruffian lean body , then am [I]493-a great drunken ruffian not [John Canty]93-john canty , but some other . ”[493-a great drunken ruffian] [The prince]236-the prince twisted [himself]236-the prince loose , unconsciously brushed [his]236-the prince profaned shoulder , and eagerly said-- “ Oh , art _ [[his]93-john canty _ father]3158-his _ father , truly ? Sweet heaven grant it be so -- then wilt [thou]493-a great drunken ruffian fetch [him]3158-his _ father away and restore [me]493-a great drunken ruffian ! ”[493-a great drunken ruffian] “ _ [[His]93-john canty _ father]3158-his _ father ? [I]493-a great drunken ruffian know not what [thou]493-a great drunken ruffian mean’st ; [I]493-a great drunken ruffian but know [I]493-a great drunken ruffian am _ [[thy]93-john canty _ father]3160-thy _ father , as [thou]493-a great drunken ruffian shalt soon have cause to-- ”[493-a great drunken ruffian] “ Oh , jest not , [palter]3161-palter not , delay not!--I am worn , [I]495-the man am wounded , [I]495-the man can bear no more . Take [me]495-the man to [the king]294-the king [[my]495-the man father]3049-my father , and [he]294-the king will make [thee]493-a great drunken ruffian rich beyond [thy]493-a great drunken ruffian wildest dreams . Believe [me]495-the man , [man]3164-man , believe me!--I speak no lie , but only the truth!--put forth [thy]493-a great drunken ruffian hand and save [me]495-the man ! [I]495-the man am indeed [the Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3050-the prince of wales ! ”[495-the man] [The man]495-the man stared down , stupefied , upon [the lad]496-the lad , then shook [his]495-the man head and muttered-- “ Gone stark mad as [any Tom o ’ Bedlam!”--then]3166-any tom o ’ bedlam!”--then[496-the lad] collared [him]496-the lad once more , and said with a coarse laugh and an oath , “ But mad or no mad , [I]496-the lad and [thy]493-a great drunken ruffian Gammer Canty will soon find where the soft places in [thy]493-a great drunken ruffian bones lie , or [I]496-the lad ’m [no true man]3167-no true man ! ”[496-the lad] With this [he]495-the man dragged [the frantic and struggling prince]497-the frantic and struggling prince away , and disappeared up [a front court]498-a front court followed by [a delighted and noisy swarm of human vermin]499-a delighted and noisy swarm of human vermin . CHAPTER V. [Tom]90-tom as [a Patrician]500-a patrician . [Tom Canty]90-tom , left alone in [the prince]236-the prince ’s cabinet , made good use of [his]90-tom opportunity . [He]90-tom turned [himself]90-tom this way and that before the great mirror , admiring [his]90-tom finery ; then walked away , imitating [[the prince]236-the prince ’s high - bred carriage]503-the prince ’s high - bred carriage , and still observing results in the glass . Next [he]90-tom drew the beautiful sword , and bowed , kissing the blade , and laying it across [his]90-tom breast , as [he]90-tom had seen [a noble knight]504-a noble knight do , by way of salute to [the lieutenant of the Tower]505-the lieutenant of the tower , five or six weeks before , when delivering [the great lords of [Norfolk]22-norfolk]506-the great lords of norfolk and [Surrey]103-surrey into [his]90-tom hands for captivity . [Tom]90-tom played with the jewelled dagger that hung upon [his]90-tom thigh ; [he]90-tom examined the costly and exquisite ornaments of [the room]507-the room ; [he]90-tom tried each of the sumptuous chairs , and thought how proud [he]90-tom would be if [the Offal Court herd]508-the offal court herd could only peep in and see [him]90-tom in [his]90-tom grandeur . [He]90-tom wondered if [they]508-the offal court herd would believe the marvellous tale [he]90-tom should tell when [he]90-tom got [home]296-home , or if [they]508-the offal court herd would shake [their]508-the offal court herd heads , and say [his]90-tom overtaxed imagination had at last upset [his]90-tom reason . At the end of half an hour it suddenly occurred to [him]90-tom that [the prince]236-the prince was gone a long time ; then right away [he]90-tom began to feel lonely ; very soon [he]90-tom fell to listening and longing , and ceased to toy with the pretty things about [him]90-tom ; [he]90-tom grew uneasy , then restless , then distressed . Suppose [some one]511-some one should come , and catch [him]90-tom in [the prince]236-the prince ’s clothes , and [the prince]236-the prince not there to explain . Might [they]511-some one not hang [him]90-tom at once , and inquire into [his]90-tom case afterward ? [He]90-tom had heard that [the great]514-the great were prompt about small matters . [His]90-tom fear rose higher and higher ; and trembling [he]90-tom softly opened the door to the antechamber , resolved to fly and seek [the prince]236-the prince , and , through [him]90-tom , protection and release . [Six gorgeous gentlemen - servants]516-six gorgeous gentlemen - servants and [two young pages of high degree , clothed like butterflies]517-two young pages of high degree , clothed like butterflies , sprang to [their]516-six gorgeous gentlemen - servants feet and bowed low before [him]90-tom . [He]90-tom stepped quickly back and shut the door . [He]90-tom said-- “ Oh , [they]516-six gorgeous gentlemen - servants mock at [me]90-tom ! [They]516-six gorgeous gentlemen - servants will go and tell . Oh ! why came [I]90-tom here to cast away [my]90-tom life ? ”[90-tom] [He]90-tom walked up and down the floor , filled with nameless fears , listening , starting at every trifling sound . Presently the door swung open , and [a silken page]518-a silken page said-- “ [The Lady Jane Grey]97-the lady jane grey . ”[518-a silken page] The door closed and [a sweet young girl , richly clad]519-a sweet young girl , richly clad , bounded toward [him]90-tom . But [she]519-a sweet young girl , richly clad stopped suddenly , and said in a distressed voice-- “ Oh , what aileth [thee]90-tom , [[my]519-a sweet young girl , richly clad lord]3168-my lord ? ”[519-a sweet young girl , richly clad] [Tom]90-tom ’s breath was nearly failing [him]90-tom ; but [he]90-tom made shift to stammer out-- “ Ah , be merciful , [thou]3169-thou ! In sooth [I]90-tom am [no lord]3170-no lord , but only [poor [Tom]90-tom Canty of Offal Court in [the city]370-the city]3171-poor tom canty of offal court in the city . [Prithee]100-prithee let [me]90-tom see [the prince]236-the prince , and [he]236-the prince will of [his]236-the prince grace restore to [me]90-tom [my]90-tom rags , and let [me]90-tom hence unhurt . Oh , be [thou]3169-thou merciful , and save [me]90-tom ! ”[90-tom] By this time [the boy]520-the boy was on [his]520-the boy knees , and supplicating with [his]520-the boy eyes and uplifted hands as well as with [his]520-the boy tongue . [The young girl]521-the young girl seemed horror - stricken . [She]521-the young girl cried out-- “ O [[my]521-the young girl lord]3168-my lord , on [thy]520-the boy knees?--and to _ [me]521-the young girl _ ! ”[521-the young girl] Then [she]521-the young girl fled away in fright ; and [Tom]90-tom , smitten with despair , sank down , murmuring-- “ There is no help , there is no hope . Now will [they]3175-they come and take [me]90-tom . ”[90-tom] Whilst [he]90-tom lay there benumbed with terror , dreadful tidings were speeding through [the palace]425-the palace . The whisper -- for it was whispered always -- flew from [menial]523-menial to menial , from [lord]524-lord to [lady]525-lady , down [all the long corridors]526-all the long corridors , from story to story , from [saloon]527-saloon to saloon , “ [The prince]236-the prince hath gone mad , [the prince]236-the prince hath gone mad ! ”[523-menial] Soon [every saloon]528-every saloon , [every marble hall]529-every marble hall , had [its groups of [glittering lords]531-glittering lords and [ladies]254-ladies]530-its groups of glittering lords and ladies , and other groups of [dazzling lesser folk]533-dazzling lesser folk , talking earnestly together in whispers , and every face had in [it]534-it dismay . Presently [a splendid official]535-a splendid official came marching by [these groups]536-these groups , making solemn proclamation-- “ IN THE NAME OF [THE KING]294-the king ! Let [none]3179-none list to this false and foolish matter , upon pain of death , nor discuss the same , nor carry it abroad . In the name of [the King]294-the king ! ”[535-a splendid official] The whisperings ceased as suddenly as if [the whisperers]537-the whisperers had been stricken dumb . Soon there was a general buzz along [the corridors]538-the corridors , of “ [The prince]236-the prince ! See , [the prince]236-the prince comes ! ”[90-tom] [Poor Tom]90-tom came slowly walking past the low - bowing groups , trying to bow in return , and meekly gazing upon [his]90-tom strange surroundings with bewildered and pathetic eyes . [Great nobles]539-great nobles walked upon each side of [him]90-tom , making [him]90-tom lean upon [them]539-great nobles , and so steady [his]90-tom steps . Behind [him]90-tom followed [the court - physicians]540-the court - physicians and [some servants]541-some servants . Presently [Tom]90-tom found [himself]90-tom in [a noble apartment of [the palace]425-the palace]542-a noble apartment of the palace and heard the door close behind [him]90-tom . Around [him]90-tom stood [those who had come with [him]90-tom]544-those who had come with him . Before [him]90-tom , at a little distance , reclined [a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression . [His]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression large head was very grey ; and [his]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression whiskers , which [he]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression wore only around [his]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression face , like a frame , were grey also . [His]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression clothing was of rich stuff , but old , and slightly frayed in places . One of [his]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression swollen legs had a pillow under it , and was wrapped in bandages . There was silence now ; and there was no head there but was bent in reverence , except [this man]546-this man ’s . [This stern - countenanced invalid]547-this stern - countenanced invalid was the dread [Henry VIII]105-henry viii . [He]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression said -- and [his]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression face grew gentle as [he]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression began to speak-- “ How now , [[my]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression lord]3168-my lord [Edward]101-poor edward , [[my]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression prince]3184-my prince ? Hast been minded to cozen [me]545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression , [the good King [[thy]101-poor edward father]3066-thy father , who loveth [thee]101-poor edward , and kindly useth [thee]101-poor edward , with a sorry jest]3185-the good king thy father , who loveth thee , and kindly useth thee , with a sorry jest ? ”[545-a very large and very fat man , with a wide , pulpy face , and a stern expression] [Poor Tom]90-tom was listening , as well as [his]90-tom dazed faculties would let [him]90-tom , to the beginning of this speech ; but when the words ‘ [me]0-my , [the good King]548-the good king ’ fell upon [his]90-tom ear , [his]90-tom face blanched , and [he]90-tom dropped as instantly upon [his]90-tom knees as if a shot had brought [him]90-tom there . Lifting up [his]90-tom hands , [he]90-tom exclaimed-- “ [Thou]294-the king [the _ King _]3187-the _ king _ ? Then am [I]90-tom undone indeed ! ”[90-tom] This speech seemed to stun [the King]294-the king . [His]90-tom eyes wandered from face to face aimlessly , then rested , bewildered , upon [the boy before [him]90-tom]550-the boy before him . Then [he]90-tom said in a tone of deep disappointment-- “ [Alack]106-alack , [I]90-tom had believed the rumour disproportioned to the truth ; but [I]90-tom fear [me]90-tom ’ tis not so . ”[90-tom] [He]90-tom breathed a heavy sigh , and said in a gentle voice , “ Come to [[thy]106-alack father]3066-thy father , [child]3189-child : [thou]106-alack art not well . ”[90-tom] [Tom]90-tom was assisted to [his]90-tom feet , and approached [the Majesty of [England]2-england]551-the majesty of england , humble and trembling . [The King]294-the king took the frightened face between [his]294-the king hands , and gazed earnestly and lovingly into it awhile , as if seeking some grateful sign of returning reason there , then pressed the curly head against [his]294-the king breast , and patted it tenderly . Presently [he]294-the king said-- “ Dost not know [[thy]106-alack father]3066-thy father , [child]3189-child ? Break not [mine]90-tom old heart ; say [thou]106-alack know’st [me]294-the king . [Thou]106-alack _ dost _ know [me]294-the king , dost [thou]106-alack not ? ”[294-the king] “ [Yea]3192-yea : [thou]106-alack art [[my]294-the king dread lord the King , whom [God]87-god preserve]3193-my dread lord the king , whom god preserve ! ”[294-the king] “ True , true -- that is well -- be comforted , tremble not so ; there is none here would hurt [thee]106-alack ; there is none here but loves [thee]106-alack . [Thou]106-alack art better now ; [thy]106-alack ill dream passeth -- is’t not so ? [Thou]106-alack wilt not miscall [thyself]3194-thyself again , as [they]3195-they say [thou]106-alack didst a little while agone ? ”[294-the king] “ [I]294-the king pray [thee]106-alack of [[thy]106-alack grace]3196-thy grace believe [me]294-the king , [I]294-the king did but speak the truth , [most dread lord]3197-most dread lord ; for [I]294-the king am the meanest among [[thy]106-alack subjects]3198-thy subjects , being [a pauper born]3199-a pauper born , and ’ tis by a sore mischance and accident [I]294-the king am here , albeit [I]294-the king was therein nothing blameful . [I]294-the king am but young to die , and [thou]106-alack canst save [me]294-the king with one little word . Oh speak it , [sir]3053-sir ! ”[294-the king] “ Die ? Talk not so , [sweet prince]3201-sweet prince -- peace , peace , to [thy]106-alack troubled heart -- [thou]106-alack shalt not die ! ”[294-the king] [Tom]90-tom dropped upon [his]90-tom knees with a glad cry-- “ [God]87-god requite [thy]106-alack mercy , [O [my]90-tom King]3202-o my king , and save [thee]106-alack long to bless [[thy]106-alack land]3203-thy land ! ”[90-tom] Then springing up , [he]90-tom turned a joyful face toward [the two lords in waiting]553-the two lords in waiting , and exclaimed , “ [Thou]106-alack heard’st it ! [I]90-tom am not to die : [the King]294-the king hath said it ! ”[90-tom] There was no movement , save that all bowed with grave respect ; but [no one]554-no one spoke . [He]90-tom hesitated , a little confused , then turned timidly toward [the King]294-the king , saying , “ [I]90-tom may go now ? ”[90-tom] “ Go ? Surely , if [thou]106-alack desirest . But why not tarry yet a little ? Whither would’st go ? ”[90-tom] [Tom]90-tom dropped [his]90-tom eyes , and answered humbly-- “ Peradventure [I]90-tom mistook ; but [I]90-tom did think [me]90-tom free , and so was [I]90-tom moved to seek again the kennel where [I]90-tom was born and bred to misery , yet which harboureth [[my]90-tom mother]3205-my mother and [[my]90-tom sisters]3206-my sisters , and so is [home]296-home to [me]90-tom ; whereas [these pomps and splendours]3208-these pomps and splendours whereunto [I]90-tom am not used -- oh , please [you]294-the king , [sir]3053-sir , to let [me]90-tom go ! ”[90-tom] [The King]294-the king was silent and thoughtful a while , and [his]294-the king face betrayed a growing distress and uneasiness . Presently [he]294-the king said , with something of hope in [his]294-the king voice-- “ Perchance [he]294-the king is but mad upon this one strain , and [hath]294-the king [his]294-the king wits unmarred as toucheth other matter . [God]87-god send it may be so ! [We]3210-we will make trial . ”[294-the king] Then [he]294-the king asked [Tom]90-tom a question in Latin , and [Tom]90-tom answered [him]90-tom lamely in the same tongue . [The lords]557-the lords and [doctors]558-doctors manifested [their]559-their gratification also . [The King]294-the king said-- “ ‘ Twas not according to [his]294-the king schooling and ability , but showeth that [his]294-the king mind is but diseased , not stricken fatally . How say [you]294-the king , [sir]3053-sir ? ”[561-the physician] [The physician]561-the physician addressed bowed low , and replied-- “ It jumpeth with [my]294-the king own conviction , [sire]3212-sire , that [thou]3213-thou hast divined aright . ”[294-the king] [The King]294-the king looked pleased with this encouragement , coming as it did from so excellent authority , and continued with good heart-- “ Now mark [ye]3214-ye all : [we]3214-ye will try [him]294-the king further . ”[294-the king] [He]294-the king put a question to [Tom]90-tom in French . [Tom]90-tom stood silent a moment , embarrassed by having so many eyes centred upon [him]90-tom , then said diffidently-- “ [I]294-the king have no knowledge of this tongue , so please [[your]294-the king majesty]3215-your majesty . ”[294-the king] [The King]294-the king fell back upon [his]294-the king couch . [The attendants]564-the attendants flew to [his]294-the king assistance ; but [he]294-the king put [them]564-the attendants aside , and said-- “ Trouble [me]294-the king not -- it is nothing but a scurvy faintness . Raise [me]294-the king ! [There]3216-there , ‘ tis sufficient . Come hither , [child]3189-child ; there , rest [thy]3189-child poor troubled head upon [[thy]3189-child father]3066-thy father ’s heart , and be at peace . [Thou’lt]3219-thou’lt soon be well : ’ tis but a passing fantasy . Fear [thou]3219-thou’lt not ; thou’lt soon be well . ”[294-the king] Then [he]294-the king turned toward [the company]565-the company : [his]294-the king gentle manner changed , and baleful lightnings began to play from [his]294-the king eyes . [He]294-the king said-- “ List [ye]565-the company all ! This [[my]294-the king son]3220-my son is mad ; but it is not permanent . Over - study hath done this , and somewhat too much of confinement . Away with [his]3220-my son books and [teachers]3221-teachers ! see [ye]565-the company to it . Pleasure [him]3220-my son with sports , beguile [him]3220-my son in wholesome ways , so that [his]3220-my son health come again . ”[294-the king] [He]294-the king raised [himself]294-the king higher still , and went on with energy , “ [He]3220-my son is mad ; but [he]3220-my son is [[my]294-the king son]3220-my son , and [[England]2-england ’s heir]3223-england ’s heir ; and , mad or sane , still shall [he]3220-my son reign ! And hear [ye]565-the company further , and proclaim it : whoso speaketh of this [his]3220-my son distemper worketh against the peace and order of [these realms]3224-these realms , and shall to the gallows ! . . . Give [me]294-the king to drink -- [I]294-the king burn : this sorrow sappeth [my]294-the king strength . . . . There , take away the cup . . . . Support [me]294-the king . There , that is well . Mad , is [he]3220-my son ? Were [he]3220-my son a thousand times mad , yet is [he]3220-my son [Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3225-prince of wales , and [I]294-the king [the King]294-the king will confirm it . This very morrow shall [he]3220-my son be installed in [his]3220-my son princely dignity in due and ancient form . Take instant order for it , [[my]294-the king lord]3168-my lord [Hertford]107-hertford . ”[294-the king] [One of [the nobles]567-the nobles]566-one of the nobles knelt at the royal couch , and said-- “ [[The King]294-the king ’s majesty]3229-the king ’s majesty knoweth that [the Hereditary Great Marshal of]3230-the hereditary great marshal of [England]2-england lieth attainted in [the Tower]19-the tower . It were not meet that one attainted-- ”[566-one of the nobles] “ Peace ! Insult not [mine]566-one of the nobles ears with [his]3220-my son hated name . Is [this man]546-this man to live for ever ? Am [I]294-the king to be baulked of [my]294-the king will ? Is [the prince]236-the prince to tarry uninstalled , because , forsooth , [the realm]3233-the realm lacketh [an Earl Marshal]3234-an earl marshal free of treasonable taint to invest [him]3220-my son with [his]3220-my son honours ? No , by the splendour of [God]87-god ! Warn [[my]294-the king Parliament]3235-my parliament to bring [me]294-the king [Norfolk]22-norfolk ’s doom before the sun rise again , else shall [they]3235-my parliament answer for it grievously ! ”[294-the king] { 1 } [Lord Hertford]107-hertford said-- “ [The King]294-the king ’s will is law ; ”[107-hertford] and , rising , returned to [his]107-hertford former place . Gradually the wrath faded out of [the old King]568-the old king ’s face , and [he]107-hertford said-- “ Kiss [me]107-hertford , [[my]107-hertford prince]3184-my prince . There . . . what fearest [thou]3184-my prince ? Am [I]107-hertford not [[thy]3184-my prince loving father]3238-thy loving father ? ”[107-hertford] “ [Thou]3184-my prince art good to [me]107-hertford that am unworthy , [O mighty and gracious lord]3239-o mighty and gracious lord : that in truth [I]107-hertford know . But -- but -- it grieveth [me]107-hertford to think of [him]568-the old king that is to die , and-- ”[107-hertford] “ Ah , ’ tis like [thee]3184-my prince , ’ tis like [thee]3184-my prince ! [I]107-hertford know [thy]3184-my prince heart is still the same , even though [thy]3184-my prince mind hath suffered hurt , for [thou]3184-my prince wert ever of [a gentle spirit]3240-a gentle spirit . But [this duke]3241-this duke standeth between [thee]3184-my prince and thine honours : [I]107-hertford will have another in [his]3241-this duke stead that shall bring no taint to [his]3241-this duke great office . Comfort [thee]3184-my prince , [[my]107-hertford prince]3184-my prince : trouble not [thy]3184-my prince poor head with this matter . ”[107-hertford] “ But is it not [I]107-hertford that speed [him]568-the old king hence , [[my]107-hertford liege]3243-my liege ? How long might [he]568-the old king not live , but for [me]107-hertford ? ”[107-hertford] “ Take no thought of [him]568-the old king , [[my]107-hertford prince]3184-my prince : [he]568-the old king is not worthy . Kiss [me]107-hertford once again , and go to [thy]3184-my prince trifles and amusements ; for [my]107-hertford malady distresseth [me]107-hertford . [I]107-hertford am aweary , and would rest . Go with [thine uncle Hertford]3245-thine uncle hertford and [[thy]3184-my prince people]3246-thy people , and come again when [my]107-hertford body is refreshed . ”[107-hertford] [Tom]90-tom , heavy - hearted , was conducted from the presence , for this last sentence was a death - blow to the hope [he]90-tom had cherished that now [he]90-tom would be set free . Once more [he]90-tom heard the buzz of low voices exclaiming , “ [The prince]236-the prince , [the prince]236-the prince comes ! ”[90-tom] [His]90-tom spirits sank lower and lower as [he]90-tom moved between the glittering files of [bowing courtiers]569-bowing courtiers ; for [he]90-tom recognised that [he]90-tom was indeed [a captive]570-a captive now , and might remain for ever shut up in this gilded cage , [a forlorn and friendless prince]571-a forlorn and friendless prince , except [God]87-god in [his]87-god mercy take pity on [him]90-tom and set [him]90-tom free . And , turn where [he]90-tom would , [he]90-tom seemed to see floating in the air the severed head and the remembered face of [the great Duke of [Norfolk]22-norfolk]572-the great duke of norfolk , the eyes fixed on [him]90-tom reproachfully . [His]90-tom old dreams had been so pleasant ; but this reality was so dreary ! CHAPTER VI . [Tom]90-tom receives instructions . [Tom]90-tom was conducted to [the principal apartment of [a noble suite]574-a noble suite]573-the principal apartment of a noble suite , and made to sit down -- a thing which [he]90-tom was loth to do , since there were [elderly men]575-elderly men and [men of high degree]576-men of high degree about [him]90-tom . [He]90-tom begged [them]577-them to be seated also , but [they]577-them only bowed [their]577-them thanks or murmured [them]577-them , and remained standing . [He]90-tom would have insisted , but [[his]90-tom ‘ uncle]578-his ‘ uncle ’ [the Earl of Hertford]108-the earl of hertford whispered in [his]90-tom ear-- “ [Prithee]100-prithee , insist not , [[my]108-the earl of hertford lord]3168-my lord ; it is not meet that [they]577-them sit in [thy]3168-my lord presence . ”[108-the earl of hertford] [The Lord St. John]109-lord st. john was announced , and after making obeisance to [Tom]90-tom , [he]109-lord st. john said-- “ [I]109-lord st. john come upon [the King]294-the king ’s errand , concerning a matter which requireth privacy . Will it please [[your]90-tom royal highness]3251-your royal highness to dismiss all that attend [you]90-tom here , save [[my]109-lord st. john lord]3168-my lord [the Earl of Hertford]3253-the earl of hertford ? ”[109-lord st. john] Observing that [Tom]90-tom did not seem to know how to proceed , [Hertford]108-the earl of hertford whispered [him]90-tom to make a sign with [his]90-tom hand , and not trouble [himself]90-tom to speak unless [he]90-tom chose . When [the waiting gentlemen]579-the waiting gentlemen had retired , [Lord St. John]109-lord st. john said-- “ [[His]294-the king majesty]3254-his majesty commandeth , that for due and weighty reasons of state , [the prince]236-the prince ’s grace shall hide [his]294-the king infirmity in all ways that be within [his]294-the king power , till it be passed and [he]294-the king be as [he]294-the king was before . To wit , that [he]294-the king shall deny to [none]3179-none that [he]294-the king is [the true prince]3154-the true prince , and heir to [England]2-england ’s greatness ; that [he]294-the king shall uphold [his]294-the king princely dignity , and shall receive , without word or sign of protest , that reverence and observance which unto it do appertain of right and ancient usage ; that [he]294-the king shall cease to speak to any of that lowly birth and life [his]294-the king malady hath conjured out of the unwholesome imaginings of o’er - wrought fancy ; that [he]294-the king shall strive with diligence to bring unto [his]294-the king memory again those faces which [he]294-the king was wo nt to know -- and where [he]294-the king faileth [he]294-the king shall hold [his]294-the king peace , neither betraying by semblance of surprise or other sign that [he]294-the king hath forgot ; that upon occasions of state , whensoever any matter shall perplex [him]294-the king as to the thing [he]294-the king should do or the utterance [he]294-the king should make , [he]294-the king shall show nought of unrest to [the curious that look on]3258-the curious that look on , but take advice in that matter of [the Lord Hertford]3259-the lord hertford , or [[my]109-lord st. john humble self]3260-my humble self , which are commanded of [the King to be upon this service and close at call]3261-the king to be upon this service and close at call , till this commandment be dissolved . Thus saith [[the King]294-the king ’s majesty , who sendeth greeting to [[your]90-tom royal highness]3251-your royal highness]3263-the king ’s majesty , who sendeth greeting to your royal highness , and prayeth that [God]87-god will of [His]87-god mercy quickly heal [you]90-tom and have [you]90-tom now and ever in [His]87-god holy keeping . ”[109-lord st. john] [The Lord St. John]109-lord st. john made reverence and stood aside . [Tom]90-tom replied resignedly-- “ [The King]294-the king hath said it . [None]3179-none may palter with [the King]294-the king ’s command , or fit it to [his]294-the king ease , where it doth chafe , with deft evasions . [The King]294-the king shall be obeyed . ”[107-hertford] [Lord Hertford]107-hertford said-- “ Touching [[the King]294-the king ’s majesty]3229-the king ’s majesty ’s ordainment concerning books and such like serious matters , it may peradventure please [[your]90-tom highness]3271-your highness to ease [your]90-tom time with lightsome entertainment , lest [you]90-tom go wearied to the banquet and suffer harm thereby . ”[90-tom] [Tom]90-tom ’s face showed inquiring surprise ; and a blush followed when [he]90-tom saw [Lord St. John]109-lord st. john ’s eyes bent sorrowfully upon [him]90-tom . [[His]90-tom lordship]580-his lordship said-- “ [Thy]90-tom memory still wrongeth [thee]90-tom , and [thou]90-tom hast shown surprise -- but suffer it not to trouble [thee]90-tom , for ’ tis a matter that will not bide , but depart with [thy]90-tom mending malady . [[My]580-his lordship Lord of [Hertford]107-hertford]3272-my lord of hertford speaketh of [the city]370-the city ’s banquet which [[the King]294-the king ’s majesty]3229-the king ’s majesty did promise , some two months flown , [[your]90-tom highness]3271-your highness should attend . [Thou]90-tom recallest it now ? ”[580-his lordship] “ It grieves [me]90-tom to confess it had indeed escaped [me]90-tom , ”[90-tom] said [Tom]90-tom , in a hesitating voice ; and blushed again . At this moment [the Lady Elizabeth]91-the lady elizabeth and [the Lady Jane Grey]97-the lady jane grey were announced . [The two lords]581-the two lords exchanged significant glances , and [Hertford]107-hertford stepped quickly toward the door . As [the young girls]582-the young girls passed [him]90-tom , [he]90-tom said in a low voice-- “ [I]90-tom pray [ye]582-the young girls , [ladies]254-ladies , seem not to observe [his]90-tom humours , nor show surprise when [his]90-tom memory doth lapse -- it will grieve [you]582-the young girls to note how it doth stick at every trifle . ”[90-tom] Meantime [Lord St. John]109-lord st. john was saying in [Tom]90-tom ’s ear-- “ Please [you]90-tom , [sir]3053-sir , keep diligently in mind [[his]90-tom majesty]3254-his majesty ’s desire . Remember all [thou]3280-thou canst--_seem _ to remember all else . Let [them]582-the young girls not perceive that [thou]3280-thou art much changed from [thy]3280-thou wo nt , for [thou]3280-thou knowest how tenderly [[thy]3280-thou old play - fellows]3281-thy old play - fellows bear [thee]3280-thou in [their]3281-thy old play - fellows hearts and how ’ twould grieve [them]3281-thy old play - fellows . Art willing , [sir]3053-sir , that [I]90-tom remain?--and [thine uncle]3283-thine uncle ? ”[90-tom] [Tom]90-tom signified assent with a gesture and a murmured word , for [he]90-tom was already learning , and in [his]90-tom simple heart was resolved to acquit [himself]90-tom as best [he]90-tom might , according to [the King]294-the king ’s command . In spite of every precaution , the conversation among [the young people]584-the young people became a little embarrassing at times .
