Kill [him]3443-another prince in disguise ! ”[458-the mob] and [the mob]458-the mob closed in on [the warrior]952-the warrior , who backed [himself]952-the warrior against a wall and began to lay about [him]952-the warrior with [his]952-the warrior long weapon like [a madman]953-a madman . [[His]952-the warrior victims]954-his victims sprawled this way and that , but the mob - tide poured over [their]954-his victims prostrate forms and dashed itself against [the champion]955-the champion with undiminished fury . [His]952-the warrior moments seemed numbered , [his]952-the warrior destruction certain , when suddenly a trumpet - blast sounded , a voice shouted , “ Way for [the King ’s messenger]3447-the king ’s messenger ! ”[956-horsemen] and a troop of [horsemen]956-horsemen came charging down upon [the mob , who fled out of harm ’s reach as fast as [their]957-the mob , who fled out of harm ’s reach as fast as their legs could carry them legs could carry [them]957-the mob , who fled out of harm ’s reach as fast as their legs could carry them]957-the mob , who fled out of harm ’s reach as fast as their legs could carry them . [The bold stranger]958-the bold stranger caught up [the Prince]236-the prince in [his]958-the bold stranger arms , and was soon far away from danger and [the multitude]960-the multitude . Return [we]961-we within [the Guildhall]881-the guildhall . Suddenly , high above the jubilant roar and thunder of [the revel]963-the revel , broke the clear peal of a bugle - note . There was instant silence -- a deep hush ; then a single voice rose -- that of [the messenger from [the palace]425-the palace]964-the messenger from the palace -- and began to pipe forth a proclamation , [the whole multitude]966-the whole multitude standing listening . The closing words , solemnly pronounced , were-- “ [The King]294-the king is dead ! ”[967-the great assemblage] [The great assemblage]967-the great assemblage bent [their]967-the great assemblage heads upon [their]967-the great assemblage breasts with one accord ; remained so , in profound silence , a few moments ; then [all]654-all sank upon [their]654-all knees in a body , stretched out [their]654-all hands toward [Tom]90-tom , and a mighty shout burst forth that seemed to shake [the building--]969-the building-- “ Long live [the King]294-the king ! ”[90-tom] [Poor Tom]90-tom ’s dazed eyes wandered abroad over this stupefying spectacle , and finally rested dreamily upon [the kneeling princesses beside [him]90-tom]970-the kneeling princesses beside him , a moment , then upon [the Earl of Hertford]108-the earl of hertford . A sudden purpose dawned in [his]90-tom face . [He]90-tom said , in a low tone , at [Lord Hertford]107-hertford ’s ear-- “ Answer [me]90-tom truly , on [thy]107-hertford faith and honour ! Uttered [I]90-tom here a command , the which [none but a king]3450-none but a king might hold privilege and prerogative to utter , would such commandment be obeyed , and [none]3179-none rise up to say [me]90-tom nay ? ”[90-tom] “ None , [[my]90-tom liege]3243-my liege , in all [these realms]3224-these realms . In [[thy]107-hertford person]3454-thy person bides the majesty of [England]2-england . [Thou]107-hertford art [the king]294-the king -- [thy]107-hertford word is law . ”[90-tom] [Tom]90-tom responded , in a strong , earnest voice , and with great animation-- “ Then shall [the king]294-the king ’s law be law of mercy , from this day , and never more be law of blood ! Up from [thy]107-hertford knees and away ! To [the Tower]3064-the tower , and say [the King]294-the king decrees [the Duke of [Norfolk]22-norfolk]3358-the duke of norfolk shall not die ! ”[90-tom] The words were caught up and carried eagerly from lip to lip far and wide over [the hall]914-the hall , and as [Hertford]107-hertford hurried from the presence , another prodigious shout burst forth-- “ The reign of blood is ended ! Long live [Edward]108-the earl of hertford , [King of [England]2-england]3460-king of england ! ”[90-tom] CHAPTER XII . [The Prince]236-the prince and [[his]236-the prince Deliverer]973-his deliverer . As soon as [Miles Hendon]128-hendon and [the little prince]430-the little prince were clear of [the mob]458-the mob , [they]976-they struck down through [back lanes]977-back lanes and [alleys]978-alleys toward [the river]3104-the river . [Their]976-they way was unobstructed until [they]976-they approached [London Bridge]4-london bridge ; then [they]976-they ploughed into [the multitude]960-the multitude again , [Hendon]128-hendon keeping a fast grip upon [the Prince’s]981-the prince’s -- no , [the King’s]130-the king’s -- wrist . The tremendous news was already abroad , and [the boy]520-the boy learned it from a thousand voices at once--“The [King]90-tom is dead ! ”[960-the multitude] The tidings struck a chill to the heart of [the poor little waif]983-the poor little waif , and sent a shudder through [his]983-the poor little waif frame . [He]983-the poor little waif realised the greatness of [his]983-the poor little waif loss , and was filled with a bitter grief ; for [the grim tyrant who had been such a terror to [others]3324-others]984-the grim tyrant who had been such a terror to others had always been gentle with [him]983-the poor little waif . The tears sprang to [his]983-the poor little waif eyes and blurred all objects . For an instant [he]983-the poor little waif felt [himself]983-the poor little waif the most forlorn , outcast , and forsaken of [God]87-god ’s creatures -- then another cry shook the night with its far - reaching thunders : “ Long live [King Edward the Sixth]87-god ! ”[87-god] and this made [his]983-the poor little waif eyes kindle , and thrilled [him]983-the poor little waif with pride to [his]983-the poor little waif fingers ’ ends . “ Ah , ”[983-the poor little waif] [he]983-the poor little waif thought , “ how grand and strange it seems--_I am [King]87-god _ ! ”[983-the poor little waif] [[Our]986-our friends]987-our friends threaded [their]987-our friends way slowly through the throngs upon [the bridge]3424-the bridge . [This structure , which had stood for six hundred years]989-this structure , which had stood for six hundred years , and had been a noisy and populous thoroughfare all that time , was a curious affair , for a closely packed rank of [stores and shops]990-stores and shops , with [family quarters]991-family quarters overhead , stretched along both sides of [it]989-this structure , which had stood for six hundred years , from [one bank of [the river]3104-the river]992-one bank of the river to the other . [The Bridge]39-the bridge was [a sort of town to itself]994-a sort of town to itself ; [it]39-the bridge had [[its]39-the bridge inn]995-its inn , [[its]39-the bridge beer - houses]996-its beer - houses , [[its]39-the bridge bakeries]997-its bakeries , [its]39-the bridge haberdasheries , [[its]39-the bridge food markets]998-its food markets , [[its]39-the bridge manufacturing industries]999-its manufacturing industries , and even [[its]39-the bridge church]1000-its church . [It]39-the bridge looked upon [the two neighbours which [it]39-the bridge linked together]1001-the two neighbours which it linked together -- [London]1-london and [Southwark]27-southwark -- as being well enough as [suburbs]1002-suburbs , but not otherwise particularly important . [It]39-the bridge was [a close corporation]1003-a close corporation , so to speak ; [it]39-the bridge was [a narrow town]1004-a narrow town , of [a single street a fifth of a mile]1005-a single street a fifth of a mile long , [its]39-the bridge population was but [a village]1006-a village population and [everybody in]1007-everybody in [it]39-the bridge knew all [[his]1007-everybody in fellow - [townsmen]1009-townsmen]1008-his fellow - townsmen intimately , and had known [[their]1009-townsmen fathers]1010-their fathers and [mothers]1011-mothers before [them]1009-townsmen -- and all [their]1009-townsmen little family affairs into the bargain . [It]39-the bridge had [[its]39-the bridge aristocracy]1012-its aristocracy , of course -- [[its]39-the bridge fine old families of [butchers]1014-butchers]1013-its fine old families of butchers , and [bakers]1015-bakers , and what - not , who had occupied [the same old premises]1016-the same old premises for five or six hundred years , and knew the great history of [the Bridge]3424-the bridge from beginning to end , and all [its]3424-the bridge strange legends ; and who always talked bridgy talk , and thought bridgy thoughts , and lied in a long , level , direct , substantial bridgy way . It was just the sort of population to be narrow and ignorant and self - conceited . [Children]1018-children were born on [the Bridge]39-the bridge , were reared [there]3216-there , grew to old age , and finally died without ever having set a foot upon [any part of [the world]1021-the world]1020-any part of the world but [London Bridge]4-london bridge alone . [Such people]1022-such people would naturally imagine that the mighty and interminable procession which moved through [[its]39-the bridge street]1023-its street night and day , with its confused roar of shouts and cries , its neighings and bellowing and bleatings and its muffled thunder - tramp , was the one great thing in [this world]1024-this world , and [themselves]1022-such people somehow [the proprietors of [it]39-the bridge]1025-the proprietors of it . And so [they]1022-such people were , in effect -- at least [they]1022-such people could exhibit it from [their]1022-such people windows , and did -- for a consideration -- whenever [a returning king]1026-a returning king or [hero]1027-hero gave it a fleeting splendour , for there was no place like it for affording a long , straight , uninterrupted view of marching columns . [Men born and reared upon the Bridge]1028-men born and reared upon the bridge found life unendurably dull and inane elsewhere . History tells of [one of these who left [the Bridge]39-the bridge at the age of seventy - one and retired to [the country]1030-the country]1029-one of these who left the bridge at the age of seventy - one and retired to the country . But [he]1029-one of these who left the bridge at the age of seventy - one and retired to the country could only fret and toss in [his]1029-one of these who left the bridge at the age of seventy - one and retired to the country bed ; [he]1029-one of these who left the bridge at the age of seventy - one and retired to the country could not go to sleep , the deep stillness was so painful , so awful , so oppressive . When [he]1029-one of these who left the bridge at the age of seventy - one and retired to the country was worn out with it , at last , [he]1029-one of these who left the bridge at the age of seventy - one and retired to the country fled back to [[his]1029-one of these who left the bridge at the age of seventy - one and retired to the country old home]1031-his old home , [a lean and haggard spectre]1032-a lean and haggard spectre , and fell peacefully to rest and pleasant dreams under the lulling music of the lashing waters and the boom and crash and thunder of [London Bridge]4-london bridge . In the times of which [we]1033-we are writing , [the Bridge]3424-the bridge furnished ‘ object lessons ’ in English history for [[its]3424-the bridge children]1035-its children -- namely , the livid and decaying heads of [renowned men impaled upon iron spikes]1036-renowned men impaled upon iron spikes atop of [its]3424-the bridge gateways . But [we]1033-we digress . [[Hendon]128-hendon ’s lodgings]1037-hendon ’s lodgings were in [the little inn on [the Bridge]3424-the bridge]1038-the little inn on the bridge . As [he]128-hendon neared the door with [[his]128-hendon small friend]1040-his small friend , a rough voice said-- “ So , [thou’rt]3461-thou’lt come at last ! [Thou’lt]3461-thou’lt not escape again , [I]93-john canty warrant [thee]520-the boy ; and if pounding [thy]520-the boy bones to a pudding can teach [thee]520-the boy somewhat , [thou’lt]3461-thou’lt not keep [us]1033-we waiting another time , mayhap,”--and[93-john canty] [John Canty]93-john canty put out [his]93-john canty hand to seize [the boy]520-the boy . [Miles Hendon]128-hendon stepped in the way and said-- “ Not too fast , [friend]3426-friend . [Thou]520-the boy art needlessly rough , methinks . What is [the lad]496-the lad to [thee]520-the boy ? ”[128-hendon] “ If it be any business of thine to make and meddle in [others]3324-others ’ affairs , [he]496-the lad is [[my]1042-the little king son]3220-my son . ”[1042-the little king] “ ‘ Tis a lie ! ”[1042-the little king] cried [the little King]1042-the little king , hotly . “ Boldly said , and [I]1042-the little king believe [thee]520-the boy , whether [thy]520-the boy small headpiece be sound or cracked , [[my]1042-the little king boy]3408-my boy . But whether [this scurvy ruffian]3467-this scurvy ruffian be [[thy]520-the boy father]3066-thy father or no , ’ tis [all one]3437-all one , [he]3467-this scurvy ruffian shall not have [thee]520-the boy to beat [thee]520-the boy and abuse , according to [his]3467-this scurvy ruffian threat , so [thou]520-the boy prefer to bide with [me]1042-the little king . ”[1042-the little king] “ [I]1042-the little king do , [I]1042-the little king do -- [I]1042-the little king know [him]3467-this scurvy ruffian not , [I]1042-the little king loathe [him]3467-this scurvy ruffian , and will die before [I]1042-the little king will go with [him]3467-this scurvy ruffian . ”[1042-the little king] “ Then ’ tis settled , and there is nought more to say . ”[1042-the little king] “ [We]3470-we will see , as to that ! ”[93-john canty] exclaimed [John Canty]93-john canty , striding past [Hendon]128-hendon to get at [the boy]520-the boy ; “ by force shall [he--]3471-he-- ”[1042-the little king] “ If [thou]520-the boy do but touch [him]520-the boy , [thou]520-the boy animated offal , [I]128-hendon will spit [thee]520-the boy like a goose ! ”[128-hendon] said [Hendon]128-hendon , barring the way and laying [his]128-hendon hand upon [his]128-hendon sword hilt . [Canty]93-john canty drew back . “ Now mark [ye]520-the boy , ”[128-hendon] continued [Hendon]128-hendon , “ [I]128-hendon took [this lad]832-this lad under [my]128-hendon protection when [a mob of such as [thou]520-the boy would have mishandled [him]520-the boy]3473-a mob of such as thou would have mishandled him , mayhap killed [him]520-the boy ; dost imagine [I]128-hendon will desert [him]520-the boy now to a worser fate?--for whether [thou]520-the boy art [[his]520-the boy father]306-his father or no -- and sooth to say , [I]128-hendon think it is a lie -- a decent swift death were better for [such a lad]3475-such a lad than life in such brute hands as thine . So go [thy]520-the boy ways , and set quick about it , for [I]128-hendon like not much bandying of words , being not over - patient in [my]128-hendon nature . ”[128-hendon] [John Canty]93-john canty moved off , muttering threats and curses , and was swallowed from sight in [the crowd]416-the crowd . [Hendon]128-hendon ascended [three flights of stairs]1045-three flights of stairs to [[his]128-hendon room]1046-his room , with [his]128-hendon charge , after ordering a meal to be sent thither . [It]1046-his room was [a poor apartment]1047-a poor apartment , with a shabby bed and some odds and ends of old furniture in [it]1046-his room , and was vaguely lighted by a couple of sickly candles . [The little King]1042-the little king dragged [himself]1042-the little king to the bed and lay down upon [it]1049-it , almost exhausted with hunger and fatigue . [He]1042-the little king had been on [his]1042-the little king feet a good part of a day and a night ( for it was now two or three o’clock in the morning ) , and had eaten nothing meantime . [He]1042-the little king murmured drowsily-- “ Prithee call [me]1042-the little king when the table is spread , ”[1042-the little king] and sank into a deep sleep immediately . A smile twinkled in [Hendon]128-hendon ’s eye , and [he]128-hendon said to [himself--]128-hendon “ By the mass , [the little beggar]3476-the little beggar takes to [one ’s quarters]3477-one ’s quarters and usurps [[one]3093-one ’s bed]3479-one ’s bed with as natural and easy a grace as if [he]1042-the little king owned them -- with never a by - [your]3480-your - leave or so - please - it - [you]3480-your , or anything of the sort . In [his]1042-the little king diseased ravings [he]1042-the little king called [himself]1042-the little king [the Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3050-the prince of wales , and bravely doth [he]1042-the little king keep up the character . Poor little friendless rat , doubtless [his]1042-the little king mind has been disordered with ill - usage . Well , [I]1050-i will be [[his]1042-the little king friend]3482-his friend ; [I]1050-i have saved [him]1042-the little king , and it draweth [me]1050-i strongly to [him]1042-the little king ; already [I]1050-i love [the bold - tongued little rascal]3483-the bold - tongued little rascal . How soldier - like [he]1042-the little king faced [the smutty rabble]3484-the smutty rabble and flung back [his]1042-the little king high defiance ! And what a comely , sweet and gentle face [he]1042-the little king hath , now that sleep hath conjured away its troubles and its griefs . [I]1050-i will teach [him]1042-the little king ; [I]1050-i will cure [his]1042-the little king malady ; yea , [I]1050-i will be [[his]1042-the little king elder brother]3485-his elder brother , and care for [him]1042-the little king and watch over [him]1042-the little king ; and whoso would shame [him]1042-the little king or do [him]1042-the little king hurt may order [his]1042-the little king shroud , for though [I]1050-i be burnt for it [he]1042-the little king shall need it ! ”[1050-i] [He]1050-i bent over [the boy]520-the boy and contemplated [him]520-the boy with kind and pitying interest , tapping the young cheek tenderly and smoothing back the tangled curls with [his]1050-i great brown hand . A slight shiver passed over [the boy]520-the boy ’s form . [Hendon]128-hendon muttered-- “ See , now , how like [a man]3486-a man it was to let [him]1042-the little king lie here uncovered and fill [his]1042-the little king body with deadly rheums . Now what shall [I]128-hendon do ? ’ twill wake [him]1042-the little king to take [him]1042-the little king up and put [him]1042-the little king within the bed , and [he]1042-the little king sorely needeth sleep . ”[128-hendon] [He]128-hendon looked about for extra covering , but finding none , doffed [his]128-hendon doublet and wrapped [the lad]496-the lad in it , saying , “ [I]128-hendon am used to nipping air and scant apparel , ’ tis little [I]128-hendon shall mind the cold!”--then[128-hendon] walked up and down [the room]507-the room , to keep [his]128-hendon blood in motion , soliloquising as before . “ [His]1042-the little king injured mind persuades [him]1042-the little king [he]1042-the little king is [Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3225-prince of wales ; ’ twill be odd to have [a Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3488-a prince of wales still with [us]3489-us , now that [he]1042-the little king that _ was _ [the prince]236-the prince is [prince]3334-prince no more , but [king]3155-king -- for this poor mind is set upon the one fantasy , and will not reason out that now it should cast by [the prince]236-the prince and call itself [the king]294-the king . . . If [[my]1055-a servant father]3049-my father liveth still , after these seven years that [I]1055-a servant have heard nought from [home]296-home in [[my]1055-a servant foreign dungeon]3497-my foreign dungeon , [he]3049-my father will welcome [the poor lad]3498-the poor lad and give [him]3498-the poor lad generous shelter for [my]1055-a servant sake ; so will [[my]1055-a servant good elder brother]3499-my good elder brother , [Arthur]131-arthur ; [[my]1055-a servant other brother]3500-my other brother , [Hugh]132-hugh -- but [I]1055-a servant will crack [his]3049-my father crown an _ [he]3049-my father _ interfere , the fox - hearted , ill - conditioned animal ! Yes , [thither]3501-thither will [we]3502-we fare -- and straightway , too . ”[1055-a servant] [A servant]1055-a servant entered with a smoking meal , disposed it upon a small deal table , placed the chairs , and took [his]1055-a servant departure , leaving [such cheap lodgers as these]1056-such cheap lodgers as these to wait upon [themselves]1056-such cheap lodgers as these . The door slammed after [him]1055-a servant , and the noise woke [the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture , and shot a glad glance about [him]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture ; then a grieved look came into [his]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture face and [he]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture murmured to [himself]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture , with a deep sigh , “ [Alack]106-alack , it was but a dream , woe is [me]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture ! ”[1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture] Next [he]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture noticed [Miles Hendon]128-hendon ’s doublet -- glanced from that to [Hendon]128-hendon , comprehended the sacrifice that had been made for [him]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture , and said , gently-- “ [Thou]3503-thou art good to [me]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture , yes , [thou]3503-thou art very good to [me]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture . Take it and put it on -- [I]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture shall not need it more . ”[1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture] Then [he]1057-the boy , who sprang to a sitting posture got up and walked to the washstand in the corner and stood there , waiting . [Hendon]128-hendon said in a cheery voice-- “ [We]3504-we ’ll have a right hearty sup and bite , now , for everything is savoury and smoking hot , and that and [thy]3503-thou nap together will make [thee]3503-thou [a little man]3505-a little man again , never fear ! ”[128-hendon] [The boy]520-the boy made no answer , but bent a steady look , that was filled with grave surprise , and also somewhat touched with impatience , upon [the tall knight of the sword]1059-the tall knight of the sword . [Hendon]128-hendon was puzzled , and said-- “ What ’s amiss ? ”[128-hendon] “ Good sir , [I]128-hendon would wash [me]128-hendon . ”[128-hendon] “ Oh , is that all ? Ask no permission of [Miles Hendon]128-hendon for aught [thou]3503-thou cravest . Make [thyself]3503-thou perfectly free here , and welcome , with all that are [his]128-hendon belongings . ”[128-hendon] Still [the boy]520-the boy stood , and moved not ; more , [he]520-the boy tapped the floor once or twice with [his]520-the boy small impatient foot . [Hendon]128-hendon was wholly perplexed . Said he-- “ Bless [us]3506-us , what is it ? ”[520-the boy] “ [Prithee]100-prithee pour the water , and make not so many words ! ”[128-hendon] [Hendon]128-hendon , suppressing a horse - laugh , and saying to [himself]128-hendon , “ By [all the saints]3507-all the saints , but this is admirable ! ”[128-hendon] stepped briskly forward and did [the small insolent]1061-the small insolent ’s bidding ; then stood by , in a sort of stupefaction , until the command , “ Come -- the towel ! ”[128-hendon] woke [him]128-hendon sharply up . [He]128-hendon took up a towel , from under [the boy]520-the boy ’s nose , and handed it to [him]520-the boy without comment . [He]128-hendon now proceeded to comfort [his]128-hendon own face with a wash , and while [he]128-hendon was at it [[his]128-hendon adopted child]1063-his adopted child seated [himself]1063-his adopted child at the table and prepared to fall to . [Hendon]128-hendon despatched [his]128-hendon ablutions with alacrity , then drew back the other chair and was about to place [himself]128-hendon at table , when [the boy]520-the boy said , indignantly-- “ Forbear ! Wouldst sit in the presence of [the King]294-the king ? ”[520-the boy] This blow staggered [Hendon]128-hendon to [his]128-hendon foundations . [He]128-hendon muttered to [himself]128-hendon , “ [Lo]133-lo , [the poor thing]3509-the poor thing ’s madness is up with the time ! It hath changed with the great change that is come to [the realm]3233-the realm , and now in fancy is [he]294-the king _ king _ ! [Good lack]3511-good lack , [I]128-hendon must humour [the conceit]3512-the conceit , too -- there is no other way -- faith , [he]294-the king would order [me]128-hendon to [the Tower]19-the tower , else ! ”[128-hendon] And pleased with this jest , [he]128-hendon removed the chair from the table , took [his]128-hendon stand behind [the King]294-the king , and proceeded to wait upon [him]294-the king in the courtliest way [he]128-hendon was capable of . While [the King]294-the king ate , the rigour of [his]294-the king royal dignity relaxed a little , and with [his]294-the king growing contentment came a desire to talk . [He]294-the king said--“I think [thou]294-the king callest [thyself]294-the king [Miles Hendon]128-hendon , if [I]294-the king heard [thee]128-hendon aright ? ”[294-the king] “ Yes , [Sire]3212-sire , ”[128-hendon] [Miles]128-hendon replied ; then observed to [himself]128-hendon , “ If [I]128-hendon _ must _ humour [the poor lad]3498-the poor lad ’s madness , [I]128-hendon must ‘ Sire ’ [him]3498-the poor lad , [I]128-hendon must ‘ Majesty ’ [him]3498-the poor lad , [I]128-hendon must not go by halves , [I]128-hendon must stick at nothing that belongeth to the part [I]128-hendon play , else shall [I]128-hendon play it ill and work evil to this charitable and kindly cause . ”[128-hendon] [The King]294-the king warmed [his]294-the king heart with a second glass of wine , and said--“I would know [thee]128-hendon -- tell [me]294-the king [thy]128-hendon story . [Thou]128-hendon hast a gallant way with [thee]128-hendon , and [a noble -- art nobly born]3515-a noble -- art nobly born ? ”[294-the king] “ [We]3516-we are of the tail of [the nobility]3517-the nobility , good [[your]294-the king Majesty]3215-your majesty . [[My]294-the king father]3049-my father is [a baronet]3520-a baronet -- [one of [the smaller lords by knight service]3522-the smaller lords by knight service]3521-one of the smaller lords by knight service { 2}--Sir [Richard Hendon of Hendon Hall]134-richard hendon of hendon hall , by [[Monk]135-monk ’s Holm in [Kent]40-kent]3523-monk ’s holm in kent . ”[294-the king] “ The name has escaped [my]294-the king memory . Go on -- tell [me]294-the king [thy]128-hendon story . ”[294-the king] “ ‘ Tis not much , [[your]294-the king Majesty]3215-your majesty , yet perchance it may beguile a short half - hour for want of a better . [[My]294-the king father]3049-my father , [Sir Richard]136-sir richard , is very rich , and of a most generous nature . [[My]294-the king mother]3205-my mother died whilst [I]294-the king was yet [a boy]239-a boy . [I]294-the king have [two brothers]3528-two brothers : [Arthur]131-arthur , [[my]294-the king elder]3529-my elder , with a soul like to [[his]131-arthur father]306-his father ’s ; and [Hugh]132-hugh , younger than [I]294-the king , [a mean spirit , covetous , treacherous , vicious]3531-a mean spirit , covetous , treacherous , vicious , underhanded -- a reptile . Such was [he]131-arthur from [the cradle]3532-the cradle ; such was [he]131-arthur ten years past , when [I]294-the king last saw [him]131-arthur -- [a ripe rascal]3533-a ripe rascal at nineteen , [I]294-the king being twenty then , and [Arthur]131-arthur twenty - two . There is [none other of [us]3535-us]3534-none other of us but [the Lady Edith]137-the lady edith , [[my]294-the king cousin]3074-my cousin -- [she]137-the lady edith was sixteen then -- beautiful , gentle , good , [the daughter of [an earl]3538-an earl , the last of [her]137-the lady edith race]3537-the daughter of an earl , the last of her race , [heiress of a great fortune and a lapsed title]3539-heiress of a great fortune and a lapsed title . [[My]294-the king father]3049-my father was [[her]137-the lady edith guardian]3541-her guardian . [I]294-the king loved [her]137-the lady edith and [she]137-the lady edith loved [me]294-the king ; but [she]137-the lady edith was betrothed to [Arthur]131-arthur from the cradle , and [Sir Richard]136-sir richard would not suffer the contract to be broken . [Arthur]131-arthur loved [another maid]3542-another maid , and bade [us]3543-us be of good cheer and hold fast to the hope that delay and luck together would some day give success to [our]3543-us several causes . [Hugh]132-hugh loved [the Lady Edith]137-the lady edith ’s fortune , though in truth [he]132-hugh said it was [herself]137-the lady edith [he]132-hugh loved -- but then ’ twas [his]132-hugh way , alway , to say the one thing and mean the other . But [he]132-hugh lost [his]132-hugh arts upon [the girl]3544-the girl ; [he]132-hugh could deceive [[my]294-the king father]3049-my father , but none else . [[My]294-the king father]3049-my father loved [him]132-hugh best of [us]3543-us all , and trusted and believed [him]132-hugh ; for [he]132-hugh was [the youngest child]3547-the youngest child , and [others]3324-others hated [him]132-hugh -- these qualities being in all ages sufficient to win [a parent]3549-a parent ’s dearest love ; and [he]132-hugh had a smooth persuasive tongue , with an admirable gift of lying -- and these be qualities which do mightily assist a blind affection to cozen itself . [I]294-the king was wild -- in troth [I]294-the king might go yet farther and say _ very _ wild , though ‘ twas a wildness of an innocent sort , since it hurt none but [me]294-the king , brought shame to none , nor loss , nor had in it any taint of crime or baseness , or what might not beseem [mine]294-the king honourable degree . “[294-the king] Yet did [[my]0-my brother]3303-my brother [Hugh]132-hugh turn these faults to good account -- [he]132-hugh seeing that [[our]1069-our brother]1070-our brother [Arthur]131-arthur ’s health was but indifferent , and hoping the worst might work [him]131-arthur profit were [I]0-my swept out of the path -- so -- but ’ twere a long tale , good [[my]0-my liege]3243-my liege , and little worth the telling . Briefly , then , [this brother]1072-this brother did deftly magnify [my]0-my faults and make [them]1073-them crimes ; ending [his]1072-this brother base work with finding a silken ladder in [[mine]0-my apartments]1074-mine apartments -- conveyed [thither]1075-thither by [his]1072-this brother own means -- and did convince [[my]0-my father]3049-my father by this , and suborned evidence of [servants]363-servants and other lying knaves , that [I]0-my was minded to carry off [[my]0-my [Edith]137-the lady edith]1078-my edith and marry with [her]137-the lady edith in rank defiance of [his]3049-my father will . “ Three years of banishment from [home]296-home and [England]2-england might make [a soldier]3551-a soldier and [a man of [me]0-my]3552-a man of me , [[my]0-my father]3049-my father said , and teach [me]0-my some degree of wisdom . [I]0-my fought out [my]0-my long probation in the continental wars , tasting sumptuously of hard knocks , privation , and adventure ; but in [my]0-my last battle [I]0-my was taken captive , and during the seven years that have waxed and waned since then , [a foreign dungeon]3554-a foreign dungeon hath harboured [me]0-my . Through wit and courage [I]0-my won to the free air at last , and fled hither straight ; and am but just arrived , right poor in purse and raiment , and poorer still in knowledge of what these dull seven years have wrought at [Hendon Hall]41-hendon hall , [[its]41-hendon hall people]3555-its people and belongings . So please [you]1042-the little king , [sir]3053-sir , [my]0-my meagre tale is told . ”[0-my] “ [Thou]3557-thou hast been shamefully abused ! ”[1042-the little king] said [the little King]1042-the little king , with a flashing eye . “ But [I]1042-the little king will right [thee]3557-thou -- by the cross will [I]1042-the little king ! [The King]294-the king hath said it . ”[1042-the little king] Then , fired by the story of [Miles]128-hendon ’s wrongs , [he]1042-the little king loosed [his]1042-the little king tongue and poured the history of [his]1042-the little king own recent misfortunes into the ears of [[his]1042-the little king astonished listener]1080-his astonished listener . When [he]1042-the little king had finished , [Miles]128-hendon said to [himself--]128-hendon “ [Lo]133-lo , what an imagination [he]128-hendon hath ! Verily , this is no common mind ; else , crazed or sane , it could not weave so straight and gaudy a tale as this out of the airy nothings wherewith it hath wrought this curious romaunt . [Poor ruined little head]3559-poor ruined little head , it shall not lack [friend]3426-friend or shelter whilst [I]294-the king bide with the living . [He]3559-poor ruined little head shall never leave [my]294-the king side ; [he]3559-poor ruined little head shall be [my]294-the king pet , [[my]294-the king little comrade]3561-my little comrade . And [he]3559-poor ruined little head shall be cured!--ay , made whole and sound -- then will [he]3559-poor ruined little head make [himself]3559-poor ruined little head a name -- and proud shall [I]294-the king be to say , ‘ Yes , [he]3559-poor ruined little head is [mine]294-the king -- [I]294-the king took [him]3559-poor ruined little head , [a homeless little ragamuffin]3562-a homeless little ragamuffin , but [I]294-the king saw what was in [him]3559-poor ruined little head , and [I]294-the king said [his]3559-poor ruined little head name would be heard some day -- behold [him]3559-poor ruined little head , observe [him]3559-poor ruined little head -- was [I]294-the king right ? ’ ”[294-the king] [The King]294-the king spoke -- in a thoughtful , measured voice-- “ [Thou]3563-your didst save [me]294-the king injury and shame , perchance [my]294-the king life , and so [my]294-the king crown . Such service demandeth rich reward . Name [thy]3563-your desire , and so it be within the compass of [my]294-the king royal power , it is thine . ”[294-the king] This fantastic suggestion startled [Hendon]128-hendon out of [his]128-hendon reverie . [He]128-hendon was about to thank [the King]294-the king and put the matter aside with saying [he]128-hendon had only done [his]128-hendon duty and desired no reward , but a wiser thought came into [his]128-hendon head , and [he]128-hendon asked leave to be silent a few moments and consider the gracious offer -- an idea which [the King]294-the king gravely approved , remarking that it was best to be not too hasty with a thing of such great import . [Miles]128-hendon reflected during some moments , then said to [himself]128-hendon , “ Yes , that is the thing to do -- by any other means it were impossible to get at it -- and certes , this hour ’s experience has taught [me]128-hendon ’ twould be most wearing and inconvenient to continue it as it is . Yes , [I]128-hendon will propose it ; ’ twas a happy accident that [I]128-hendon did not throw the chance away . ”[128-hendon] Then [he]128-hendon dropped upon one knee and said-- “ [My]128-hendon poor service went not beyond the limit of [a subject]3564-a subject ’s simple duty , and therefore hath no merit ; but since [[your]3563-your Majesty]3215-your majesty is pleased to hold it worthy some reward , [I]128-hendon take heart of grace to make petition to this effect . Near four hundred years ago , as [[your]3563-your grace]3566-your grace knoweth , there being ill blood betwixt [John]93-john canty , [King of [England]2-england]3460-king of england , and [the King of [France]42-france]3568-the king of france , it was decreed that [two champions]3569-two champions should fight together in the lists , and so settle the dispute by what is called the arbitrament of [God]87-god . [These two kings]3570-these two kings , and [the Spanish king]3571-the spanish king , being assembled to witness and judge the conflict , [the French champion]3572-the french champion appeared ; but so redoubtable was [he]3572-the french champion , that [[our]3573-our English knights]3574-our english knights refused to measure weapons with [him]3572-the french champion . So the matter , which was a weighty one , was like to go against [the English monarch]3575-the english monarch by default . Now in [the Tower]19-the tower lay [the Lord de Courcy]138-the lord de courcy , the mightiest arm in [England]2-england , stripped of [his]138-the lord de courcy honours and possessions , and wasting with long captivity . Appeal was made to [him]138-the lord de courcy ; [he]138-the lord de courcy gave assent , and came forth arrayed for battle ; but no sooner did [the Frenchman]3576-the frenchman glimpse [his]138-the lord de courcy huge frame and hear [his]138-the lord de courcy famous name but [he]138-the lord de courcy fled away , and [the French king]3577-the french king ’s cause was lost . [King John]139-king john restored [De Courcy]140-de courcy ’s titles and possessions , and said , ‘ Name [thy]3577-the french king wish and [thou]3577-the french king shalt have it , though it cost [me]128-hendon half [[my]128-hendon kingdom]3578-my kingdom ; ’ whereat [De Courcy]140-de courcy , kneeling , as [I]128-hendon do now , made answer , ‘ This , then , [I]128-hendon ask , [[my]128-hendon liege]3243-my liege ; that [I]128-hendon and [[my]128-hendon successors]3580-my successors may have and hold the privilege of remaining covered in the presence of [the kings of [England]2-england]3581-the kings of england , henceforth while the throne shall last . ’ The boon was granted , as [[your]3582-your Majesty]3215-your majesty knoweth ; and there hath been no time , these four hundred years , that that line has failed of [an heir]3584-an heir ; and so , even unto this day , [the head of [that ancient house]3586-that ancient house]3585-the head of that ancient house still weareth [his]3585-the head of that ancient house hat or helm before [[the King]294-the king ’s Majesty]3229-the king ’s majesty , without let or hindrance , and this [none other]3589-none other may do . { 3 } Invoking this precedent in aid of [my]128-hendon prayer , [I]128-hendon beseech [the King]294-the king to grant to [me]128-hendon but this one grace and privilege -- to [my]128-hendon more than sufficient reward -- and none other , to wit : that [I]128-hendon and [[my]128-hendon heirs]3591-my heirs , for ever , may _ sit _ in the presence of [the Majesty of [England]2-england]551-the majesty of england ! ”[128-hendon] “ Rise , [Sir Miles Hendon]128-hendon , [Knight]3593-knight , ”[294-the king] said [the King]294-the king , gravely -- giving the accolade with [Hendon]128-hendon ’s sword--“rise , and seat [thyself]3594-thyself . [Thy]294-the king petition is granted . Whilst [England]2-england remains , and the crown continues , the privilege shall not lapse . ”[294-the king] [[His]294-the king Majesty]3254-his majesty walked apart , musing , and [Hendon]128-hendon dropped into a chair at table , observing to [himself]128-hendon , “ ‘ Twas a brave thought , and hath wrought [me]128-hendon a mighty deliverance ; [my]128-hendon legs are grievously wearied . An [I]128-hendon had not thought of that , [I]128-hendon must have had to stand for weeks , till [[my]128-hendon poor lad]3595-my poor lad ’s wits are cured . ”[128-hendon] After a little , [he]128-hendon went on , “ And so [I]128-hendon am become [a knight of [the Kingdom of Dreams]3597-the kingdom of dreams and Shadows]3596-a knight of the kingdom of dreams and shadows ! A most odd and strange position , truly , for one so matter - of - fact as [I.]128-hendon [I]128-hendon will not laugh -- no , God forbid , for this thing which is so substanceless to [me]128-hendon is _ real _ to [him]3595-my poor lad . And to [me]128-hendon , also , in one way , it is not a falsity , for it reflects with truth the sweet and generous spirit that is in [him]3595-my poor lad . ”[128-hendon] After a pause : “ Ah , what if [he]3595-my poor lad should call [me]128-hendon by [my]128-hendon fine title before folk!--there’d be a merry contrast betwixt [my]128-hendon glory and [my]128-hendon raiment ! But no matter , let [him]3595-my poor lad call [me]128-hendon what [he]3595-my poor lad will , so it please [him]3595-my poor lad ; [I]128-hendon shall be content . ”[128-hendon] CHAPTER XIII . The disappearance of [the Prince]236-the prince . A heavy drowsiness presently fell upon [the two comrades]1087-the two comrades . [The King]294-the king said-- “ Remove these rags . ”--meaning[294-the king] [his]294-the king clothing . [Hendon]128-hendon disapparelled [the boy]520-the boy without dissent or remark , tucked [him]520-the boy up in bed , then glanced about [the room]507-the room , saying to [himself]128-hendon , ruefully , “ [He]3595-my poor lad hath taken [my]128-hendon bed again , as before -- marry , what shall _ [I]128-hendon _ do ? ”[128-hendon] [The little King]1042-the little king observed [his]1042-the little king perplexity , and dissipated it with a word . [He]1042-the little king said , sleepily-- “ [Thou]128-hendon wilt sleep athwart the door , and guard it . ”[1042-the little king] In a moment more [he]1042-the little king was out of [his]1042-the little king troubles , in a deep slumber . “ [Dear heart]3598-dear heart , [he]3595-my poor lad should have been born [a king]390-a king ! ”[128-hendon] muttered [Hendon]128-hendon , admiringly ; “ [he]3595-my poor lad playeth the part to a marvel . ”[128-hendon] Then [he]1042-the little king stretched [himself]1042-the little king across the door , on the floor , saying contentedly-- “ [I]1042-the little king have lodged worse for seven years ; ’ twould be but ill gratitude to [Him]3595-my poor lad above to find fault with this . ”[1042-the little king] [He]1042-the little king dropped asleep as the dawn appeared . Toward noon [he]1042-the little king rose , uncovered [his]1042-the little king unconscious ward -- a section at a time -- and took [his]1042-the little king measure with a string . [The King]294-the king awoke , just as [he]294-the king had completed [his]294-the king work , complained of the cold , and asked what [he]294-the king was doing . “ ‘ Tis done , now , [[my]128-hendon liege]3243-my liege , ”[128-hendon] said [Hendon]128-hendon ; “ [I]128-hendon have a bit of business outside , but will presently return ; sleep [thou]3595-my poor lad again -- [thou]3595-my poor lad needest it . There -- let [me]128-hendon cover [thy]3595-my poor lad head also -- [thou’lt]3595-my poor lad be warm the sooner . ”[128-hendon] [The King]294-the king was back in [dreamland]1094-dreamland before this speech was ended . [Miles]128-hendon slipped softly out , and slipped as softly in again , in the course of thirty or forty minutes , with a complete second - hand suit of [boy]1095-boy ’s clothing , of cheap material , and showing signs of wear ; but tidy , and suited to the season of the year . [He]1042-the little king seated [himself]1042-the little king , and began to overhaul [his]1042-the little king purchase , mumbling to himself-- “ A longer purse would have got a better sort , but when [one]3093-one has not the long purse one must be content with what [a short one]3602-a short one may do-- “[1042-the little king] ‘ There was [a woman in [[our]1097-our town]1098-our town , In [[our]1097-our town]1098-our town]1096-a woman in our town , in our town did dwell-- ’ “ [He]1042-the little king stirred , methinks -- [I]1042-the little king must sing in a less thunderous key ; ’ tis not good to mar [his]1042-the little king sleep , with this journey before [him]1042-the little king , and [he]1042-the little king so wearied out , [poor chap]3603-poor chap . . . This garment--‘tis well enough -- a stitch here and another one there will set it aright . This other is better , albeit a stitch or two will not come amiss in it , likewise . . . _ These _ be very good and sound , and will keep [his]1042-the little king small feet warm and dry -- an odd new thing to [him]1042-the little king , belike , since [he]1042-the little king has doubtless been used to foot it bare , winters and summers the same . . . Would thread were bread , seeing one getteth a year ’s sufficiency for a farthing , and such a brave big needle without cost , for mere love . Now shall [I]1042-the little king have [the demon]3604-the demon ’s own time to thread it ! ”[1042-the little king] And so [he]1042-the little king had . [He]1042-the little king did as [men]649-men have always done , and probably always will do , to the end of time -- held the needle still , and tried to thrust the thread through the eye , which is the opposite of [a woman]1101-a woman ’s way . Time and time again the thread missed the mark , going sometimes on one side of the needle , sometimes on the other , sometimes doubling up against the shaft ; but [he]1042-the little king was patient , having been through these experiences before , when [he]1042-the little king was soldiering . [He]1042-the little king succeeded at last , and took up the garment that had lain waiting , meantime , across [his]1042-the little king lap , and began [his]1042-the little king work . “ [The inn]3605-the inn is paid -- the breakfast that is to come , included -- and there is wherewithal left to buy a couple of donkeys and meet [our]3606-us little costs for the two or three days betwixt this and the plenty that awaits [us]3606-us at [Hendon Hall--]43-hendon hall-- “[1042-the little king] ‘ [She]1101-a woman loved [her]1101-a woman hus-- ’ “ Body o ’ [me]1042-the little king ! [I]1042-the little king have driven the needle under [my]1042-the little king nail ! . . . It matters little--‘tis not a novelty -- yet ’ tis not a convenience , neither . . . . [We]3606-us shall be merry [there]3216-there , [little one]3608-little one , never doubt it ! [Thy]3609-thy troubles will vanish there , and likewise [thy]3609-thy sad distemper-- “[1042-the little king] ‘ [She]1101-a woman loved [[her]1101-a woman husband]309-her husband dearilee , But [another man--]1103-another man-- ’ “ These be noble large stitches!”--holding[1042-the little king] the garment up and viewing it admiringly--“they have a grandeur and a majesty that do cause these small stingy ones of [the tailor - man]3610-the tailor - man to look mightily paltry and plebeian-- “[1042-the little king] ‘ [She]1101-a woman loved [[her]1101-a woman husband]309-her husband dearilee , But [another man [he]309-her husband loved]1105-another man he loved she,-- ’ “ Marry , ’ tis done -- a goodly piece of work , too , and wrought with expedition . Now will [I]309-her husband wake [him]309-her husband , apparel [him]309-her husband , pour for [him]309-her husband , feed [him]309-her husband , and then will [we]3606-us hie [us]3606-us to [the mart by [the Tabard Inn]44-the tabard inn in [Southwark]27-southwark]3611-the mart by the tabard inn in southwark and -- be pleased to rise , [my]309-her husband liege!--he answereth not -- what ho , [my]309-her husband liege!--of a truth must [I]309-her husband profane [[his]309-her husband sacred person]3612-his sacred person with a touch , sith [his]309-her husband slumber is deaf to speech . What ! ”[309-her husband] [He]309-her husband threw back the covers -- [the boy]520-the boy was gone ! [He]309-her husband stared about [him]309-her husband in speechless astonishment for a moment ; noticed for the first time that [[his]309-her husband ward]1107-his ward ’s ragged raiment was also missing ; then [he]309-her husband began to rage and storm and shout for [the innkeeper]1108-the innkeeper . At that moment [a servant]1055-a servant entered with the breakfast . “ Explain , [thou]3613-thou limb of [Satan]141-satan , or [thy]3613-thou time is come ! ”[1055-a servant] roared [the man of war]1110-the man of war , and made so savage a spring toward [the waiter]1111-the waiter that [this latter]1112-this latter could not find [his]1112-this latter tongue , for the instant , for fright and surprise . “ Where is [the boy]520-the boy ? ”[495-the man] In disjointed and trembling syllables [the man]495-the man gave the information desired . “ [You]520-the boy were hardly gone from [the place]3615-the place , [[your]520-the boy worship]3110-your worship , when [a youth]3617-a youth came running and said it was [your]520-the boy worship ’s will that [the boy]520-the boy come to [you]520-the boy straight , at the bridge - end on [the [Southwark]27-southwark side]3619-the southwark side . [I]495-the man brought [him]520-the boy hither ; and when [he]520-the boy woke [the lad]496-the lad and gave [his]520-the boy message , [the lad]496-the lad did grumble some little for being disturbed ‘ so early , ’ as [he]496-the lad called it , but straightway trussed on [his]496-the lad rags and went with [the youth]3622-the youth , only saying it had been better manners that [your]520-the boy worship came [yourself]520-the boy , not sent [a stranger]3623-a stranger -- and so-- ”[495-the man] “ And so thou’rt [a fool!--a fool]3624-a fool!--a fool and easily cozened -- hang all [thy]3624-a fool!--a fool breed ! Yet mayhap no hurt is done . Possibly no harm is meant [the boy]520-the boy . [I]1114-the servant will go fetch [him]520-the boy . Make the table ready . Stay ! the coverings of the bed were disposed as if one lay beneath them -- happened that by accident ? ”[1114-the servant] “ [I]1114-the servant know not , good [your]520-the boy worship . [I]1114-the servant saw [the youth]3622-the youth meddle with [them]3627-them -- [he]3622-the youth that came for [the boy]520-the boy . ”[1114-the servant] “ Thousand deaths ! ‘ Twas done to deceive [me--‘tis]3629-me--‘tis plain ’ twas done to gain time . Hark [ye]520-the boy ! Was [that youth]3630-that youth alone ? ”[495-the man] “ All alone , [[your]520-the boy worship]3110-your worship . ”[1114-the servant] “ Art sure ? ”[1114-the servant] “ Sure , [[your]520-the boy worship]3110-your worship . ”[495-the man] “ Collect [thy]3624-a fool!--a fool scattered wits -- bethink [thee]3624-a fool!--a fool -- take time , [man]3164-man . ”[1114-the servant] After a moment ’s thought , [the servant]1114-the servant said-- “ When [he]520-the boy came , [none]3179-none came with [him]520-the boy ; but now [I]1114-the servant remember [me]1114-the servant that as [the two]437-the two stepped into the throng of [the Bridge]3424-the bridge , [a ruffian - looking man]3637-a ruffian - looking man plunged out from some near place ; and just as [he]520-the boy was joining [them--]437-the two ”[1114-the servant] “ What _ then_?--out with it ! ”[128-hendon] thundered [the impatient Hendon]128-hendon , interrupting . “ Just then [the crowd]416-the crowd lapped [them]416-the crowd up and closed [them]416-the crowd in , and [I]128-hendon saw no more , being called by [[my]128-hendon master]3639-my master , who was in a rage because a joint that [the scrivener]3640-the scrivener had ordered was forgot , though [I]128-hendon take [all the saints]3507-all the saints to witness that to blame _ [me]128-hendon _ for that miscarriage were like holding [the unborn babe]3642-the unborn babe to judgment for sins com-- ”[128-hendon] “ Out of [my]1114-the servant sight , [idiot]3643-idiot ! [Thy]3642-the unborn babe prating drives [me]1114-the servant mad ! Hold ! [Whither]3644-whither art flying ? Canst not bide still an instant ? Went [they]416-the crowd toward [Southwark]27-southwark ? ”[1114-the servant] “ Even so , [your]128-hendon worship -- for , as [I]128-hendon said before , as to [that detestable joint]3645-that detestable joint , [the babe unborn]3646-the babe unborn is no whit more blameless than-- ”[128-hendon] “ Art here _ yet _ ! And prating still ! Vanish , lest [I]1115-the servitor throttle [thee]128-hendon ! ”[1115-the servitor] [The servitor]1115-the servitor vanished . [Hendon]128-hendon followed after [him]1115-the servitor , passed [him]1115-the servitor , and plunged down [the stairs]1116-the stairs two steps at a stride , muttering , “ ‘ Tis [that scurvy villain that claimed [he]3647-that scurvy villain that claimed he was his son was [[his]3647-that scurvy villain that claimed he was his son son]3648-his son]3647-that scurvy villain that claimed he was his son . [I]1117-i have lost [thee]128-hendon , [[my]1117-i poor little mad master]3649-my poor little mad master -- it is a bitter thought -- and [I]1117-i had come to love [thee]128-hendon so ! No ! by book and bell , _ not _ lost ! Not lost , for [I]1117-i will ransack [the land]3332-the land till [I]1117-i find [thee]128-hendon again . [Poor child]3366-poor child , [yonder]3366-poor child is [his]3649-my poor little mad master breakfast -- and [mine]1117-i , but [I]1117-i have no hunger now ; so , let the rats have it -- speed , speed ! that is the word ! ”[1117-i] As [he]1117-i wormed [his]1117-i swift way through the noisy multitudes upon [the Bridge]3424-the bridge [he]1117-i several times said to [himself]1117-i -- clinging to the thought as if it were a particularly pleasing one--“He grumbled , but [he]1117-i _ went_--he went , yes , because [he]1117-i thought [Miles Hendon]128-hendon asked it , [sweet lad]3652-sweet lad -- [he]1117-i would [ne’er]3653-ne’er have done it for another , [I]1117-i know it well . ”[1117-i] CHAPTER XIV . ‘ [Le Roi est mort]1119-le roi est mort -- vive le Roi . ’ Toward daylight of the same morning , [Tom Canty]90-tom stirred out of a heavy sleep and opened [his]90-tom eyes in the dark . [He]90-tom lay silent a few moments , trying to analyse [his]90-tom confused thoughts and impressions , and get some sort of meaning out of them ; then suddenly [he]90-tom burst out in a rapturous but guarded voice-- “ [I]90-tom see it all , [I]90-tom see it all ! Now [God]87-god be thanked , [I]90-tom am indeed awake at last ! Come , joy ! vanish , sorrow ! Ho , [Nan]92-nan ! Bet ! kick off [your]92-nan straw and hie [ye]92-nan hither to [my]90-tom side , till [I]90-tom do pour into [your]92-nan unbelieving ears the wildest madcap dream that ever the spirits of night did conjure up to astonish the soul of [man withal]3654-man withal ! . . . [Ho]3655-ho , [Nan]92-nan , [I]90-tom say ! Bet ! ”[90-tom] A dim form appeared at [his]90-tom side , and a voice said-- “ Wilt deign to deliver [thy]92-nan commands ? ”[90-tom] “ Commands ? . . . O , woe is [me]90-tom , [I]90-tom know [thy]92-nan voice ! Speak [thou]92-nan -- who am [I]90-tom ? ”[90-tom] “ [Thou]92-nan ? In sooth , yesternight wert [thou]92-nan [the Prince of [Wales]3-wales]3050-the prince of wales ; to - day art [thou]92-nan [[my]90-tom most gracious liege]3657-my most gracious liege , [Edward]87-god , [King of [England]2-england]3460-king of england . ”[90-tom] [Tom]90-tom buried [his]90-tom head among [his]90-tom pillows , murmuring plaintively-- “ Alack , it was no dream ! Go to [thy]92-nan rest , [sweet sir]3112-sweet sir -- leave [me]90-tom to [my]90-tom sorrows . ”[90-tom] [Tom]90-tom slept again , and after a time [he]90-tom had this pleasant dream . [He]90-tom thought it was summer , and [he]90-tom was playing , all alone , in the fair meadow called [[Goodman]142-goodman ’s Fields]1120-goodman ’s fields , when [a dwarf only a foot high , with long red whiskers and a humped back]1121-a dwarf only a foot high , with long red whiskers and a humped back , appeared to [him]90-tom suddenly and said , “ Dig by that stump . ”[90-tom] [He]90-tom did so , and found twelve bright new pennies -- wonderful riches ! Yet this was not the best of it ; for [the dwarf]1122-the dwarf said-- “ [I]1122-the dwarf know [thee]90-tom . [Thou]90-tom art [a good lad]3660-a good lad , and a deserving ; [thy]90-tom distresses shall end , for the day of [thy]90-tom reward is come . Dig here every seventh day , and [thou]90-tom shalt find always the same treasure , twelve bright new pennies . Tell none -- keep the secret . ”[1122-the dwarf] Then [the dwarf]1122-the dwarf vanished , and [Tom]90-tom flew to [Offal Court]18-offal court with [his]90-tom prize , saying to [himself]90-tom , “ Every night will [I]90-tom give [[my]90-tom father]3049-my father a penny ; [he]3049-my father will think [I]90-tom begged it , it will glad [his]3049-my father heart , and [I]90-tom shall no more be beaten . One penny every week [the good priest]3662-the good priest that teacheth [me]90-tom shall have ; [mother]3663-mother , [Nan]92-nan , and Bet the other four . [We]3664-we be done with hunger and rags , now , done with fears and frets and savage usage . ”[90-tom] In [his]90-tom dream [he]90-tom reached [[his]90-tom sordid home]1124-his sordid home all out of breath , but with eyes dancing with grateful enthusiasm ; cast four of [his]90-tom pennies into [[his]90-tom mother]287-his mother ’s lap and cried out-- “ [They]3665-they are for [thee!--all]3666-thee!--all of [them]3665-they , every one!--for [thee]90-tom and [Nan]92-nan and Bet -- and honestly come by , not begged nor stolen ! ”[1126-the happy and astonished mother] [The happy and astonished mother]1126-the happy and astonished mother strained [him]90-tom to [her]1126-the happy and astonished mother breast and exclaimed-- “ It waxeth late -- may it please [[your]90-tom Majesty]3215-your majesty to rise ? ”[1126-the happy and astonished mother] Ah ! that was not the answer [he]90-tom was expecting . The dream had snapped asunder -- [he]90-tom was awake . [He]90-tom opened [his]90-tom eyes -- [the richly clad First Lord of [the Bedchamber]1128-the bedchamber]1127-the richly clad first lord of the bedchamber was kneeling by [[his]1127-the richly clad first lord of the bedchamber couch]1129-his couch . The gladness of the lying dream faded away -- [the poor boy]1130-the poor boy recognised that [he]90-tom was still [a captive]570-a captive and [a king]390-a king . [The room]507-the room was filled with [courtiers]1134-courtiers clothed in purple mantles -- the mourning colour -- and with [noble servants of [the monarch]1136-the monarch]1135-noble servants of the monarch . [Tom]90-tom sat up in bed and gazed out from the heavy silken curtains upon this fine company . The weighty business of dressing began , and [one courtier]1137-one courtier after another knelt and paid [his]1137-one courtier court and offered to [the little King]1042-the little king [his]1137-one courtier condolences upon [his]1137-one courtier heavy loss , whilst the dressing proceeded . In the beginning , a shirt was taken up by [the Chief Equerry in Waiting]1139-the chief equerry in waiting , who passed [it]1140-it to [the First Lord of the Buckhounds]1141-the first lord of the buckhounds , who passed [it]1140-it to [the Second Gentleman of the Bedchamber]1142-the second gentleman of the bedchamber , who passed [it]1140-it to [the Head Ranger of [Windsor Forest]45-windsor forest]1143-the head ranger of windsor forest , who passed it to [the Third Groom of the Stole]1144-the third groom of the stole , who passed [it]1140-it to [the Chancellor Royal of [the Duchy of Lancaster]1146-the duchy of lancaster , who passed [it]1140-it to [the Master of the Wardrobe]1147-the master of the wardrobe , who passed it to [Norroy King - at - Arms]1148-norroy king - at - arms , who passed it to [the Constable of the Tower]1149-the constable of the tower , who passed [it]1140-it to [the Chief Steward of the Household]1150-the chief steward of the household , who passed [it]1140-it to [the Hereditary Grand Diaperer]1151-the hereditary grand diaperer , who passed it to [the Lord High Admiral of]1152-the lord high admiral of [England]2-england , who passed [it]1140-it to the Archbishop of [Canterbury]46-canterbury , who passed [it]1140-it to [the First Lord of the Bedchamber]1153-the first lord of the bedchamber , who took what was left of [it]1140-it and put it on [Tom]90-tom]1145-the chancellor royal of the duchy of lancaster , who passed it to the master of the wardrobe , who passed it to norroy king - at - arms , who passed it to the constable of the tower , who passed it to the chief steward of the household , who passed it to the hereditary grand diaperer , who passed it to the lord high admiral of england , who passed it to the archbishop of canterbury , who passed it to the first lord of the bedchamber , who took what was left of it and put it on tom . [Poor little wondering chap]1154-poor little wondering chap , it reminded [him]90-tom of passing buckets at a fire . Each garment in its turn had to go through this slow and solemn process ; consequently [Tom]90-tom grew very weary of the ceremony ; so weary that [he]90-tom felt an almost gushing gratefulness when [he]90-tom at last saw [his]90-tom long silken hose begin the journey down the line and knew that the end of the matter was drawing near . But [he]90-tom exulted too soon . [The First Lord of the Bedchamber]1153-the first lord of the bedchamber received the hose and was about to encase [Tom]90-tom ’s legs in them , when a sudden flush invaded [his]90-tom face and [he]90-tom hurriedly hustled the things back into the hands of [the Archbishop of [Canterbury]46-canterbury]1156-the archbishop of canterbury with an astounded look and a whispered , “ See , [[my]90-tom lord]3168-my lord ! ”[90-tom] pointing to a something connected with the hose . [The Archbishop]1157-the archbishop paled , then flushed , and passed the hose to [the Lord High Admiral]931-the lord high admiral , whispering , “ See , [[my]1159-the admiral lord]3168-my lord ! ”[1159-the admiral] [The Admiral]1159-the admiral passed the hose to [the Hereditary Grand Diaperer]1151-the hereditary grand diaperer , and had hardly breath enough in [his]90-tom body to ejaculate , “ See , [[my]1159-the admiral lord]3168-my lord ! ”[1159-the admiral] The hose drifted backward along the line , to [the Chief Steward of the Household]1150-the chief steward of the household , [the Constable of the Tower]1149-the constable of the tower , [Norroy King - at - Arms]1148-norroy king - at - arms , [the Master of the Wardrobe]1147-the master of the wardrobe , [the Chancellor Royal of [the Duchy of]1166-the duchy of [Lancaster]47-lancaster]1165-the chancellor royal of the duchy of lancaster , [the Third Groom of the Stole]1144-the third groom of the stole , [the Head Ranger of]1168-the head ranger of [Windsor Forest]45-windsor forest , [the Second Gentleman of the Bedchamber]1142-the second gentleman of the bedchamber , [the First Lord of the Buckhounds,--accompanied always with that amazed and frightened “ See]3671-the first lord of the buckhounds,--accompanied always with that amazed and frightened “ see ! see!”--till[3671-the first lord of the buckhounds,--accompanied always with that amazed and frightened “ see] [they]1170-they finally reached the hands of [the Chief Equerry in Waiting]1139-the chief equerry in waiting , who gazed a moment , with a pallid face , upon what had caused all this dismay , then hoarsely whispered , “ Body of [my]90-tom life , a tag gone from a truss - point!--to [the Tower]3064-the tower with [the Head Keeper of the King]3673-the head keeper of the king ’s Hose!”--after[90-tom] which [he]90-tom leaned upon the shoulder of [the First Lord of [the Buckhounds]143-the buckhounds]1141-the first lord of the buckhounds to regather [his]90-tom vanished strength whilst fresh hose , without any damaged strings to [them]1170-they , were brought . But all things must have an end , and so in time [Tom Canty]90-tom was in a condition to get out of bed . [The proper official]1173-the proper official poured water , [the proper official]1173-the proper official engineered the washing , [the proper official]1173-the proper official stood by with a towel , and by - and - by [Tom]90-tom got safely through the purifying stage and was ready for the services of [the Hairdresser - royal]1176-the hairdresser - royal . When [he]90-tom at length emerged from [this master]1177-this master ’s hands , [he]90-tom was a gracious figure and as pretty as [a girl]1178-a girl , in [his]90-tom mantle and trunks of purple satin , and purple - plumed cap . [He]90-tom now moved in state toward [[his]90-tom breakfast - room]1179-his breakfast - room , through the midst of the courtly assemblage ; and as [he]90-tom passed , [these]1180-these fell back , leaving [his]90-tom way free , and dropped upon [their]1180-these knees . After breakfast [he]90-tom was conducted , with regal ceremony , attended by [[his]90-tom great officers]1181-his great officers and [[his]90-tom guard of [fifty Gentlemen Pensioners bearing gilt battle - axes]1183-fifty gentlemen pensioners bearing gilt battle - axes]1182-his guard of fifty gentlemen pensioners bearing gilt battle - axes , to [the throne - room , where [he]90-tom proceeded to transact business of state]1184-the throne - room , where he proceeded to transact business of state . [[His]90-tom ‘ uncle]578-his ‘ uncle , ’ [Lord Hertford]107-hertford , took [his]90-tom stand by the throne , to assist [the royal mind]1186-the royal mind with wise counsel . [The body of illustrious men named by [the late King]1188-the late king as [[his]1188-the late king executors]1189-his executors]1187-the body of illustrious men named by the late king as his executors appeared , to ask [Tom]90-tom ’s approval of certain acts of [theirs]1187-the body of illustrious men named by the late king as his executors -- rather a form , and yet not wholly a form , since there was [no Protector]1190-no protector as yet . [The Archbishop of Canterbury]1156-the archbishop of canterbury made report of the decree of [the Council of Executors]1192-the council of executors concerning the obsequies of [[his]1156-the archbishop of canterbury late most illustrious Majesty]1193-his late most illustrious majesty , and finished by reading the signatures of [the Executors]1194-the executors , to wit : [the Archbishop of [Canterbury]46-canterbury]1156-the archbishop of canterbury ; [the Lord Chancellor of]1196-the lord chancellor of [England]2-england ; [William Lord St. John]109-lord st. john ; [John Lord Russell]144-john lord russell ; [Edward Earl of Hertford]108-the earl of hertford ; [John Viscount Lisle]145-john viscount lisle ; [Cuthbert Bishop of]1197-cuthbert bishop of [Durham--]48-durham-- [Tom]90-tom was not listening -- an earlier clause of the document was puzzling [him]90-tom . At this point [he]90-tom turned and whispered to [Lord Hertford--]1198-lord hertford-- “ What day did [he]107-hertford say the burial hath been appointed for ? ”[90-tom] “ The sixteenth of the coming month , [[my]90-tom liege]3243-my liege . ”[90-tom] “ ‘ Tis a strange folly . Will [he]107-hertford keep ? ”[90-tom] [Poor chap]3603-poor chap , [he]90-tom was still new to the customs of [royalty]436-royalty ; [he]90-tom was used to seeing [the forlorn dead of [Offal Court]3091-offal court]1201-the forlorn dead of offal court hustled out of the way with a very different sort of expedition . However , [the Lord Hertford]107-hertford set [his]107-hertford mind at rest with a word or two . [A secretary of state]1203-a secretary of state presented an order of [the Council]1204-the council appointing the morrow at eleven for the reception of [the foreign ambassadors]1205-the foreign ambassadors , and desired [the King]294-the king ’s assent . [Tom]90-tom turned an inquiring look toward [Hertford]107-hertford , who whispered-- “ [[Your]90-tom Majesty]3215-your majesty will signify consent . [They]3215-your majesty come to testify [[their]3215-your majesty royal masters]3676-their royal masters ’ sense of the heavy calamity which hath visited [your]90-tom Grace and [the realm of England]3677-the realm of england . ”[107-hertford] [Tom]90-tom did as [he]90-tom was bidden . [Another secretary]1207-another secretary began to read a preamble concerning the expenses of [[the late King]1188-the late king ’s household]1209-the late king ’s household , which had amounted to 28,000 pounds during the preceding six months -- a sum so vast that it made [Tom]90-tom Canty gasp ; [he]90-tom gasped again when the fact appeared that 20,000 pounds of this money was still owing and unpaid ; { 4 } and once more when it appeared that [[the King]90-tom ’s coffers]1210-the king ’s coffers were about empty , and [[his]90-tom twelve hundred servants]1211-his twelve hundred servants much embarrassed for lack of the wages due [them]1211-his twelve hundred servants . [Tom]90-tom spoke out , with lively apprehension-- “ [We]3678-we be going to the dogs , ’ tis plain . ‘ Tis meet and necessary that [we]3678-we take [a smaller house]3679-a smaller house and set [the servants]428-the servants at large , sith [they]428-the servants be of no value but to make delay , and trouble one with offices that harass the spirit and shame the soul , [they]428-the servants misbecoming any but a doll , that hath nor brains nor hands to help itself withal . [I]90-tom remember [me]90-tom of [a small house that standeth over against [the fish - market]3682-the fish - market , by [Billingsgate--]49-billingsgate--]3681-a small house that standeth over against the fish - market , by billingsgate-- ”[90-tom] A sharp pressure upon [Tom]90-tom ’s arm stopped [his]90-tom foolish tongue and sent a blush to [his]90-tom face ; but no countenance there betrayed any sign that this strange speech had been remarked or given concern . [A secretary]1212-a secretary made report that forasmuch as [the late King]1188-the late king had provided in [his]90-tom will for conferring the ducal degree upon [the Earl of Hertford]3253-the earl of hertford and raising [[his]90-tom brother]1215-his brother , [Sir Thomas Seymour]146-tom , to the peerage , and likewise [[Hertford]107-hertford ’s son]1216-hertford ’s son to an earldom , together with similar aggrandisements to [other great servants of the Crown]1217-other great servants of the crown , [the Council]1204-the council had resolved to hold a sitting on the 16th of February for the delivering and confirming of these honours , and that meantime , [the late King]1188-the late king not having granted , in writing , estates suitable to the support of [these dignities]1220-these dignities , [the Council]50-the council , knowing [his]90-tom private wishes in that regard , had thought proper to grant to [Seymour]146-tom ‘ 500 pound lands , ’ and to [[Hertford]107-hertford ’s son]1216-hertford ’s son ‘ 800 pound lands , and 300 pound of [the next bishop]1222-the next bishop ’s lands which should fall [vacant,’--his present Majesty]1223-vacant,’--his present majesty being willing . { 5 } [Tom]146-tom was about to blurt out something about the propriety of paying [the late King]1188-the late king ’s debts first , before squandering all this money , but a timely touch upon [his]146-tom arm , from [the thoughtful Hertford]107-hertford , saved [him]146-tom this indiscretion ; wherefore [he]146-tom gave the royal assent , without spoken comment , but with much inward discomfort . While [he]146-tom sat reflecting a moment over the ease with which [he]146-tom was doing strange and glittering miracles , a happy thought shot into [his]146-tom mind : why not make [[his]146-tom mother]287-his mother [Duchess of [Offal Court]3091-offal court]1226-duchess of offal court , and give [her]287-his mother an estate ? But a sorrowful thought swept it instantly away : [he]146-tom was only [a king]390-a king in name , [these grave veterans]1229-these grave veterans and [great nobles]539-great nobles were [[his]146-tom masters]1231-his masters ; to [them]1229-these grave veterans [[his]146-tom mother]287-his mother was only [the creature of a diseased mind]1233-the creature of a diseased mind ; [they]1229-these grave veterans would simply listen to [his]146-tom project with unbelieving ears , then send for [the doctor]1234-the doctor . The dull work went tediously on . Petitions were read , and proclamations , patents , and all manner of wordy , repetitious , and wearisome papers relating to the public business ; and at last [Tom]146-tom sighed pathetically and murmured to [himself]146-tom , “ In what have [I]146-tom offended , that [the good God]3683-the good god should take [me]146-tom away from [the fields]3684-the fields and the free air and the sunshine , to shut [me]146-tom up here and make [me]146-tom [a king]390-a king and afflict [me]146-tom so ? ”[146-tom] Then [his]146-tom poor muddled head nodded a while and presently drooped to [his]146-tom shoulder ; and the business of [the empire]1235-the empire came to a standstill for want of that august factor , the ratifying power . Silence ensued around [the slumbering child]1236-the slumbering child , and [the sages of [the realm]3233-the realm]1237-the sages of the realm ceased from [their]1237-the sages of the realm deliberations . During the forenoon , [Tom]146-tom had an enjoyable hour , by permission of [[his]146-tom keepers]609-his keepers , [Hertford]107-hertford and [St. John]109-lord st. john , with [the Lady Elizabeth]91-the lady elizabeth and [the little Lady Jane Grey]97-the lady jane grey ; though the spirits of [the princesses]1240-the princesses were rather subdued by the mighty stroke that had fallen upon [the royal house]1241-the royal house ; and at the end of the visit [his]146-tom ‘ elder sister’--afterwards [the ‘ Bloody Mary ’ of history]1242-the ‘ bloody mary ’ of history -- chilled [him]146-tom with a solemn interview which had but one merit in [his]146-tom eyes , its brevity . [He]146-tom had a few moments to [himself]146-tom , and then [a slim lad of about twelve years of age]1243-a slim lad of about twelve years of age was admitted to [his]146-tom presence , whose clothing , except [his]1243-a slim lad of about twelve years of age snowy ruff and the laces about [his]1243-a slim lad of about twelve years of age wrists , was of black,--doublet , hose , and all . [He]1243-a slim lad of about twelve years of age bore no badge of mourning but a knot of purple ribbon on [his]1243-a slim lad of about twelve years of age shoulder . [He]1243-a slim lad of about twelve years of age advanced hesitatingly , with head bowed and bare , and dropped upon one knee in front of [Tom]146-tom . [Tom]146-tom sat still and contemplated [him]1243-a slim lad of about twelve years of age soberly a moment . Then [he]146-tom said-- “ Rise , [lad]3052-lad . Who art [thou]520-the boy . What wouldst have ? ”[146-tom] [The boy]520-the boy rose , and stood at graceful ease , but with an aspect of concern in [his]520-the boy face . [He]520-the boy said-- “ Of a surety [thou]520-the boy must remember [me]520-the boy , [[my]520-the boy lord]3168-my lord . [I]520-the boy am [[thy]520-the boy whipping - boy]3688-thy whipping - boy . ”[520-the boy] “ [My]520-the boy _ [whipping_-boy]3689-whipping_-boy ? ”[520-the boy] “ The same , [[your]520-the boy Grace]3566-your grace . [I]520-the boy am [Humphrey]147-humphrey -- [Humphrey Marlow]147-humphrey . ”[520-the boy] [Tom]146-tom perceived that here was [someone whom [[his]146-tom keepers]609-his keepers ought to have posted [him]146-tom about]1245-someone whom his keepers ought to have posted him about . The situation was delicate . What should [he]146-tom do?--pretend [he]146-tom knew [this lad]832-this lad , and then betray by [his]146-tom every utterance that [he]146-tom had never heard of [him]832-this lad before ? No , that would not do . An idea came to [his]146-tom relief : accidents like this might be likely to happen with some frequency , now that business urgencies would often call [Hertford]107-hertford and [St. John]109-lord st. john from [his]146-tom side , [they]1248-they being [members of [the Council of Executors]1192-the council of executors]1249-members of the council of executors ; therefore perhaps it would be well to strike out a plan [himself]146-tom to meet the requirements of such emergencies . Yes , that would be a wise course -- [he]146-tom would practise on [this boy]829-this boy , and see what sort of success [he]829-this boy might achieve . So [he]146-tom stroked [his]146-tom brow perplexedly a moment or two , and presently said-- “ Now [I]146-tom seem to remember [thee]829-this boy somewhat -- but [my]146-tom wit is clogged and dim with suffering-- ”[146-tom] “ [Alack]106-alack , [[my]1252-the whipping - boy poor master]3691-my poor master ! ”[1252-the whipping - boy] ejaculated [the whipping - boy]1252-the whipping - boy , with feeling ; adding , to [himself]1252-the whipping - boy , “ In truth ’ tis as [they]1248-they said -- [his]3691-my poor master mind is gone -- alas , [poor soul]3692-poor soul ! But misfortune catch [me]1252-the whipping - boy , how am [I]1252-the whipping - boy forgetting ! [They]1248-they said [one]3093-one must not seem to observe that aught is wrong with [him]3691-my poor master . ”[1252-the whipping - boy] “ ‘ Tis strange how [my]146-tom memory doth wanton with [me]146-tom these days , ”[146-tom] said [Tom]146-tom . “ But mind it not -- [I]146-tom mend apace -- a little clue doth often serve to bring [me]146-tom back again the things and names which had escaped [me]146-tom . ( And not [they]1248-they , only , forsooth , but e’en such as [I]146-tom ne’er heard before -- as [this lad]832-this lad shall see . ) Give [thy]3691-my poor master business speech . ”[146-tom] “ ‘ Tis matter of small weight , [[my]146-tom liege]3243-my liege , yet will [I]146-tom touch upon it , an ’ it please [[your]3243-my liege Grace]3566-your grace . Two days gone by , when [[your]3243-my liege Majesty]3215-your majesty faulted thrice in [your]3243-my liege Greek -- in the morning lessons,--dost remember it ? ”[146-tom] “ [Y]3698-y - e - s -- methinks [I]146-tom do . ( It is not much of a lie -- an ’ [I]146-tom had meddled with the Greek at all , [I]146-tom had not faulted simply thrice , but forty times . ) Yes , [I]146-tom do recall it , now -- go on . ”[146-tom] “ [The master]3699-the master , being wroth with what [he]3699-the master termed such slovenly and doltish work , did promise that [he]3699-the master would soundly whip [me]146-tom for it -- and-- ”[146-tom] “ Whip _ [thee]3691-my poor master _ ! ”[146-tom] said [Tom]146-tom , astonished out of [his]146-tom presence of mind . “ Why should [he]3699-the master whip _ [thee]3691-my poor master _ for faults of [mine]146-tom ? ”[146-tom] “ Ah , [[your]3243-my liege Grace]3566-your grace forgetteth again . [He]3699-the master always scourgeth [me]146-tom when [thou]3691-my poor master dost fail in [thy]3691-my poor master lessons . ”[146-tom] “ True , true -- [I]146-tom had forgot . [Thou]3691-my poor master teachest [me]146-tom in private -- then if [I]146-tom fail , [he]3699-the master argueth that [thy]3691-my poor master office was lamely done , and-- ”[146-tom] “ Oh , [[my]146-tom liege]3243-my liege , what words are these ? [I]146-tom , [the humblest of [[thy]3691-my poor master servants]3703-thy servants]3702-the humblest of thy servants , presume to teach _ [thee]3691-my poor master _ ? ”[146-tom] “ Then where is [thy]3691-my poor master blame ? What riddle is this ? Am [I]146-tom in truth gone mad , or is it [thou]3691-my poor master ?
