Kneeling , [he]1537-the humorous tinker pretended to kiss [the King]294-the king ’s foot , and was indignantly spurned ; whereupon [he]1537-the humorous tinker went about begging for a rag to paste over the place upon [his]1537-the humorous tinker face which had been touched by the foot , saying it must be preserved from contact with the vulgar air , and that [he]1537-the humorous tinker should make [his]1537-the humorous tinker fortune by going on [the highway]1303-the highway and exposing it to view at the rate of a hundred shillings a sight . [He]1537-the humorous tinker made [himself]1537-the humorous tinker so killingly funny that [he]1537-the humorous tinker was the envy and admiration of [the whole mangy rabble]1540-the whole mangy rabble . Tears of shame and indignation stood in [the little monarch]1541-the little monarch ’s eyes ; and the thought in [his]1541-the little monarch heart was , “ Had [I]1541-the little monarch offered [them]1544-the troop of vagabonds a deep wrong [they]1544-the troop of vagabonds could not be more cruel -- yet have [I]1541-the little monarch proffered nought but to do [them]1544-the troop of vagabonds a kindness -- and it is thus [they]1544-the troop of vagabonds use [me]1541-the little monarch for it ! ”[1541-the little monarch] CHAPTER XVIII . [The Prince]236-the prince with [the Tramps]1543-the tramps . [The troop of [vagabonds]1545-vagabonds]1544-the troop of vagabonds turned out at early dawn , and set forward on [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds march . There was a lowering sky overhead , sloppy ground under foot , and a winter chill in the air . All gaiety was gone from [the company]565-the company ; [some]372-some were sullen and silent , [some]372-some were irritable and petulant , none were gentle - humoured , [all]654-all were thirsty . [The Ruffler]164-the ruffler put ‘ [Jack]155-jack ’ in [Hugo]156-hugo ’s charge , with some brief instructions , and commanded [John Canty]93-john canty to keep away from [him]156-hugo and let [him]156-hugo alone ; [he]164-the ruffler also warned [Hugo]156-hugo not to be too rough with [the lad]496-the lad . After a while the weather grew milder , and the clouds lifted somewhat . [The troop]1551-the troop ceased to shiver , and [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds spirits began to improve . [They]1544-the troop of vagabonds grew more and more cheerful , and finally began to chaff [each other]246-each other and insult [passengers]1553-passengers along [the highway]1303-the highway . This showed that [they]1544-the troop of vagabonds were awaking to an appreciation of life and its joys once more . The dread in which [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds sort was held was apparent in the fact that [everybody]247-everybody gave [them]1544-the troop of vagabonds [the road]454-the road , and took [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds ribald insolences meekly , without venturing to talk back . [They]1544-the troop of vagabonds snatched linen from the hedges , occasionally in full view of [the owners]1557-the owners , who made no protest , but only seemed grateful that [they]1557-the owners did not take the hedges , too . [By - and - by]1558-by - and - by [they]1544-the troop of vagabonds invaded [a small farmhouse]1559-a small farmhouse and made [themselves]1544-the troop of vagabonds at [home]296-home while [the trembling farmer]1561-the trembling farmer and [[his]1561-the trembling farmer people]3151-his people swept the larder clean to furnish a breakfast for [them]1544-the troop of vagabonds . [They]1544-the troop of vagabonds chucked [the housewife]1563-the housewife and [[her]1563-the housewife daughters]1564-her daughters under the chin whilst receiving the food from [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds hands , and made coarse jests about [them]1544-the troop of vagabonds , accompanied with insulting epithets and bursts of horse - laughter . [They]1544-the troop of vagabonds threw bones and vegetables at [the farmer]1565-the farmer and [[his]1561-the trembling farmer sons]1566-his sons , kept [them]1544-the troop of vagabonds dodging all the time , and applauded uproariously when a good hit was made . [They]1544-the troop of vagabonds ended by buttering the head of [one of [the daughters who resented some of [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds familiarities]1568-the daughters who resented some of their familiarities]1567-one of the daughters who resented some of their familiarities . When [they]1544-the troop of vagabonds took [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds leave [they]1544-the troop of vagabonds threatened to come back and burn [the house]292-the house over the heads of [the family]820-the family if any report of [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds doings got to the ears of [the authorities]1571-the authorities . About noon , after a long and weary tramp , [the gang]1491-the gang came to a halt behind a hedge on [the outskirts of [a considerable village]1574-a considerable village]1573-the outskirts of a considerable village . An hour was allowed for rest , then [the crew]1575-the crew scattered [themselves]1544-the troop of vagabonds abroad to enter [the village]3790-the village at different points to ply [their]1544-the troop of vagabonds various trades--‘Jack ’ was sent with [Hugo]156-hugo . [They]1544-the troop of vagabonds wandered hither and thither for some time , [Hugo]156-hugo watching for opportunities to do a stroke of business , but finding none -- so [he]156-hugo finally said-- “ [I]156-hugo see nought to steal ; [it]1574-a considerable village is [a paltry place]4007-a paltry place . Wherefore [we]1544-the troop of vagabonds will beg . ”[156-hugo] “ _ [We]1544-the troop of vagabonds _ , forsooth ! Follow [thy]1544-the troop of vagabonds trade -- it befits [thee]1544-the troop of vagabonds . But _ [I]156-hugo _ will not beg . ”[156-hugo] “ [Thou’lt]4008-thy not beg ! ”[156-hugo] exclaimed [Hugo]156-hugo , eyeing [the King]294-the king with surprise . “ Prithee , since when hast [thou]4008-thy reformed ? ”[156-hugo] “ What dost [thou]4008-thy mean ? ”[156-hugo] “ Mean ? Hast [thou]4008-thy not begged [the streets of [London]1-london]4009-the streets of london all [thy]4008-thy life ? ”[156-hugo] “ [I]156-hugo ? [Thou]156-hugo idiot ! ”[156-hugo] “ Spare [thy]4008-thy compliments -- [thy]4008-thy stock will last the longer . [[Thy]4008-thy father]3066-thy father says [thou]4008-thy hast begged all [thy]4008-thy days . Mayhap [he]3066-thy father lied . Peradventure [you]294-the king will even make so bold as to _ say _ [he]3066-thy father lied , ”[156-hugo] scoffed [Hugo]156-hugo . “ [Him]3066-thy father _ [you]294-the king _ call [[my]156-hugo father]3049-my father ? Yes , [he]3066-thy father lied . ”[156-hugo] “ Come , play not [thy]4008-thy merry game of madman so far , [mate]4012-mate ; use it for [thy]4008-thy amusement , not [thy]4008-thy hurt . An ’ [I]156-hugo tell [him]3066-thy father this , [he]3066-thy father will scorch [thee]4008-thy finely for it . ”[156-hugo] “ Save [thyself]3066-thy father the trouble . [I]156-hugo will tell [him]3066-thy father . ”[156-hugo] “ [I]294-the king like [thy]4008-thy spirit , [I]294-the king do in truth ; but [I]294-the king do not admire [thy]4008-thy judgment . Bone - rackings and bastings be plenty enow in this life , without going out of [one]3093-one ’s way to invite [them]4008-thy . But a truce to these matters ; _ [I]294-the king _ believe [[your]4008-thy father]4014-your father . [I]294-the king doubt not [he]4014-your father can lie ; [I]294-the king doubt not [he]4014-your father _ doth _ lie , upon occasion , for the best of [us]4015-us do that ; but there is no occasion here . [A wise man]4016-a wise man does not waste so good a commodity as lying for nought . But come ; sith it is [thy]4008-thy humour to give over begging , wherewithal shall [we]4015-us busy [ourselves]4015-us ? With robbing [kitchens]4017-kitchens ? ”[294-the king] [The King]294-the king said , impatiently-- “ Have done with this folly -- [you]156-hugo weary [me]156-hugo ! ”[156-hugo] [Hugo]156-hugo replied , with temper-- “ Now harkee , [mate]4012-mate ; [you]4008-thy will not beg , [you]4008-thy will not rob ; so be it . But [I]294-the king will tell [you]4008-thy what [you]4008-thy _ will _ do . [You]4008-thy will play decoy whilst _ [I]294-the king _ beg . Refuse , an ’ [you]4008-thy think [you]4008-thy may venture ! ”[294-the king] [The King]294-the king was about to reply contemptuously , when [Hugo]156-hugo said , interrupting-- “ Peace ! Here comes one with a kindly face . Now will [I]156-hugo fall down in a fit . When [the stranger]949-the stranger runs to [me]156-hugo , set [you]4008-thy up a wail , and fall upon [your]4008-thy knees , seeming to weep ; then cry out as all the devils of misery were in [your]4008-thy belly , and say , ‘ Oh , [sir]3053-sir , it is [[my]156-hugo poor afflicted brother]4021-my poor afflicted brother , and [we]4022-we be friendless ; o ’ [God]87-god ’s name cast through [your]4008-thy merciful eyes one pitiful look upon [a sick , forsaken , and most miserable wretch]4023-a sick , forsaken , and most miserable wretch ; bestow one little penny out of [thy]4008-thy riches upon [one smitten of God and ready to perish!’--and]4024-one smitten of god and ready to perish!’--and mind [you]4008-thy , keep [you]4008-thy _ on _ wailing , and abate not till [we]4022-we bilk [him]4021-my poor afflicted brother of [his]4021-my poor afflicted brother penny , else shall [you]4008-thy rue it . ”[156-hugo] Then immediately [Hugo]156-hugo began to moan , and groan , and roll [his]156-hugo eyes , and reel and totter about ; and when [the stranger]949-the stranger was close at hand , down [he]949-the stranger sprawled before [him]949-the stranger , with a shriek , and began to writhe and wallow in the dirt , in seeming agony . “ O , [dear]4025-dear , [O]4025-dear dear ! ”[1581-the benevolent stranger] cried [the benevolent stranger]1581-the benevolent stranger , “ [O]4025-dear poor soul , [poor soul]3692-poor soul , how [he]4021-my poor afflicted brother doth suffer ! There -- let [me]1581-the benevolent stranger help [thee]4025-dear up . ”[1581-the benevolent stranger] “ [O noble sir]4027-o noble sir , [forbear]4028-forbear , and [God]87-god love [you]4027-o noble sir for [a princely gentleman]4029-a princely gentleman -- but it giveth [me]1581-the benevolent stranger cruel pain to touch [me]1581-the benevolent stranger when [I]1581-the benevolent stranger am taken so . [[My]1581-the benevolent stranger brother]3303-my brother there will tell [your]4027-o noble sir worship how [I]1581-the benevolent stranger am racked with anguish when these fits be upon [me]1581-the benevolent stranger . A penny , [dear sir]4031-dear sir , a penny , to buy a little food ; then leave [me]1581-the benevolent stranger to [my]1581-the benevolent stranger sorrows . ”[1581-the benevolent stranger] “ A penny ! [thou]4032-thou shalt have three , [thou]4032-thou hapless creature,”--and[1582-he] [he]1582-he fumbled in [his]1582-he pocket with nervous haste and got them out . “ There , [poor lad]3380-poor lad , take them and most welcome . Now come hither , [[my]1582-he boy]3408-my boy , and help [me]1582-he carry [[thy]4032-thou stricken brother]4035-thy stricken brother to [yon house]4036-yon house , where-- ”[1582-he] “ [I]294-the king am not [[his]4035-thy stricken brother brother]1215-his brother , ”[294-the king] said [the King]294-the king , interrupting . “ What ! not [[his]4035-thy stricken brother brother]1215-his brother ? ”[294-the king] “ Oh , hear [him]4035-thy stricken brother ! ”[156-hugo] groaned [Hugo]156-hugo , then privately ground [his]156-hugo teeth . “ [He]4035-thy stricken brother denies [[his]4035-thy stricken brother own brother]4039-his own brother -- and [he]4035-thy stricken brother with one foot in the grave ! ”[156-hugo] “ [Boy]1095-boy , [thou]4032-thou art indeed hard of heart , if this is [[thy]4032-thou brother]4041-thy brother . For shame!--and [he]4041-thy brother scarce able to move hand or foot . If [he]4041-thy brother is not [[thy]4032-thou brother]4041-thy brother , who is [he]4041-thy brother , then ? ”[294-the king] “ [A beggar]288-a beggar and [a thief]286-a thief ! [He]4041-thy brother has got [your]1095-boy money and has picked [your]1095-boy pocket likewise . An ’ [thou]4032-thou would’st do a healing miracle , lay [thy]4032-thou staff over [his]4041-thy brother shoulders and trust [Providence]165-providence for the rest . ”[156-hugo] But [Hugo]156-hugo did not tarry for the miracle . In a moment [he]156-hugo was up and off like the wind , [the gentleman following after and raising the hue and cry]1584-the gentleman following after and raising the hue and cry lustily as [he]156-hugo went . [The King]294-the king , breathing deep gratitude to Heaven for [his]294-the king own release , fled in the opposite direction , and did not slacken [his]294-the king pace until [he]294-the king was out of harm ’s reach . [He]294-the king took [the first road that offered]1586-the first road that offered , and soon put [the village]3790-the village behind [him]294-the king . [He]294-the king hurried along , as briskly as [he]294-the king could , during several hours , keeping a nervous watch over [his]294-the king shoulder for pursuit ; but [his]294-the king fears left [him]294-the king at last , and a grateful sense of security took [their]1588-their place . [He]294-the king recognised , now , that [he]294-the king was hungry , and also very tired . So [he]294-the king halted at [a farmhouse]1589-a farmhouse ; but when [he]294-the king was about to speak , [he]294-the king was cut short and driven rudely away . [His]294-the king clothes were against [him]294-the king . [He]294-the king wandered on , wounded and indignant , and was resolved to put [himself]294-the king in the way of like treatment no more . But hunger is [pride ’s master]1590-pride ’s master ; so , as the evening drew near , [he]294-the king made an attempt at [another farmhouse]1591-another farmhouse ; but here [he]294-the king fared worse than before ; for [he]294-the king was called hard names and was promised arrest as [a vagrant]1592-a vagrant except [he]294-the king moved on promptly . The night came on , chilly and overcast ; and still [the footsore monarch]1593-the footsore monarch laboured slowly on . [He]294-the king was obliged to keep moving , for every time [he]294-the king sat down to rest [he]294-the king was soon penetrated to the bone with the cold . All [his]294-the king sensations and experiences , as [he]294-the king moved through the solemn gloom and the empty vastness of the night , were new and strange to [him]294-the king . At intervals [he]294-the king heard voices approach , pass by , and fade into silence ; and as [he]294-the king saw nothing more of the bodies [they]1594-they belonged to than a sort of formless drifting blur , there was something spectral and uncanny about it all that made [him]294-the king shudder . Occasionally [he]294-the king caught the twinkle of a light -- always far away , apparently -- almost in [another world]1595-another world ; if [he]294-the king heard the tinkle of a sheep ’s bell , it was vague , distant , indistinct ; the muffled lowing of the herds floated to [him]294-the king on the night wind in vanishing cadences , a mournful sound ; now and then came the complaining howl of a dog over [viewless expanses of field and forest]1596-viewless expanses of field and forest ; all sounds were remote ; they made [the little King]1042-the little king feel that all life and activity were far removed from [him]294-the king , and that [he]294-the king stood solitary , companionless , in the centre of a measureless solitude . [He]294-the king stumbled along , through the gruesome fascinations of this new experience , startled occasionally by the soft rustling of the dry leaves overhead , so like human whispers they seemed to sound ; and by - and - by [he]294-the king came suddenly upon the freckled light of a tin lantern near at hand . [He]294-the king stepped back into the shadows and waited . The lantern stood by the open door of [a barn]1598-a barn . [The King]294-the king waited some time -- there was no sound , and [nobody]650-nobody stirring . [He]294-the king got so cold , standing still , and [the hospitable barn]1601-the hospitable barn looked so enticing , that at last [he]294-the king resolved to risk everything and enter . [He]294-the king started swiftly and stealthily , and just as [he]294-the king was crossing the threshold [he]294-the king heard voices behind [him]294-the king . [He]294-the king darted behind a cask , within [the barn]1442-the barn , and stooped down . [Two farm - labourers]1603-two farm - labourers came in , bringing the lantern with [them]1603-two farm - labourers , and fell to work , talking meanwhile . Whilst [they]1603-two farm - labourers moved about with the light , [the King]294-the king made good use of [his]294-the king eyes and took the bearings of what seemed to be [a good - sized stall at the further end of [the place]3615-the place]1605-a good - sized stall at the further end of the place , purposing to grope [his]294-the king way to [it]1605-a good - sized stall at the further end of the place when [he]294-the king should be left to [himself]294-the king . [He]294-the king also noted the position of a pile of horse blankets , midway of [the route]1607-the route , with the intent to levy upon [them]1603-two farm - labourers for the service of [the crown of [England]2-england]1608-the crown of england for one night . By - and - by [the men]1609-the men finished and went away , fastening the door behind [them]1609-the men and taking the lantern with [them]1609-the men . [The shivering King]1610-the shivering king made for the blankets , with as good speed as the darkness would allow ; gathered them up , and then groped [his]294-the king way safely to [the stall]1611-the stall . Of two of the blankets [he]294-the king made a bed , then covered [himself]294-the king with the remaining two . [He]294-the king was [a glad monarch]1612-a glad monarch , now , though the blankets were old and thin , and not quite warm enough ; and besides gave out a pungent horsey odour that was almost suffocatingly powerful . Although [the King]294-the king was hungry and chilly , [he]294-the king was also so tired and so drowsy that [these latter influences]1614-these latter influences soon began to get the advantage of [the former]619-the former , and [he]294-the king presently dozed off into a state of semi - consciousness . Then , just as [he]294-the king was on the point of losing [himself]294-the king wholly , [he]294-the king distinctly felt something touch [him]294-the king ! [He]294-the king was broad awake in a moment , and gasping for breath . The cold horror of that mysterious touch in the dark almost made [his]294-the king heart stand still . [He]294-the king lay motionless , and listened , scarcely breathing . But nothing stirred , and there was no sound . [He]294-the king continued to listen , and wait , during what seemed a long time , but still nothing stirred , and there was no sound . So [he]294-the king began to drop into a drowse once more , at last ; and all at once [he]294-the king felt that mysterious touch again ! It was a grisly thing , this light touch from this noiseless and invisible presence ; it made [the boy]520-the boy sick with ghostly fears . What should [he]294-the king do ? That was the question ; but [he]294-the king did not know how to answer it . Should [he]294-the king leave [these reasonably comfortable quarters]1617-these reasonably comfortable quarters and fly from this inscrutable horror ? But fly whither ? [He]294-the king could not get out of [the barn]1442-the barn ; and the idea of scurrying blindly hither and thither in the dark , within the captivity of the four walls , with this phantom gliding after [him]294-the king , and visiting [him]294-the king with that soft hideous touch upon cheek or shoulder at every turn , was intolerable . But to stay where [he]294-the king was , and endure this living death all night -- was that better ? No . What , then , was there left to do ? Ah , there was but one course ; [he]294-the king knew it well -- [he]294-the king must put out [his]294-the king hand and find that thing ! It was easy to think this ; but it was hard to brace [himself]294-the king up to try it . Three times [he]294-the king stretched [his]294-the king hand a little way out into the dark , gingerly ; and snatched it suddenly back , with a gasp -- not because it had encountered anything , but because [he]294-the king had felt so sure it was just _ going _ to . But the fourth time , [he]294-the king groped a little further , and [his]294-the king hand lightly swept against something soft and warm . This petrified [him]294-the king , nearly , with fright ; [his]294-the king mind was in such a state that [he]294-the king could imagine the thing to be nothing else than a corpse , newly dead and still warm . [He]294-the king thought [he]294-the king would rather die than touch it again . But [he]294-the king thought this false thought because [he]294-the king did not know the immortal strength of human curiosity . In no long time [his]294-the king hand was tremblingly groping again -- against [his]294-the king judgment , and without [his]294-the king consent -- but groping persistently on , just the same . It encountered a bunch of long hair ; [he]294-the king shuddered , but followed up the hair and found what seemed to be a warm rope ; followed up the rope and found [an innocent calf!--for the rope]1619-an innocent calf!--for the rope was not a rope at all , but the calf ’s tail . [The King]294-the king was cordially ashamed of [himself]294-the king for having gotten all that fright and misery out of so paltry a matter as a slumbering calf ; but [he]294-the king need not have felt so about it , for it was not the calf that frightened [him]294-the king , but a dreadful non - existent something which the calf stood for ; and [any other boy]1621-any other boy , in those old superstitious times , would have acted and suffered just as [he]294-the king had done . [The King]294-the king was not only delighted to find that [the creature]1623-the creature was only a calf , but delighted to have [the calf]1624-the calf ’s company ; for [he]294-the king had been feeling so lonesome and friendless that the company and comradeship of even this humble animal were welcome . And [he]294-the king had been so buffeted , so rudely entreated by [his]294-the king own kind , that it was a real comfort to [him]294-the king to feel that [he]294-the king was at last in the society of [a fellow - creature that had at least a soft heart and a gentle spirit , whatever loftier attributes might be lacking]1625-a fellow - creature that had at least a soft heart and a gentle spirit , whatever loftier attributes might be lacking . So [he]294-the king resolved to waive rank and make friends with the calf . While stroking its sleek warm back -- for it lay near [him]294-the king and within easy reach -- it occurred to [him]294-the king that this calf might be utilised in more ways than one . Whereupon [he]294-the king re - arranged [his]294-the king bed , spreading it down close to the calf ; then [he]294-the king cuddled [himself]294-the king up to the calf ’s back , drew the covers up over [himself]294-the king and [[his]294-the king friend]3482-his friend , and in a minute or two was as warm and comfortable as [he]294-the king had ever been in [the downy couches of [the regal palace of [Westminster]15-westminster]1628-the regal palace of westminster]1627-the downy couches of the regal palace of westminster . Pleasant thoughts came at once ; life took on a cheerfuller seeming . [He]294-the king was free of the bonds of servitude and crime , free of the companionship of [base and brutal outlaws]1629-base and brutal outlaws ; [he]294-the king was warm ; [he]294-the king was sheltered ; in a word , [he]294-the king was happy . The night wind was rising ; it swept by in fitful gusts that made [the old barn]1630-the old barn quake and rattle , then its forces died down at intervals , and went moaning and wailing around corners and projections -- but it was all music to [the King]294-the king , now that [he]294-the king was snug and comfortable : let it blow and rage , let it batter and bang , let it moan and wail , [he]294-the king minded it not , [he]294-the king only enjoyed it . [He]294-the king merely snuggled the closer to [[his]294-the king friend]3482-his friend , in a luxury of warm contentment , and drifted blissfully out of consciousness into a deep and dreamless sleep that was full of serenity and peace . The distant dogs howled , the melancholy kine complained , and the winds went on raging , whilst furious sheets of rain drove along the roof ; but [the Majesty of [England]2-england]551-the majesty of england slept on , undisturbed , and the calf did the same , [it]1634-it being a simple creature , and not easily troubled by storms or embarrassed by sleeping with [a king]390-a king . CHAPTER XIX . [The Prince]236-the prince with [the peasants]1637-the peasants . When [the King]294-the king awoke in the early morning , [he]294-the king found that a wet but thoughtful rat had crept into [the place]3615-the place during the night and made a cosy bed for [itself]1634-it in [his]294-the king bosom . Being disturbed now , it scampered away . [The boy]520-the boy smiled , and said , “ [Poor fool]4045-poor fool , why so fearful ? [I]520-the boy am as forlorn as [thou]4046-thou . ‘ Twould be a sham in [me]520-the boy to hurt the helpless , who am [myself]520-the boy so helpless . Moreover , [I]520-the boy owe [you]4045-poor fool thanks for a good omen ; for when [a king]390-a king has fallen so low that the very rats do make a bed of [him]390-a king , it surely meaneth that [his]390-a king fortunes be upon the turn , since it is plain [he]390-a king can no lower go . ”[520-the boy] [He]520-the boy got up and stepped out of [the stall]1611-the stall , and just then [he]520-the boy heard the sound of [children]1018-children ’s voices . [The barn]1442-the barn door opened and [a couple of little girls]1644-a couple of little girls came in . As soon as [they]1644-a couple of little girls saw [him]294-the king [their]1644-a couple of little girls talking and laughing ceased , and [they]1644-a couple of little girls stopped and stood still , gazing at [him]294-the king with strong curiosity ; [they]1644-a couple of little girls presently began to whisper together , then [they]1644-a couple of little girls approached nearer , and stopped again to gaze and whisper . By - and - by [they]1644-a couple of little girls gathered courage and began to discuss [him]294-the king aloud . [One]166-one said-- “ [He]294-the king hath a comely face . ”[1645-the other] [The other]1645-the other added-- “ And pretty hair . ”[1645-the other] “ But is ill clothed enow . ”[1645-the other] “ And how starved [he]294-the king looketh . ”[1644-a couple of little girls] [They]1644-a couple of little girls came still nearer , sidling shyly around and about [him]294-the king , examining [him]294-the king minutely from all points , as if [he]294-the king were some strange new kind of animal , but warily and watchfully the while , as if [they]1644-a couple of little girls half feared [he]294-the king might be a sort of animal that would bite , upon occasion . Finally [they]1644-a couple of little girls halted before [him]294-the king , holding [each other]246-each other ’s hands for protection , and took a good satisfying stare with [their]1644-a couple of little girls innocent eyes ; then [one of [them]1644-a couple of little girls]681-one of them plucked up all [her]681-one of them courage and inquired with honest directness-- “ Who art [thou]294-the king , [boy]1095-boy ? ”[681-one of them] “ [I]681-one of them am [the King]294-the king , ”[681-one of them] was the grave answer . [The children]290-the children gave a little start , and [their]290-the children eyes spread [themselves]290-the children wide open and remained so during a speechless half minute . Then curiosity broke the silence-- “ [The _ King]4050-the _ king _ ? What King ? ”[3093-one] “ [The King of [England]2-england]4051-the king of england . ”[290-the children] [The children]290-the children looked at [each other]246-each other -- then at [him]294-the king -- then at [each other]246-each other again -- wonderingly , perplexedly ; then [one]3093-one said-- “ Didst hear [him]294-the king , [Margery?--he]167-margery?--he said [he]294-the king is [the King]294-the king . Can that be true ? ”[3093-one] “ How can it be else but true , [Prissy]168-prissy ? Would [he]294-the king say a lie ? For look [you]168-prissy , [Prissy]168-prissy , an ’ it were not true , it _ would _ be a lie . It surely would be . Now think on’t . For all things that be not true , be lies -- [thou]4053-thou canst make nought else out of it . ”[3093-one] It was a good tight argument , without a leak in it anywhere ; and it left [Prissy]168-prissy ’s half - doubts not a leg to stand on . [She]168-prissy considered a moment , then put [the King]294-the king upon [his]294-the king honour with the simple remark-- “ If [thou]4053-thou art truly [the King]294-the king , then [I]168-prissy believe [thee]4053-thou . ”[168-prissy] “ [I]168-prissy am truly [the King]294-the king . ”[168-prissy] This settled the matter . [[His]294-the king Majesty]3254-his majesty ’s royalty was accepted without further question or discussion , and [the two little girls]1655-the two little girls began at once to inquire into how [he]294-the king came to be where [he]294-the king was , and how [he]294-the king came to be so unroyally clad , and whither [he]294-the king was bound , and all about [his]294-the king affairs . It was a mighty relief to [him]294-the king to pour out [his]294-the king troubles where they would not be scoffed at or doubted ; so [he]294-the king told [his]294-the king tale with feeling , forgetting even [his]294-the king hunger for the time ; and it was received with the deepest and tenderest sympathy by [the gentle little maids]1656-the gentle little maids . But when [he]294-the king got down to [his]294-the king latest experiences and [they]1655-the two little girls learned how long [he]294-the king had been without food , [they]1655-the two little girls cut [him]294-the king short and hurried [him]294-the king away to [the farmhouse]1657-the farmhouse to find a breakfast for [him]294-the king . [The King]294-the king was cheerful and happy now , and said to [himself]294-the king , “ When [I]294-the king am come to [mine]294-the king own again , [I]294-the king will always honour [little children]4056-little children , remembering how that these trusted [me]294-the king and believed in [me]294-the king in [my]294-the king time of trouble ; whilst [they]4056-little children that were older , and thought [themselves]4056-little children wiser , mocked at [me]294-the king and held [me]294-the king for [a liar]4057-a liar . ”[294-the king] [[The children]290-the children ’s mother]1660-the children ’s mother received [the King]294-the king kindly , and was full of pity ; for [his]294-the king forlorn condition and apparently crazed intellect touched [her]1660-the children ’s mother womanly heart . [She]1660-the children ’s mother was [a widow]1662-a widow , and rather poor ; consequently [she]1660-the children ’s mother had seen trouble enough to enable [her]1660-the children ’s mother to feel for [the unfortunate]1663-the unfortunate . [She]1660-the children ’s mother imagined that [the demented boy]1664-the demented boy had wandered away from [[his]1664-the demented boy friends]1665-his friends or [keepers]1666-keepers ; so [she]1660-the children ’s mother tried to find out whence [he]1664-the demented boy had come , in order that [she]1660-the children ’s mother might take measures to return [him]1664-the demented boy ; but all [her]1660-the children ’s mother references to [neighbouring towns]1667-neighbouring towns and [villages]1668-villages , and all [her]1660-the children ’s mother inquiries in the same line went for nothing -- [the boy]520-the boy ’s face , and [his]520-the boy answers , too , showed that the things [she]1660-the children ’s mother was talking of were not familiar to [him]520-the boy . [He]520-the boy spoke earnestly and simply about court matters , and broke down , more than once , when speaking of [the late King]1188-the late king ‘ [[his]520-the boy father]306-his father ’ ; but whenever the conversation changed to baser topics , [he]520-the boy lost interest and became silent . [The woman]802-the woman was mightily puzzled ; but [she]1660-the children ’s mother did not give up . As [she]1660-the children ’s mother proceeded with [her]1660-the children ’s mother cooking , [she]1660-the children ’s mother set [herself]1660-the children ’s mother to contriving devices to surprise [the boy]520-the boy into betraying [his]520-the boy real secret . [She]1660-the children ’s mother talked about cattle -- [he]520-the boy showed no concern ; then about sheep -- the same result : so [her]1660-the children ’s mother guess that [he]520-the boy had been [a shepherd boy]1674-a shepherd boy was an error ; [she]1660-the children ’s mother talked about [mills]1675-mills ; and about [weavers]1676-weavers , [tinkers]1677-tinkers , [smiths]1678-smiths , [trades]1679-trades and [tradesmen of all sorts]1680-tradesmen of all sorts ; and about Bedlam , and [jails]1681-jails , and charitable retreats : but no matter , [she]1660-the children ’s mother was baffled at all points . Not altogether , either ; for [she]1660-the children ’s mother argued that [she]1660-the children ’s mother had narrowed the thing down to domestic service . Yes , [she]1660-the children ’s mother was sure [she]1660-the children ’s mother was on the right track , now ; [he]520-the boy must have been [a house servant]1682-a house servant . So [she]1660-the children ’s mother led up to that . But the result was discouraging . The subject of sweeping appeared to weary [him]520-the boy ; fire - building failed to stir [him]520-the boy ; scrubbing and scouring awoke no enthusiasm . [The goodwife]1683-the goodwife touched , with a perishing hope , and rather as a matter of form , upon the subject of cooking . To [her]1660-the children ’s mother surprise , and [her]1660-the children ’s mother vast delight , [the King]294-the king ’s face lighted at once ! Ah , [she]1660-the children ’s mother had hunted [him]294-the king down at last , [she]1660-the children ’s mother thought ; and [she]1660-the children ’s mother was right proud , too , of the devious shrewdness and tact which had accomplished it . [Her]1660-the children ’s mother tired tongue got a chance to rest , now ; for [the King]87-god ’s , inspired by gnawing hunger and the fragrant smells that came from the sputtering pots and pans , turned itself loose and delivered itself up to such an eloquent dissertation upon certain toothsome dishes , that within three minutes [the woman]802-the woman said to [herself]802-the woman , “ Of a truth [I]802-the woman was right -- [he]294-the king hath holpen in [a kitchen]4058-a kitchen ! ”[802-the woman] Then [he]87-god broadened [his]87-god bill of fare , and discussed it with such appreciation and animation , that [the goodwife]1683-the goodwife said to [herself]1660-the children ’s mother , “ Good lack ! how can [he]294-the king know so many dishes , and so fine ones withal ? For these belong only upon the tables of [the rich and great]4059-the rich and great . Ah , now [I]1683-the goodwife see ! ragged outcast as [he]294-the king is , [he]294-the king must have served in [the palace]425-the palace before [his]294-the king reason went astray ; yes , [he]294-the king must have helped in [the very kitchen of [the King]294-the king [himself]294-the king]4061-the very kitchen of the king himself ! [I]1683-the goodwife will test [him]294-the king . ”[1683-the goodwife] Full of eagerness to prove [her]1660-the children ’s mother sagacity , [she]1660-the children ’s mother told [the King]294-the king to mind the cooking a moment -- hinting that [he]294-the king might manufacture and add a dish or two , if [he]294-the king chose ; then [she]1660-the children ’s mother went out of [the room]507-the room and gave [[her]1660-the children ’s mother children]1689-her children a sign to follow after . [The King]294-the king muttered-- “ [Another English king]4063-another english king had a commission like to this , in a bygone time -- it is nothing against [my]294-the king dignity to undertake an office which [the great Alfred]4064-the great alfred stooped to assume . But [I]294-the king will try to better serve [my]294-the king trust than [he]4063-another english king ; for [he]4063-another english king let the cakes burn . ”[294-the king] The intent was good , but the performance was not answerable to it , for [this King]1691-this king , like [the other one]1692-the other one , soon fell into deep thinkings concerning [his]1691-this king vast affairs , and the same calamity resulted -- the cookery got burned . [The woman]802-the woman returned in time to save the breakfast from entire destruction ; and [she]1660-the children ’s mother promptly brought [the King]294-the king out of [his]294-the king dreams with a brisk and cordial tongue - lashing . Then , seeing how troubled [he]294-the king was over [his]294-the king violated trust , [she]1660-the children ’s mother softened at once , and was all goodness and gentleness toward [him]294-the king . [The boy]520-the boy made a hearty and satisfying meal , and was greatly refreshed and gladdened by it . It was a meal which was distinguished by this curious feature , that rank was waived on both sides ; yet [neither recipient of the favour]1696-neither recipient of the favour was aware that it had been extended . [The goodwife]1683-the goodwife had intended to feed [this young tramp]1698-this young tramp with broken victuals in a corner , like [any other tramp]1699-any other tramp or like a dog ; but [she]1660-the children ’s mother was so remorseful for the scolding [she]1660-the children ’s mother had given [him]294-the king , that [she]1660-the children ’s mother did what [she]1660-the children ’s mother could to atone for it by allowing [him]294-the king to sit at the family table and eat with [[his]294-the king betters]1700-his betters , on ostensible terms of equality with [them]1700-his betters ; and [the King]294-the king , on [his]294-the king side , was so remorseful for having broken [his]294-the king trust , after [the family]820-the family had been so kind to [him]294-the king , that [he]294-the king forced [himself]294-the king to atone for it by humbling [himself]294-the king to the family level , instead of requiring [the woman]802-the woman and [[her]802-the woman children]1689-her children to stand and wait upon [him]294-the king , while [he]294-the king occupied [their]820-the family table in the solitary state due to [his]294-the king birth and dignity . It does [us]1705-us all good to unbend sometimes . [This good woman]1706-this good woman was made happy all the day long by the applauses which [she]1706-this good woman got out of [herself]1706-this good woman for [her]1706-this good woman magnanimous condescension to [a tramp]1707-a tramp ; and [the King]294-the king was just as self - complacent over [his]294-the king gracious humility toward [a humble peasant woman]1709-a humble peasant woman . When breakfast was over , [the housewife]1563-the housewife told [the King]294-the king to wash up the dishes . This command was [a staggerer]1712-a staggerer , for a moment , and [the King]294-the king came near rebelling ; but then [he]294-the king said to [himself]294-the king , “ [Alfred the Great]169-alfred the great watched the cakes ; doubtless [he]169-alfred the great would have washed the dishes too -- therefore will [I]294-the king essay it . ”[294-the king] [He]294-the king made a sufficiently poor job of it ; and to [his]294-the king surprise too , for the cleaning of wooden spoons and trenchers had seemed an easy thing to do . It was a tedious and troublesome piece of work , but [he]294-the king finished it at last . [He]294-the king was becoming impatient to get away on [his]294-the king journey now ; however , [he]294-the king was not to lose [this thrifty dame]1714-this thrifty dame ’s society so easily . [She]1563-the housewife furnished [him]294-the king some little odds and ends of employment , which [he]294-the king got through with after a fair fashion and with some credit . Then [she]1563-the housewife set [him]294-the king and [the little girls]1715-the little girls to paring some winter apples ; but [he]294-the king was so awkward at this service that [she]1563-the housewife retired [him]294-the king from it and gave [him]294-the king a butcher knife to grind . Afterwards [she]1563-the housewife kept [him]294-the king carding wool until [he]294-the king began to think [he]294-the king had laid [the good King Alfred]170-the good king alfred about far enough in the shade for the present in the matter of showy menial heroisms that would read picturesquely in story - books and histories , and so [he]294-the king was half - minded to resign . And when , just after the noonday dinner , [the goodwife]1683-the goodwife gave [him]294-the king a basket of kittens to drown , [he]294-the king did resign . At least [he]294-the king was just going to resign -- for [he]294-the king felt that [he]294-the king must draw the line somewhere , and it seemed to [him]294-the king that to draw it at kitten - drowning was about the right thing -- when there was an interruption . The interruption was [John Canty]93-john canty -- with a peddler ’s pack on [his]93-john canty back -- and [Hugo]156-hugo . [The King]294-the king discovered [these rascals]1718-these rascals approaching the front gate before [they]1718-these rascals had had a chance to see [him]294-the king ; so [he]294-the king said nothing about drawing the line , but took up [his]294-the king basket of kittens and stepped quietly out the back way , without a word . [He]294-the king left the creatures in [an out - house]1719-an out - house , and hurried on , into [a narrow lane at the rear]1720-a narrow lane at the rear . CHAPTER XX . [The Prince]236-the prince and [the hermit]1722-the hermit . The high hedge hid [him]294-the king from [the house]292-the house , now ; and so , under the impulse of a deadly fright , [he]294-the king let out all [his]294-the king forces and sped toward [a wood in the distance]1724-a wood in the distance . [He]294-the king never looked back until [he]294-the king had almost gained the shelter of [the forest]1438-the forest ; then [he]294-the king turned and descried [two figures in the distance]1726-two figures in the distance . That was sufficient ; [he]294-the king did not wait to scan [them]1726-two figures in the distance critically , but hurried on , and never abated [his]294-the king pace till [he]294-the king was far within the twilight depths of [the wood]1421-the wood . Then [he]294-the king stopped ; being persuaded that [he]294-the king was now tolerably safe . [He]294-the king listened intently , but the stillness was profound and solemn -- awful , even , and depressing to [the spirits]1728-the spirits . At wide intervals [his]294-the king straining ear did detect sounds , but they were so remote , and hollow , and mysterious , that they seemed not to be real sounds , but only the moaning and complaining ghosts of [departed ones]1729-departed ones . So the sounds were yet more dreary than the silence which [they]1726-two figures in the distance interrupted . It was [his]294-the king purpose , in the beginning , to stay where [he]294-the king was the rest of the day ; but a chill soon invaded [his]294-the king perspiring body , and [he]294-the king was at last obliged to resume movement in order to get warm . [He]294-the king struck straight through [the forest]1438-the forest , hoping to pierce to [a road presently]1731-a road presently , but [he]294-the king was disappointed in this . [He]294-the king travelled on and on ; but the farther [he]294-the king went , the denser the wood became , apparently . The gloom began to thicken , by - and - by , and [the King]294-the king realised that the night was coming on . It made [him]294-the king shudder to think of spending it in such an uncanny place ; so [he]294-the king tried to hurry faster , but [he]294-the king only made the less speed , for [he]294-the king could not now see well enough to choose [his]294-the king steps judiciously ; consequently [he]294-the king kept tripping over roots and tangling [himself]294-the king in vines and briers . And how glad [he]294-the king was when at last [he]294-the king caught the glimmer of a light ! [He]294-the king approached it warily , stopping often to look about [him]294-the king and listen . It came from an unglazed window - opening in [a shabby little hut]1733-a shabby little hut . [He]294-the king heard a voice , now , and felt a disposition to run and hide ; but [he]294-the king changed [his]294-the king mind at once , for this voice was praying , evidently . [He]294-the king glided to the one window of [the hut]1734-the hut , raised [himself]294-the king on tiptoe , and stole a glance within . [The room]507-the room was small ; [its]507-the room floor was the natural earth , beaten hard by use ; in a corner was a bed of rushes and a ragged blanket or two ; near it was a pail , a cup , a basin , and two or three pots and pans ; there was a short bench and a three - legged stool ; on the hearth the remains of a faggot fire were smouldering ; before a shrine , which was lighted by a single candle , knelt [an aged man]1736-an aged man , and on an old wooden box at [his]1736-an aged man side lay an open book and a human skull . [The man]495-the man was of large , bony frame ; [his]495-the man hair and whiskers were very long and snowy white ; [he]495-the man was clothed in a robe of sheepskins which reached from [his]495-the man neck to [his]495-the man heels . “ [A holy hermit]4065-a holy hermit ! ”[294-the king] said [the King]294-the king to [himself]294-the king ; “ now am [I]294-the king indeed fortunate . ”[294-the king] [The hermit]1722-the hermit rose from [his]1722-the hermit knees ; [the King]294-the king knocked . A deep voice responded-- “ Enter!--but leave sin behind , for the ground whereon [thou]294-the king shalt stand is holy ! ”[294-the king] [The King]294-the king entered , and paused . [The hermit]1722-the hermit turned a pair of gleaming , unrestful eyes upon [him]294-the king , and said-- “ Who art [thou]294-the king ? ”[1722-the hermit] “ [I]1722-the hermit am [the King]294-the king , ”[1722-the hermit] came the answer , with placid simplicity . “ Welcome , [King]3155-king ! ”[1722-the hermit] cried [the hermit]1722-the hermit , with enthusiasm . Then , bustling about with feverish activity , and constantly saying , “ Welcome , welcome , ”[1722-the hermit] [he]1722-the hermit arranged [his]1722-the hermit bench , seated [the King]294-the king on it , by the hearth , threw some faggots on the fire , and finally fell to pacing the floor with a nervous stride . “ Welcome ! Many have sought sanctuary here , but [they]4068-they were not worthy , and were turned away . But [a King who casts [his]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office crown away , and despises the vain splendours of [[his]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office office]4070-his office]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office , and clothes [his]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office body in rags , to devote [his]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office life to holiness and the mortification of the flesh -- [he]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office is worthy , [he]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office is welcome!--here shall [he]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office abide all [his]4069-a king who casts his crown away , and despises the vain splendours of his office days till death come . ”[294-the king] [The King]294-the king hastened to interrupt and explain , but [the hermit]1722-the hermit paid no attention to [him]294-the king -- did not even hear [him]294-the king , apparently , but went right on with [his]1722-the hermit talk , with a raised voice and a growing energy . “ And [thou]4071-thou shalt be at peace here . None shall find out [thy]4071-thou refuge to disquiet [thee]4071-thou with supplications to return to that empty and foolish life which [God]87-god hath moved [thee]4071-thou to abandon . [Thou]4071-thou shalt pray [here]451-here ; [thou]4071-thou shalt study the Book ; [thou]4071-thou shalt meditate upon the follies and delusions of [this world]1024-this world , and upon the sublimities of [the world]1021-the world to come ; [thou]4071-thou shalt feed upon crusts and herbs , and scourge [thy]4071-thou body with whips , daily , to the purifying of [thy]4071-thou soul . [Thou]4071-thou shalt wear a hair shirt next [thy]4071-thou skin ; [thou]4071-thou shalt drink water only ; and [thou]4071-thou shalt be at peace ; yes , wholly at peace ; for whoso comes to seek [thee]4071-thou shall go [his]1747-the old man , still pacing back and forth way again , baffled ; [he]1747-the old man , still pacing back and forth shall not find [thee]4071-thou , [he]1747-the old man , still pacing back and forth shall not molest [thee]4071-thou . ”[1747-the old man , still pacing back and forth] [The old man , still pacing back and forth]1747-the old man , still pacing back and forth , ceased to speak aloud , and began to mutter . [The King]294-the king seized this opportunity to state [his]294-the king case ; and [he]294-the king did it with an eloquence inspired by uneasiness and apprehension . But [the hermit]1722-the hermit went on muttering , and gave no heed . And still muttering , [he]1722-the hermit approached [the King]294-the king and said impressively-- “ ‘ Sh ! [I]1722-the hermit will tell [you]294-the king a secret ! ”[1722-the hermit] [He]1722-the hermit bent down to impart it , but checked [himself]1722-the hermit , and assumed a listening attitude . After a moment or two [he]1722-the hermit went on tiptoe to the window - opening , put [his]1722-the hermit head out , and peered around in the gloaming , then came tiptoeing back again , put [his]1722-the hermit face close down to [the King]294-the king ’s , and whispered-- “ [I]1722-the hermit am [an archangel]4075-an archangel ! ”[1722-the hermit] [The King]294-the king started violently , and said to [himself]294-the king , “ Would God [I]294-the king were with [the outlaws]4076-the outlaws again ; for lo , now am [I]294-the king [the prisoner of [a madman]953-a madman]4077-the prisoner of a madman ! ”[294-the king] [His]294-the king apprehensions were heightened , and they showed plainly in [his]294-the king face . In a low excited voice [the hermit]1722-the hermit continued-- “ [I]1754-i see [you]294-the king feel [my]1754-i atmosphere ! There ’s awe in [your]294-the king face ! None may be in this atmosphere and not be thus affected ; for it is the very atmosphere of [heaven]3949-heaven . [I]1754-i go thither and return , in the twinkling of an eye . [I]1754-i was made [an archangel]4075-an archangel on this very spot , it is five years ago , by angels sent from [heaven]3949-heaven to confer that awful dignity . [Their]4082-they presence filled [this place]4083-this place with an intolerable brightness . And [they]4082-they knelt to [me]1754-i , [King]3155-king ! yes , [they]4082-they knelt to [me]1754-i ! for [I]1754-i was greater than [they]4082-they . [I]1754-i have walked in the courts of [heaven]3949-heaven , and held speech with [the patriarchs]4086-the patriarchs . Touch [my]1754-i hand -- be not afraid -- touch it . There -- now [thou]4087-thou hast touched a hand which has been clasped by [Abraham]171-abraham and [Isaac]172-isaac and [Jacob]173-jacob ! For [I]1754-i have walked in [the golden courts]4088-the golden courts ; [I]1754-i have seen [the Deity]4089-the deity face to face ! ”[1754-i] [He]1754-i paused , to give this speech effect ; then [his]1754-i face suddenly changed , and [he]1754-i started to [his]1754-i feet again saying , with angry energy , “ Yes , [I]1754-i am [an archangel]4075-an archangel ; _ [a mere archangel!_--I that might have been pope]4091-a mere archangel!_--i that might have been pope ! It is verily true . [I]1754-i was told it from [heaven]3949-heaven in a dream , twenty years ago ; ah , yes , [I]1754-i was to be pope!--and [I]1754-i _ should _ have been [pope]4093-pope , for [Heaven]95-heaven had said it -- but [the King]294-the king dissolved [[my]1754-i religious house]4095-my religious house , and [I]1754-i , [poor obscure unfriended monk]4096-poor obscure unfriended monk , was cast homeless upon [the world]1021-the world , robbed of [my]1754-i mighty destiny ! ”[1754-i] Here [he]1754-i began to mumble again , and beat [his]1754-i forehead in futile rage , with [his]1754-i fist ; now and then articulating a venomous curse , and now and then a pathetic “ Wherefore [I]1754-i am nought but [an archangel]4075-an archangel -- [I]1754-i that should have been [pope]4093-pope ! ”[1754-i] So [he]1754-i went on , for an hour , whilst [the poor little King]1755-the poor little king sat and suffered . Then all at once [the old man]1756-the old man ’s frenzy departed , and [he]1754-i became all gentleness . [His]1754-i voice softened , [he]1754-i came down out of [his]1754-i clouds , and fell to prattling along so simply and so humanly , that [he]1754-i soon won [the King]294-the king ’s heart completely . [The old devotee]1758-the old devotee moved [the boy]520-the boy nearer to the fire and made [him]520-the boy comfortable ; doctored [his]520-the boy small bruises and abrasions with a deft and tender hand ; and then set about preparing and cooking a supper -- chatting pleasantly all the time , and occasionally stroking [the lad]496-the lad ’s cheek or patting [his]520-the boy head , in such a gently caressing way that in a little while all the fear and repulsion inspired by [the archangel]1761-the archangel were changed to reverence and affection for [the man]495-the man . This happy state of things continued while [the two]437-the two ate the supper ; then , after a prayer before [the shrine]1764-the shrine , [the hermit]1722-the hermit put [the boy]520-the boy to bed , in [a small adjoining room]1767-a small adjoining room , tucking [him]520-the boy in as snugly and lovingly as [a mother]1768-a mother might ; and so , with a parting caress , left [him]520-the boy and sat down by the fire , and began to poke the brands about in an absent and aimless way . Presently [he]520-the boy paused ; then tapped [his]520-the boy forehead several times with [his]520-the boy fingers , as if trying to recall some thought which had escaped from [his]520-the boy mind . Apparently [he]520-the boy was unsuccessful . Now [he]520-the boy started quickly up , and entered [[[his]520-the boy guest]1769-his guest ’s room]1770-his guest ’s room , and said-- “ [Thou]495-the man art [King]3155-king ? ”[520-the boy] “ Yes , ”[520-the boy] was the response , drowsily uttered . “ What [King]87-god ? ”[520-the boy] “ Of [England]2-england . ”[520-the boy] “ Of [England]2-england ? Then [Henry]105-henry viii is gone ! ”[520-the boy] “ [Alack]106-alack , it is so . [I]520-the boy am [[his]1756-the old man son]3648-his son . ”[520-the boy] A black frown settled down upon [the hermit]1722-the hermit ’s face , and [he]520-the boy clenched [his]520-the boy bony hands with a vindictive energy . [He]520-the boy stood a few moments , breathing fast and swallowing repeatedly , then said in a husky voice-- “ Dost know it was [he]105-henry viii that turned [us]4102-us out into [the world]1021-the world houseless and homeless ? ”[520-the boy] There was no response . [The old man]1756-the old man bent down and scanned [the boy]520-the boy ’s reposeful face and listened to [his]520-the boy placid breathing . “ [He]105-henry viii sleeps -- sleeps soundly ; ”[1756-the old man] and the frown vanished away and gave place to an expression of evil satisfaction . A smile flitted across [the dreaming boy]1774-the dreaming boy ’s features . [The hermit]1722-the hermit muttered , “ So -- [his]105-henry viii heart is happy ; ”[1722-the hermit] and [he]1722-the hermit turned away . [He]1722-the hermit went stealthily about [the place]3615-the place , seeking here and there for something ; now and then halting to listen , now and then jerking [his]1722-the hermit head around and casting a quick glance toward the bed ; and always muttering , always mumbling to [himself]1722-the hermit . At last [he]1722-the hermit found what [he]1722-the hermit seemed to want -- a rusty old butcher knife and a whetstone . Then [he]1722-the hermit crept to [his]1722-the hermit place by the fire , sat [himself]1722-the hermit down , and began to whet the knife softly on the stone , still muttering , mumbling , ejaculating . The winds sighed around [the lonely place]1777-the lonely place , the mysterious voices of the night floated by out of the distances . The shining eyes of venturesome mice and rats peered out at [the old man]1756-the old man from cracks and coverts , but [he]1722-the hermit went on with [his]1722-the hermit work , rapt , absorbed , and noted none of these things . At long intervals [he]1722-the hermit drew [his]1722-the hermit thumb along the edge of [his]1722-the hermit knife , and nodded [his]1722-the hermit head with satisfaction . “ It grows sharper , ”[1722-the hermit] [he]1722-the hermit said ; “ yes , it grows sharper . ”[1722-the hermit] [He]1722-the hermit took no note of the flight of time , but worked tranquilly on , entertaining [himself]1722-the hermit with [his]1722-the hermit thoughts , which broke out occasionally in articulate speech-- “ [[His]1722-the hermit father]306-his father wrought [us]4105-us evil , [he]306-his father destroyed [us]4105-us -- and is gone down into the eternal fires ! Yes , down into the eternal fires ! [He]1722-the hermit escaped [us]4105-us -- but it was [God]87-god ’s will , yes it was [God]87-god ’s will , [we]4105-us must not repine . But [he]1722-the hermit hath not escaped the fires ! No , [he]1722-the hermit hath not escaped the fires , the consuming , unpitying , remorseless fires -- and _ they _ are everlasting ! ”[1722-the hermit] And so [he]1722-the hermit wrought , and still wrought -- mumbling , chuckling a low rasping chuckle at times -- and at times breaking again into words-- “ It was [[his]1722-the hermit father]306-his father that did it all . [I]294-the king am but [an archangel]4075-an archangel ; but for [him]1722-the hermit [I]294-the king should be [pope]4093-pope ! ”[294-the king] [The King]294-the king stirred . [The hermit]1722-the hermit sprang noiselessly to the bedside , and went down upon [his]1722-the hermit knees , bending over the prostrate form with [his]1722-the hermit knife uplifted . [The boy]520-the boy stirred again ; [his]520-the boy eyes came open for an instant , but there was no speculation in them , [they]1782-they saw nothing ; the next moment [his]520-the boy tranquil breathing showed that [his]520-the boy sleep was sound once more . [The hermit]1722-the hermit watched and listened , for a time , keeping [his]1722-the hermit position and scarcely breathing ; then [he]1722-the hermit slowly lowered [his]1722-the hermit arms , and presently crept away , saying,-- “ It is long past midnight ; it is not best that [he]520-the boy should cry out , lest by accident [someone]4109-someone be passing . ”[1722-the hermit] [He]1722-the hermit glided about [[his]1722-the hermit hovel]1784-his hovel , gathering a rag here , a thong there , and another one yonder ; then [he]1722-the hermit returned , and by careful and gentle handling [he]1722-the hermit managed to tie [the King]294-the king ’s ankles together without waking [him]294-the king . Next [he]1722-the hermit essayed to tie the wrists ; [he]1722-the hermit made several attempts to cross them , but [the boy]520-the boy always drew one hand or the other away , just as the cord was ready to be applied ; but at last , when [the archangel]1761-the archangel was almost ready to despair , [the boy]520-the boy crossed [his]520-the boy hands [himself]520-the boy , and the next moment they were bound . Now a bandage was passed under [the sleeper]837-the sleeper ’s chin and brought up over [his]837-the sleeper head and tied fast -- and so softly , so gradually , and so deftly were the knots drawn together and compacted , that [the boy]520-the boy slept peacefully through it all without stirring . CHAPTER XXI . [Hendon]128-hendon to the rescue . [The old man]1756-the old man glided away , stooping , stealthy , cat - like , and brought the low bench . [He]1722-the hermit seated [himself]1722-the hermit upon it , half [his]1722-the hermit body in the dim and flickering light , and the other half in shadow ; and so , with [his]1722-the hermit craving eyes bent upon [the slumbering boy]836-the slumbering boy , [he]1722-the hermit kept [his]1722-the hermit patient vigil there , heedless of the drift of time , and softly whetted [his]1722-the hermit knife , and mumbled and chuckled ; and in aspect and attitude [he]1722-the hermit resembled nothing so much as a grizzly , monstrous spider , gloating over some hapless insect that lay bound and helpless in [his]1756-the old man web . After a long while , [the old man]1756-the old man , who was still gazing,--yet not seeing , [his]1756-the old man mind having settled into a dreamy abstraction,--observed , on a sudden , that [the boy]520-the boy ’s eyes were open ! wide open and staring!--staring up in frozen horror at the knife . The smile of [a gratified devil]1795-a gratified devil crept over [the old man]1756-the old man ’s face , and [he]1756-the old man said , without changing [his]1756-the old man attitude or [his]1756-the old man occupation-- “ [Son of [Henry the Eighth]174-henry the eighth]4110-son of henry the eighth , hast [thou]4111-thou prayed ? ”[1756-the old man] [The boy]520-the boy struggled helplessly in [his]520-the boy bonds , and at the same time forced a smothered sound through [his]520-the boy closed jaws , which [the hermit]1722-the hermit chose to interpret as an affirmative answer to [his]1722-the hermit question . “ Then pray again . Pray the prayer for [the dying]4112-the dying ! ”[1722-the hermit] A shudder shook [the boy]520-the boy ’s frame , and [his]520-the boy face blenched . Then [he]520-the boy struggled again to free [himself]520-the boy -- turning and twisting [himself]520-the boy this way and that ; tugging frantically , fiercely , desperately -- but uselessly -- to burst [his]520-the boy fetters ; and all the while [the old ogre]1800-the old ogre smiled down upon [him]520-the boy , and nodded [his]1800-the old ogre head , and placidly whetted [his]1800-the old ogre knife ; mumbling , from time to time , “ The moments are precious , they are few and precious -- pray the prayer for [the dying]4112-the dying ! ”[520-the boy] [The boy]520-the boy uttered a despairing groan , and ceased from [his]520-the boy struggles , panting . The tears came , then , and trickled , one after the other , down [his]520-the boy face ; but this piteous sight wrought no softening effect upon [the savage old man]1802-the savage old man . The dawn was coming now ; [the hermit]1722-the hermit observed it , and spoke up sharply , with a touch of nervous apprehension in [his]1722-the hermit voice-- “ [I]1722-the hermit may not indulge this ecstasy longer ! The night is already gone . It seems but a moment -- only a moment ; would it had endured a year ! Seed of [the Church]4114-the church ’s spoiler , close [thy]1722-the hermit perishing eyes , an ’ [thou]1722-the hermit fearest to look upon-- ”[1722-the hermit] The rest was lost in inarticulate mutterings . [The old man]1756-the old man sank upon [his]1756-the old man knees , [his]1756-the old man knife in [his]1756-the old man hand , and bent [himself]1756-the old man over [the moaning boy]1805-the moaning boy . Hark ! There was a sound of voices near [the cabin]1806-the cabin -- the knife dropped from [the hermit]1722-the hermit ’s hand ; [he]1722-the hermit cast a sheepskin over [the boy]520-the boy and started up , trembling . The sounds increased , and presently the voices became rough and angry ; then came blows , and cries for help ; then a clatter of swift footsteps , retreating . Immediately came a succession of thundering knocks upon the cabin door , followed by-- “ Hullo - o - o ! Open ! And despatch , in the name of [all the devils]4115-all the devils ! ”[128-hendon] Oh , this was the blessedest sound that had ever made music in [the King]294-the king ’s ears ; for it was [Miles Hendon]128-hendon ’s voice ! [The hermit]1722-the hermit , grinding [his]1722-the hermit teeth in impotent rage , moved swiftly out of the bedchamber , closing the door behind [him]1722-the hermit ; and straightway [the King]294-the king heard a talk , to this effect , proceeding from [the ‘ chapel’:--]1812-the ‘ chapel’:-- “ Homage and greeting , [reverend sir]4116-reverend sir ! Where is [the boy--_my _ boy]4117-the boy--_my _ boy ? ”[294-the king] “ [What boy]4118-what boy , [friend]3426-friend ? ”[294-the king] “ [What boy]4118-what boy ! Lie [me]294-the king no lies , [sir priest]4121-sir priest , play [me]294-the king no deceptions!--I am not in the humour for it . Near to [this place]4083-this place [I]294-the king caught [the scoundrels who [I]294-the king judged]4123-the scoundrels who i judged did steal [him]4117-the boy--_my _ boy from [me]294-the king , and [I]294-the king made [them]4123-the scoundrels who i judged confess ; [they]4123-the scoundrels who i judged said [he]4117-the boy--_my _ boy was at large again , and [they]4123-the scoundrels who i judged had tracked [him]4117-the boy--_my _ boy to [your]3426-friend door . [They]4123-the scoundrels who i judged showed [me]294-the king [his]4117-the boy--_my _ boy very footprints . Now palter no more ; for look [you]3426-friend , [holy sir]4124-holy sir , an ’ [thou]4125-thou produce [him]4117-the boy--_my _ boy not -- Where is [the boy]520-the boy ? ”[294-the king] “ [O good sir]4127-o good sir , peradventure [you]3426-friend mean [the ragged regal vagrant that tarried here the night]4128-the ragged regal vagrant that tarried here the night . If such as [you]3426-friend take an interest in such as [he]4117-the boy--_my _ boy , know , then , that [I]294-the king have sent [him]4117-the boy--_my _ boy of an errand . [He]4117-the boy--_my _ boy will be back anon . ”[294-the king] “ How soon ? How soon ? Come , waste not the time -- cannot [I]294-the king overtake [him]4117-the boy--_my _ boy ? How soon will [he]4117-the boy--_my _ boy be back ? ”[294-the king] “ [Thou]4125-thou need’st not stir ; [he]4117-the boy--_my _ boy will return quickly . ”[294-the king] “ So be it , then . [I]294-the king will try to wait . But stop!--_you _ sent [him]4117-the boy--_my _ boy of an errand?--you ! Verily this is a lie -- [he]4117-the boy--_my _ boy would not go . [He]4117-the boy--_my _ boy would pull [thy]4125-thou old beard , an ’ [thou]4125-thou didst offer [him]4117-the boy--_my _ boy such an insolence . [Thou]4125-thou hast lied , [friend]3426-friend ; [thou]4125-thou hast surely lied ! [He]4117-the boy--_my _ boy would not go for [thee]4125-thou , nor for [any man]4130-any man . ”[294-the king] “ For [any _ man_--no]4131-any _ man_--no ; haply not . But [I]294-the king am not [a man]3486-a man . ”[294-the king] “ _ What _ ! Now o ’ [God]87-god ’s name what art [thou]4125-thou , then ? ”[294-the king] “ It is a secret -- mark [thou]4125-thou reveal it not . [I]294-the king am [an archangel]4075-an archangel ! ”[294-the king] There was a tremendous ejaculation from [Miles Hendon]128-hendon -- not altogether unprofane -- followed by-- “ This doth well and truly account for [his]4117-the boy--_my _ boy complaisance ! Right well [I]294-the king knew [he]4117-the boy--_my _ boy would budge nor hand nor foot in the menial service of [any mortal]4134-any mortal ; but , [lord]524-lord , even [a king]390-a king must obey when [an archangel]4075-an archangel gives the word o ’ command ! Let [me--‘sh]4138-me--‘sh ! What noise was that ? ”[294-the king] All this while [the little King]1042-the little king had been yonder , alternately quaking with terror and trembling with hope ; and all the while , too , [he]1042-the little king had thrown all the strength [he]1042-the little king could into [his]1042-the little king anguished moanings , constantly expecting [them]1814-them to reach [Hendon]128-hendon ’s ear , but always realising , with bitterness , that [they]1814-them failed , or at least made no impression . So this last remark of [[his]1042-the little king servant]1815-his servant came as comes a reviving breath from [fresh fields]1816-fresh fields to the dying ; and [he]1042-the little king exerted [himself]1042-the little king once more , and with all [his]1042-the little king energy , just as [the hermit]1722-the hermit was saying-- “ Noise ? [I]1722-the hermit heard only the wind . ”[1722-the hermit] “ Mayhap it was . Yes , doubtless that was it . [I]1722-the hermit have been hearing it faintly all the -- there it is again ! It is not the wind ! What an odd sound ! Come , [we]4139-we will hunt it out ! ”[1722-the hermit] Now [the King]294-the king ’s joy was nearly insupportable . [His]294-the king tired lungs did [their]1814-them utmost -- and hopefully , too -- but the sealed jaws and the muffling sheepskin sadly crippled the effort . Then [the poor fellow]1819-the poor fellow ’s heart sank , to hear [the hermit]1722-the hermit say-- “ Ah , it came from without -- [I]1722-the hermit think from [the copse yonder]4140-the copse yonder . Come , [I]1722-the hermit will lead the way . ”[1722-the hermit] [The King]294-the king heard [the two]437-the two pass out , talking ; heard [their]437-the two footsteps die quickly away -- then [he]294-the king was alone with a boding , brooding , awful silence . It seemed an age till [he]294-the king heard the steps and voices approaching again -- and this time [he]294-the king heard an added sound,--the trampling of hoofs , apparently . Then [he]294-the king heard [Hendon]128-hendon say-- “ [I]128-hendon will not wait longer . [I]128-hendon _ can not _ wait longer . [He]1722-the hermit has lost [his]1722-the hermit way in [this thick wood]4141-this thick wood . Which direction took [he]1722-the hermit ? Quick -- point it out to [me]128-hendon . ”[128-hendon] “ [He]1722-the hermit -- but wait ; [I]128-hendon will go with [thee]128-hendon . ”[128-hendon] “ Good -- good ! Why , truly [thou]128-hendon art better than [thy]128-hendon looks . Marry [I]128-hendon do not think there ’s [not another archangel with so right a heart as thine]4142-not another archangel with so right a heart as thine . Wilt ride ? Wilt take [the wee donkey that ’s for [[my]128-hendon boy]3408-my boy]4143-the wee donkey that ’s for my boy , or wilt [thou]128-hendon fork [thy]128-hendon holy legs over this ill - conditioned slave of a mule that [I]128-hendon have provided for [myself?--and]1722-the hermit had been cheated in too , had [he]1722-the hermit cost but the indifferent sum of a month ’s usury on a brass farthing let to a tinker out of work . ”[128-hendon] “ No -- ride [thy]128-hendon mule , and lead [thine]128-hendon ass ; [I]128-hendon am surer on [mine]128-hendon own feet , and will walk . ”[128-hendon] “ Then prithee mind the little beast for [me]128-hendon while [I]128-hendon take [my]128-hendon life in [my]128-hendon hands and make what success [I]128-hendon may toward mounting the big one . ”[128-hendon] Then followed a confusion of kicks , cuffs , tramplings and plungings , accompanied by a thunderous intermingling of volleyed curses , and finally a bitter apostrophe to the mule , which must have broken its spirit , for hostilities seemed to cease from that moment . With unutterable misery [the fettered little King]1823-the fettered little king heard the voices and footsteps fade away and die out . All hope forsook [him]1823-the fettered little king , now , for the moment , and a dull despair settled down upon [his]1823-the fettered little king heart . “ [[My]1823-the fettered little king only friend]4145-my only friend is deceived and got rid of , ”[1823-the fettered little king] [he]1823-the fettered little king said ; “ [the hermit]1722-the hermit will return and-- ”[1823-the fettered little king] [He]1823-the fettered little king finished with a gasp ; and at once fell to struggling so frantically with [his]1823-the fettered little king bonds again , that [he]1823-the fettered little king shook off the smothering sheepskin . And now [he]1823-the fettered little king heard the door open ! The sound chilled [him]1823-the fettered little king to the marrow -- already [he]1823-the fettered little king seemed to feel the knife at [his]1823-the fettered little king throat . Horror made [him]1823-the fettered little king close [his]1823-the fettered little king eyes ; horror made [him]1823-the fettered little king open them again -- and before [him]1823-the fettered little king stood [John Canty]93-john canty and [Hugo]156-hugo ! [He]1823-the fettered little king would have said “ Thank [God]87-god ! ”[1823-the fettered little king] if [his]1823-the fettered little king jaws had been free . A moment or two later [his]1823-the fettered little king limbs were at liberty , and [[his]1823-the fettered little king captors]1824-his captors , each gripping [him]1823-the fettered little king by an arm , were hurrying [him]1823-the fettered little king with all speed through [the forest]1438-the forest . CHAPTER XXII . [A Victim of Treachery]1826-a victim of treachery . Once more ‘ [King Foo]175-king foo - foo [the First ’]1827-the first ’ was roving with [the tramps]1543-the tramps and [outlaws]1829-outlaws , a butt for [their]1830-their coarse jests and dull - witted railleries , and sometimes the victim of small spitefulness at the hands of [Canty]93-john canty and [Hugo]156-hugo when the Ruffler ’s back was turned . None but [Canty]93-john canty and [Hugo]156-hugo really disliked [him]1823-the fettered little king . [Some of [the others]3425-the others]1831-some of the others liked [him]1823-the fettered little king , and [all]654-all admired [his]1823-the fettered little king pluck and spirit . During two or three days , [Hugo]156-hugo , in whose ward and charge [the King]294-the king was , did what [he]156-hugo covertly could to make [the boy]520-the boy uncomfortable ; and at night , during the customary orgies , [he]156-hugo amused [the company]565-the company by putting small indignities upon [him]156-hugo -- always as if by accident . Twice [he]156-hugo stepped upon [the King]294-the king ’s toes -- accidentally -- and [the King]294-the king , as became [[his]294-the king royalty]1839-his royalty , was contemptuously unconscious of it and indifferent to it ; but the third time [Hugo]156-hugo entertained [himself]156-hugo in that way , [the King]294-the king felled [him]156-hugo to the ground with a cudgel , to the prodigious delight of [the tribe]1841-the tribe . [Hugo]156-hugo , consumed with anger and shame , sprang up , seized a cudgel , and came at [[his]156-hugo small adversary]1842-his small adversary in a fury . Instantly a ring was formed around [the gladiators]1843-the gladiators , and the betting and cheering began . But poor [Hugo]156-hugo stood no chance whatever . [His]156-hugo frantic and lubberly ‘ prentice - work found but a poor market for itself when pitted against an arm which had been trained by [the first masters of [Europe]61-europe]1844-the first masters of europe in single - stick , quarter - staff , and every art and trick of swordsmanship . [The little King]1042-the little king stood , alert but at graceful ease , and caught and turned aside the thick rain of blows with a facility and precision which set [the motley on - lookers]1846-the motley on - lookers wild with admiration ; and every now and then , when [his]294-the king practised eye detected an opening , and a lightning - swift rap upon [Hugo]156-hugo ’s head followed as a result , the storm of cheers and laughter that swept [the place]3615-the place was something wonderful to hear . At the end of fifteen minutes , [Hugo]156-hugo , [all battered , bruised , and the target for a pitiless bombardment of ridicule]1848-all battered , bruised , and the target for a pitiless bombardment of ridicule , slunk from [the field]1849-the field ; and [the unscathed hero of the fight]1850-the unscathed hero of the fight was seized and borne aloft upon the shoulders of [the joyous rabble]1851-the joyous rabble to the place of honour beside the Ruffler , where with vast ceremony [he]156-hugo was crowned [King of the Game - Cocks]1852-king of the game - cocks ; [his]156-hugo meaner title being at the same time solemnly cancelled and annulled , and a decree of banishment from [the gang]1491-the gang pronounced against [any who should thenceforth utter it]1854-any who should thenceforth utter it . All attempts to make [the King]294-the king serviceable to [the troop]1551-the troop had failed . [He]294-the king had stubbornly refused to act ; moreover , [he]294-the king was always trying to escape . [He]294-the king had been thrust into [an unwatched kitchen]1857-an unwatched kitchen , the first day of [his]294-the king return ; [he]294-the king not only came forth empty - handed , but tried to rouse [the housemates]1858-the housemates . [He]294-the king was sent out with a tinker to help [him]294-the king at [his]294-the king work ; [he]294-the king would not work ; moreover , [he]294-the king threatened [the tinker]1859-the tinker with [his]294-the king own soldering - iron ; and finally both [Hugo]156-hugo and [the tinker]1859-the tinker found [their]1861-their hands full with the mere matter of keeping [his]156-hugo from getting away . [He]294-the king delivered the thunders of [[his]294-the king royalty]1839-his royalty upon the heads of all who hampered [his]294-the king liberties or tried to force [him]294-the king to service . [He]294-the king was sent out , in [Hugo]156-hugo ’s charge , in company with [a slatternly woman]1863-a slatternly woman and [a diseased baby]1864-a diseased baby , to beg ; but the result was not encouraging -- [he]294-the king declined to plead for [the mendicants]1865-the mendicants , or be a party to [their]1865-the mendicants cause in any way .
