The first thing that falleth under [your]2643-you eye will be the Great Seal -- fetch it hither . ”[2642-this foolish lad] [All the company]2645-all the company wondered at this speech , and wondered still more to see [the little mendicant]2646-the little mendicant pick out [this peer]2647-this peer without hesitancy or apparent fear of mistake , and call [him]2647-this peer by name with such a placidly convincing air of having known [him]2647-this peer all [his]2647-this peer life . [The peer]2648-the peer was almost surprised into obeying . [He]2648-the peer even made a movement as if to go , but quickly recovered [his]2648-the peer tranquil attitude and confessed [his]2648-the peer blunder with a blush . [Tom Canty]90-tom turned upon [him]2648-the peer and said , sharply-- “ Why dost [thou]90-tom hesitate ? Hast not heard [the King]294-the king ’s command ? Go ! ”[90-tom] [The Lord St. John]109-lord st. john made a deep obeisance -- and it was observed that it was [a significantly cautious and non - committal one]2649-a significantly cautious and non - committal one , it not being delivered at either of [the kings]1399-the kings , but at [the neutral ground about half -]2651-the neutral ground about half - way between the two -- and took [his]109-lord st. john leave . Now began a movement of the gorgeous particles of that official group which was slow , scarcely perceptible , and yet steady and persistent -- a movement such as is observed in a kaleidoscope that is turned slowly , whereby the components of one splendid cluster fall away and join [themselves]2652-themselves to another -- a movement which , little by little , in the present case , dissolved [the glittering crowd that stood about [Tom Canty]90-tom and clustered it together again in [the neighbourhood of [the new - comer]2613-the new - comer]2654-the neighbourhood of the new - comer]2653-the glittering crowd that stood about tom canty and clustered it together again in the neighbourhood of the new - comer . [Tom Canty]90-tom stood almost alone . Now ensued a brief season of deep suspense and waiting -- during which even the few faint hearts still remaining near [Tom Canty]90-tom gradually scraped together courage enough to glide , one by one , over to [the majority]2656-the majority . So at last [Tom Canty]90-tom , in [his]90-tom royal robes and jewels , stood wholly alone and isolated from [the world]1021-the world , a conspicuous figure , occupying an eloquent vacancy . Now [the Lord St. John]109-lord st. john was seen returning . As [he]109-lord st. john advanced up the mid - aisle the interest was so intense that the low murmur of conversation in the great assemblage died out and was succeeded by a profound hush , a breathless stillness , through which [his]109-lord st. john footfalls pulsed with a dull and distant sound . Every eye was fastened upon [him]109-lord st. john as [he]109-lord st. john moved along . [He]109-lord st. john reached [the platform]2532-the platform , paused a moment , then moved toward [Tom Canty]90-tom with a deep obeisance , and said-- “ [Sire]3212-sire , the Seal is not there ! ”[109-lord st. john] [A mob]2659-a mob does not melt away from the presence of a plague - patient with more haste than the band of [pallid and terrified courtiers]2660-pallid and terrified courtiers melted away from the presence of [the shabby little claimant of the Crown]2661-the shabby little claimant of the crown . In a moment [he]90-tom stood all alone , without [friend or supporter]2662-friend or supporter , [a target upon which was concentrated a bitter fire of scornful and angry looks]2663-a target upon which was concentrated a bitter fire of scornful and angry looks . [The Lord Protector]2359-the lord protector called out fiercely-- “ Cast [the beggar]4483-the beggar into [the street]853-the street , and scourge [him]4483-the beggar through [the town]1411-the town -- [the paltry knave]4486-the paltry knave is worth no more consideration ! ”[2359-the lord protector] [Officers of the guard]2665-officers of the guard sprang forward to obey , but [Tom Canty]90-tom waved [them]2665-officers of the guard off and said-- “ Back ! Whoso touches [him]4483-the beggar perils [his]4483-the beggar life ! ”[90-tom] [The Lord Protector]186-the lord protector was perplexed in the last degree . [He]186-the lord protector said to [the Lord St. John--]199-the lord st. john-- “ Searched [you]199-the lord st. john-- well?--but it boots not to ask that . It doth seem passing strange . Little things , trifles , slip out of [one]3093-one ’s ken , and [one]3093-one does not think it matter for surprise ; but how so bulky a thing as the Seal of [England]2-england can vanish away and [no man]4489-no man be able to get track of it again -- a massy golden disk-- ”[186-the lord protector] [Tom Canty]90-tom , with beaming eyes , sprang forward and shouted-- “ Hold , that is enough ! Was it round?--and thick?--and had it letters and devices graved upon [it?--yes]4490-it?--yes ? Oh , _ now _ [I]186-the lord protector know what this Great Seal is that there ’s been such worry and pother about . An ’ [ye]199-the lord st. john-- had described it to [me]186-the lord protector , [ye]199-the lord st. john-- could have had it three weeks ago . Bethink [thee]199-the lord st. john-- , [[my]90-tom King]3798-my king -- spur [thy]199-the lord st. john-- memory -- it was the last , the very _ last _ thing [thou]199-the lord st. john-- didst that day before [thou]199-the lord st. john-- didst rush forth from [the palace]425-the palace , clothed in [my]90-tom rags , to punish [the soldier that insulted [me]90-tom]4496-the soldier that insulted me . ”[90-tom] A silence ensued , undisturbed by a movement or a whisper , and all eyes were fixed upon [the new - comer]2613-the new - comer , who stood , with bent head and corrugated brow , groping in [his]2613-the new - comer memory among [a thronging multitude of valueless recollections for one single little elusive fact , which , found]2668-a thronging multitude of valueless recollections for one single little elusive fact , which , found , would seat [him]2613-the new - comer upon a throne -- unfound , would leave [him]2613-the new - comer as [he]2613-the new - comer was , for good and all -- [a pauper]3411-a pauper and [an outcast]848-an outcast . Moment after moment passed -- the moments built themselves into minutes -- still [the boy]520-the boy struggled silently on , and gave no sign . But at last [he]520-the boy heaved a sigh , shook [his]520-the boy head slowly , and said , with a trembling lip and in a despondent voice-- “ [I]520-the boy call the scene back -- all of it -- but the Seal hath no place in it . ”[520-the boy] [He]520-the boy paused , then looked up , and said with gentle dignity , “ [[My]520-the boy lords]4497-my lords and [gentlemen]3872-gentlemen , if [ye]3872-gentlemen will rob [[your]3872-gentlemen rightful sovereign]4499-your rightful sovereign of [his]4499-your rightful sovereign own for lack of this evidence which [he]4499-your rightful sovereign is not able to furnish , [I]520-the boy may not stay [ye]3872-gentlemen , being powerless . But-- ”[520-the boy] “ Oh , folly , oh , madness , [[my]90-tom King]3798-my king ! ”[90-tom] cried [Tom Canty]90-tom , in a panic , “ wait!--think ! Do not give up!--the cause is not lost ! Nor _ shall _ be , neither ! List to what [I]90-tom say -- follow every word -- [I]90-tom am going to bring that morning back again , [every hap]4501-every hap just as it happened . [We]4502-we talked -- [I]90-tom told [you]3872-gentlemen of [[my]90-tom sisters]3206-my sisters , [Nan]92-nan and [Bet]189-elizabeth of york -- ah , yes , [you]3872-gentlemen remember that ; and about [mine]90-tom old grandam -- and the rough games of [the lads of [Offal Court]3091-offal court]4504-the lads of offal court -- yes , [you]3872-gentlemen remember these things also ; very well , follow [me]90-tom still , [you]3872-gentlemen shall recall everything . [You]3872-gentlemen gave [me]90-tom food and drink , and did with princely courtesy send away [the servants]428-the servants , so that [my]90-tom low breeding might not shame [me]90-tom before [them]428-the servants -- ah , yes , this also [you]3872-gentlemen remember . ”[90-tom] As [Tom]90-tom checked off [his]90-tom details , and [the other boy]2672-the other boy nodded [his]2672-the other boy head in recognition of [them]2673-them , [the great audience]2674-the great audience and [the officials]2675-the officials stared in puzzled wonderment ; the tale sounded like true history , yet how could this impossible conjunction between [a prince]392-a prince and [a beggar - boy]2677-a beggar - boy have come about ? Never was [a company of people]2678-a company of people so perplexed , so interested , and so stupefied , before . “ For a jest , [[my]2679-the ragged claimant prince]3184-my prince , [we]4508-we did exchange garments . Then [we]4508-we stood before a mirror ; and so alike were [we]4508-we that [both]1909-both said it seemed as if there had been no change made -- yes , [you]3872-gentlemen remember that . Then [you]3872-gentlemen noticed that [the soldier]415-the soldier had hurt [my]2679-the ragged claimant hand -- look ! here it is , [I]2679-the ragged claimant can not yet even write with it , the fingers are so stiff . At this [[your]3872-gentlemen Highness]3271-your highness sprang up , vowing vengeance upon [that soldier]4512-that soldier , and ran towards the door -- [you]3872-gentlemen passed a table -- that thing [you]3872-gentlemen call the Seal lay on that table -- [you]3872-gentlemen snatched it up and looked eagerly about , as if for a place to hide it -- [your]3872-gentlemen eye caught sight of-- ”[2679-the ragged claimant] “ There , ’ tis sufficient!--and [the good God]3683-the good god be thanked ! ”[2679-the ragged claimant] exclaimed [the ragged claimant]2679-the ragged claimant , in a mighty excitement . “ Go , [[my]2679-the ragged claimant good St. [John]109-lord st. john]4514-my good st. john -- in an arm - piece of the Milanese armour that hangs on the wall , [thou’lt]4515-thou’lt find the Seal ! ”[2679-the ragged claimant] “ Right , [[my]90-tom King]3798-my king ! right ! ”[90-tom] cried [Tom Canty]90-tom ; “ _ Now _ the sceptre of [England]2-england is thine own ; and it were better for [him]109-lord st. john that would dispute it that [he]109-lord st. john had been born dumb ! Go , [[my]90-tom [Lord St. John]109-lord st. john]4475-my lord st. john , give [thy]2680-the whole assemblage feet wings ! ”[90-tom] [The whole assemblage]2680-the whole assemblage was on its feet now , and well - nigh out of [its]2680-the whole assemblage mind with uneasiness , apprehension , and consuming excitement . On the floor and on the platform a deafening buzz of frantic conversation burst forth , and for some time [nobody]650-nobody knew anything or heard anything or was interested in anything but what [[his]90-tom neighbour]3105-his neighbour was shouting into [his]90-tom ear , or [he]90-tom was shouting into [[his]90-tom neighbour]3105-his neighbour ’s ear . Time -- [nobody]650-nobody knew how much of it -- swept by unheeded and unnoted . At last a sudden hush fell upon [the house]292-the house , and in the same moment [St. John]109-lord st. john appeared upon [the platform]2532-the platform , and held the Great Seal aloft in [his]109-lord st. john hand . Then such a shout went up-- “ Long live [the true King]2340-the true king ! ”[109-lord st. john] For five minutes the air quaked with shouts and the crash of musical instruments , and was white with a storm of waving handkerchiefs ; and through it all [a ragged lad]2687-a ragged lad , [the most conspicuous figure in [England]2-england]2688-the most conspicuous figure in england , stood , flushed and happy and proud , in the centre of [the spacious platform]2689-the spacious platform , with [the great vassals of [the kingdom]2242-the kingdom]2690-the great vassals of the kingdom kneeling around [him]2687-a ragged lad . Then all rose , and [Tom Canty]90-tom cried out-- “ Now , O [[my]90-tom King]3798-my king , take these regal garments back , and give [poor [Tom]90-tom]4520-poor tom , [[thy]90-tom servant]4521-thy servant , [his]90-tom shreds and remnants again . ”[90-tom] [The Lord Protector]2359-the lord protector spoke up-- “ Let the small varlet be stripped and flung into [the Tower]3064-the tower . ”[2359-the lord protector] But [the new King]4381-the new king , [the true King]2340-the true king , said-- “ [I]4381-the new king will not have it so . But for [him]90-tom [I]4381-the new king had not got [my]4381-the new king crown again -- [none]3179-none shall lay a hand upon [him]90-tom to harm [him]90-tom . And as for [thee]4524-thee , [[my]4381-the new king good uncle]4525-my good uncle , [[my]4381-the new king Lord Protector]4526-my lord protector , this conduct of thine is not grateful toward [this poor lad]4187-this poor lad , for [I]4381-the new king hear [he]90-tom hath made [thee]4524-thee [a duke”--the[4381-the new king] Protector]4528-a duke”--the protector blushed--“yet [he]90-tom was not [a king]390-a king ; wherefore what is [thy]90-tom fine title worth now ? To - morrow [you]4524-thee shall sue to [me]2695-me , _ through [him]90-tom _ , for its confirmation , else [no duke]4530-no duke , but [a simple earl]4531-a simple earl , shalt [thou]4524-thee remain . ”[2695-me] Under this rebuke , [his]2695-me Grace [the Duke of Somerset]2696-the duke of somerset retired a little from the front for the moment . [The King]294-the king turned to [Tom]90-tom , and said [kindly--“My poor boy]4532-kindly--“my poor boy , how was it that [you]90-tom could remember where [I]294-the king hid the Seal when [I]294-the king could not remember it [myself]294-the king ? ”[294-the king] “ Ah , [[my]294-the king King]3798-my king , that was easy , since [I]294-the king used it divers days . ”[294-the king] “ Used it -- yet could not explain where it was ? ”[294-the king] “ [I]294-the king did not know it was _ that _ [they]4534-they wanted . [They]4534-they did not describe it , [[your]294-the king Majesty]3215-your majesty . ”[294-the king] “ Then how used [you]90-tom it ? ”[294-the king] The red blood began to steal up into [Tom]90-tom ’s cheeks , and [he]90-tom dropped [his]90-tom eyes and was silent . “ Speak up , [good lad]4536-good lad , and fear nothing , ”[294-the king] said [the King]294-the king . “ How used [you]90-tom [the Great Seal of [England]2-england]4537-the great seal of england ? ”[294-the king] [Tom]90-tom stammered a moment , in a pathetic confusion , then got it out-- “ To crack nuts with ! ”[3366-poor child] [Poor child]3366-poor child , the avalanche of laughter that greeted this nearly swept [him]90-tom off [his]90-tom feet . But if a doubt remained in any mind that [Tom Canty]90-tom was not [the King of [England]2-england]4051-the king of england and familiar with the august appurtenances of [royalty]436-royalty , this reply disposed of it utterly . Meantime the sumptuous robe of state had been removed from [Tom]90-tom ’s shoulders to [the King]294-the king ’s , whose rags were effectually hidden from sight under it . Then the coronation ceremonies were resumed ; [the true King]2340-the true king was anointed and the crown set upon [his]2340-the true king head , whilst cannon thundered the news to [the city]370-the city , and all [London]1-london seemed to rock with applause . CHAPTER XXXIII . [Edward]87-god as [King]3155-king . [Miles Hendon]128-hendon was picturesque enough before [he]128-hendon got into the riot on [London Bridge]4-london bridge -- [he]128-hendon was more so when [he]128-hendon got out of it . [He]128-hendon had but little money when [he]128-hendon got in , none at all when [he]128-hendon got out . The pickpockets had stripped [him]128-hendon of [his]128-hendon last farthing . But no matter , so [he]128-hendon found [[his]128-hendon boy]2706-his boy . Being [a soldier]3551-a soldier , [he]128-hendon did not go at [his]128-hendon task in a random way , but set to work , first of all , to arrange [his]128-hendon campaign . What would [the boy]520-the boy naturally do ? Where would [he]520-the boy naturally go ? Well -- argued [Miles]128-hendon -- [he]520-the boy would naturally go to [[his]520-the boy former haunts]1415-his former haunts , for that is the instinct of unsound minds , when homeless and forsaken , as well as of [sound ones]2710-sound ones . Whereabouts were [[his]520-the boy former haunts]1415-his former haunts ? [His]520-the boy rags , taken together with [the low villain who seemed to know [him]520-the boy and who even claimed to be [[his]520-the boy father]306-his father]2712-the low villain who seemed to know him and who even claimed to be his father , indicated that [[his]520-the boy home]2058-his home was in one or another of [the poorest and meanest districts of [London]1-london]2715-the poorest and meanest districts of london . Would the search for [him]520-the boy be difficult , or long ? No , it was likely to be easy and brief . [He]520-the boy would not hunt for [the boy]520-the boy , [he]520-the boy would hunt for [a crowd]2717-a crowd ; in the centre of [a big crowd or a little one]2718-a big crowd or a little one , sooner or later , [he]520-the boy should find [[his]520-the boy poor little friend]2719-his poor little friend , sure ; and [the mangy mob]2720-the mangy mob would be entertaining [itself]2720-the mangy mob with pestering and aggravating [the boy]520-the boy , who would be proclaiming [himself]520-the boy [King]3155-king , as usual . Then [Miles Hendon]128-hendon would cripple [some of [those people]2724-those people]2723-some of those people , and carry off [[his]128-hendon little ward]2725-his little ward , and comfort and cheer [him]520-the boy with loving words , and [the two]437-the two would never be separated any more . So [Miles]128-hendon started on [his]128-hendon quest . Hour after hour [he]128-hendon tramped through [back alleys]2456-back alleys and [squalid streets]2728-squalid streets , seeking [groups]2729-groups and [crowds]2730-crowds , and finding no end of [them]2731-them , but never any sign of [the boy]520-the boy . This greatly surprised [him]128-hendon , but did not discourage [him]128-hendon . To [his]128-hendon notion , there was nothing the matter with [his]128-hendon plan of campaign ; the only miscalculation about it was that the campaign was becoming a lengthy one , whereas [he]128-hendon had expected it to be short . When daylight arrived , at last , [he]128-hendon had made many a mile , and canvassed many [a crowd]2717-a crowd , but the only result was that [he]128-hendon was tolerably tired , rather hungry and very sleepy . [He]128-hendon wanted some breakfast , but there was no way to get it . To beg for it did not occur to [him]128-hendon ; as to pawning [his]128-hendon sword , [he]128-hendon would as soon have thought of parting with [his]128-hendon honour ; [he]128-hendon could spare some of [his]128-hendon clothes -- yes , but [one]3093-one could as easily find [a customer]2735-a customer for a disease as for such clothes . At noon [he]128-hendon was still tramping -- among the rabble which followed after the royal procession , now ; for [he]128-hendon argued that this regal display would attract [[his]128-hendon little lunatic]2736-his little lunatic powerfully . [He]128-hendon followed the pageant through all [its]2737-its devious windings about [London]1-london , and all the way to [Westminster]15-westminster and [the Abbey]72-the abbey . [He]128-hendon drifted here and there amongst the multitudes that were massed in [the vicinity]2738-the vicinity for a weary long time , baffled and perplexed , and finally wandered off , thinking , and trying to contrive some way to better [his]128-hendon plan of campaign . By - and - by , when [he]128-hendon came to [himself]128-hendon out of [his]128-hendon musings , [he]128-hendon discovered that [the town]1411-the town was far behind [him]128-hendon and that the day was growing old . [He]128-hendon was near [the river]3104-the river , and in [the country]1030-the country ; it was [a region of [fine rural seats]2743-fine rural seats]2742-a region of fine rural seats -- not [the sort of district to welcome clothes like [his]128-hendon]2744-the sort of district to welcome clothes like his . It was not at all cold ; so [he]128-hendon stretched [himself]128-hendon on the ground in the lee of a hedge to rest and think . Drowsiness presently began to settle upon [his]128-hendon senses ; the faint and far - off boom of cannon was wafted to [his]128-hendon ear , and [he]128-hendon said to [himself]128-hendon , “ [The new King]4381-the new king is crowned , ”[128-hendon] and straightway fell asleep . [He]128-hendon had not slept or rested , before , for more than thirty hours . [He]128-hendon did not wake again until near the middle of the next morning . [He]128-hendon got up , lame , stiff , and half famished , washed [himself]128-hendon in [the river]3104-the river , stayed [his]128-hendon stomach with a pint or two of water , and trudged off toward [Westminster]15-westminster , grumbling at [himself]128-hendon for having wasted so much time . [Hunger]200-hunger helped [him]128-hendon to a new plan , now ; [he]128-hendon would try to get speech with [old Sir Humphrey Marlow]147-humphrey and borrow a few marks , and -- but that was enough of a plan for the present ; it would be time enough to enlarge it when this first stage should be accomplished . Toward eleven o’clock [he]128-hendon approached [the palace]425-the palace ; and although [a host of showy people]2747-a host of showy people were about [him]128-hendon , moving in the same direction , [he]128-hendon was not inconspicuous -- [his]128-hendon costume took care of that . [He]128-hendon watched [these people]1325-these people ’s faces narrowly , hoping to find [a charitable one whose possessor]2749-a charitable one whose possessor might be willing to carry [his]128-hendon name to [the old lieutenant]2750-the old lieutenant -- as to trying to get into [the palace]425-the palace [himself]128-hendon , that was simply out of the question . Presently [[our]2752-our whipping - boy]2753-our whipping - boy passed [him]128-hendon , then wheeled about and scanned [his]128-hendon figure well , saying to [himself]2753-our whipping - boy , “ An ’ that is not the very vagabond [[his]128-hendon Majesty]3254-his majesty is in such a worry about , then am [I]2753-our whipping - boy an ass -- though belike [I]2753-our whipping - boy was that before . [He]128-hendon answereth the description to a rag -- that [God]87-god should make two such would be to cheapen miracles by wasteful repetition . [I]2753-our whipping - boy would [I]2753-our whipping - boy could contrive an excuse to speak with [him]128-hendon . ”[2753-our whipping - boy] [Miles Hendon]128-hendon saved [him]128-hendon the trouble ; for [he]128-hendon turned about , then , as [a man]3486-a man generally will when [somebody]2755-somebody mesmerises [him]3486-a man by gazing hard at [him]3486-a man from behind ; and observing a strong interest in [the boy]520-the boy ’s eyes , [he]128-hendon stepped toward [him]520-the boy and said-- “ [You]520-the boy have just come out from [the palace]425-the palace ; do [you]520-the boy belong [there]3216-there ? ”[128-hendon] “ Yes , [your]520-the boy worship . ”[128-hendon] “ Know [you]520-the boy [Sir Humphrey Marlow]147-humphrey ? ”[520-the boy] [The boy]520-the boy started , and said to [himself]520-the boy , “ [Lord]4542-lord ! [[mine]520-the boy old departed father]4543-mine old departed father ! ”[520-the boy] Then [he]520-the boy answered aloud , “ Right well , [your]520-the boy worship . ”[520-the boy] “ Good -- is [he]4543-mine old departed father within ? ”[128-hendon] “ Yes , ”[520-the boy] said [the boy]520-the boy ; and added , to [himself]520-the boy , “ within [his]4543-mine old departed father grave . ”[520-the boy] “ Might [I]128-hendon crave [your]520-the boy favour to carry [my]128-hendon name to [him]4543-mine old departed father , and say [I]128-hendon beg to say a word in [his]4543-mine old departed father ear ? ”[128-hendon] “ [I]128-hendon will despatch the business right willingly , [fair sir]4544-fair sir . ”[128-hendon] “ Then say [Miles Hendon]128-hendon , [son of [Sir Richard]136-sir richard]4545-son of sir richard , is here without -- [I]520-the boy shall be greatly bounden to [you]520-the boy , [[my]520-the boy good lad]4546-my good lad . ”[520-the boy] [The boy]520-the boy looked disappointed . “ [The King]294-the king did not name [him]4543-mine old departed father so , ”[520-the boy] [he]520-the boy said to [himself]520-the boy ; “ but it mattereth not , this is [[his]294-the king twin brother]4548-his twin brother , and can give [[his]294-the king Majesty]3254-his majesty news of t’other Sir - Odds - and - Ends , [I]520-the boy warrant . ”[520-the boy] So [he]520-the boy said to [Miles]128-hendon , “ Step in there a moment , [good sir]3747-good sir , and wait till [I]520-the boy bring [you]128-hendon word . ”[520-the boy] [Hendon]128-hendon retired to [the place indicated]2760-the place indicated -- [it]2760-the place indicated was a recess sunk in [the palace]425-the palace wall , with a stone bench in it -- a shelter for [sentinels in bad weather]2762-sentinels in bad weather . [He]128-hendon had hardly seated [himself]128-hendon when [some halberdiers]2763-some halberdiers , in charge of [an officer]2764-an officer , passed by . [The officer]1341-the officer saw [him]128-hendon , halted [[his]1341-the officer men]2766-his men , and commanded [Hendon]128-hendon to come forth . [He]128-hendon obeyed , and was promptly arrested as [a suspicious character prowling within [the precincts of [the palace]425-the palace]2768-the precincts of the palace]2767-a suspicious character prowling within the precincts of the palace . Things began to look ugly . [Poor Miles]128-hendon was going to explain , but [the officer]1341-the officer roughly silenced [him]128-hendon , and ordered [[his]1341-the officer men]2766-his men to disarm [him]128-hendon and search [him]128-hendon . “ [God of [his]1341-the officer mercy]4266-god of his mercy grant that [they]2766-his men find somewhat , ”[128-hendon] said [poor [Miles]128-hendon]2772-poor miles ; “ [I]128-hendon have searched enow , and failed , yet is [my]128-hendon need greater than [theirs]2766-his men . ”[128-hendon] Nothing was found but a document . [The officer]1341-the officer tore it open , and [Hendon]128-hendon smiled when [he]128-hendon recognised the ‘ pot - hooks ’ made by [[his]128-hendon lost little friend]2774-his lost little friend that black day at [Hendon Hall]41-hendon hall . [The officer]1341-the officer ’s face grew dark as [he]1341-the officer read the English paragraph , and [Miles]128-hendon blenched to the opposite colour as [he]128-hendon listened . “ [Another new claimant of the Crown]4552-another new claimant of the crown ! ”[1341-the officer] cried [the officer]1341-the officer . “ Verily [they]2766-his men breed like rabbits , to - day . Seize [the rascal]4553-the rascal , [men]649-men , and see [ye]649-men keep [him]4553-the rascal fast whilst [I]1341-the officer convey this precious paper within and send it to [the King]294-the king . ”[1341-the officer] [He]1341-the officer hurried away , leaving [the prisoner]1342-the prisoner in the grip of [the halberdiers]2778-the halberdiers . “ Now is [my]128-hendon evil luck ended at last , ”[128-hendon] muttered [Hendon]128-hendon , “ for [I]128-hendon shall dangle at a rope ’s end for a certainty , by reason of that bit of writing . And what will become of [[my]128-hendon poor lad!--ah]4556-my poor lad!--ah , only [the good God]3683-the good god knoweth . ”[128-hendon] By - and - by [he]128-hendon saw [the officer]1341-the officer coming again , in a great hurry ; so [he]128-hendon plucked [his]128-hendon courage together , purposing to meet [his]128-hendon trouble as became [a man]3486-a man . [The officer]1341-the officer ordered [the men]1609-the men to loose [the prisoner]1342-the prisoner and return [his]1341-the officer sword to [him]1342-the prisoner ; then bowed respectfully , and said-- “ Please [you]128-hendon , [sir]3053-sir , to follow [me]1341-the officer . ”[1341-the officer] [Hendon]128-hendon followed , saying to [himself]128-hendon , “ An ’ [I]128-hendon were not travelling to death and judgment , and so must needs economise in sin , [I]128-hendon would throttle [this knave]4559-this knave for [his]4559-this knave mock courtesy . ”[128-hendon] [The two]437-the two traversed [a populous court]2785-a populous court , and arrived at [the grand entrance of [the palace]425-the palace]2786-the grand entrance of the palace , where [the officer , with another bow]2788-the officer , with another bow , delivered [Hendon]128-hendon into the hands of a gorgeous official , who received [him]128-hendon with profound respect and led [him]128-hendon forward through [a great hall]2789-a great hall , lined on both sides with rows of splendid flunkeys ( who made reverential obeisance as [the two passed along]2790-the two passed along , but fell into death - throes of silent laughter at [[our]2791-our stately scarecrow]2792-our stately scarecrow the moment [his]128-hendon back was turned ) , and up a broad staircase , among [flocks of fine folk]2793-flocks of fine folk , and finally conducted [him]128-hendon into [a vast room]2794-a vast room , clove a passage for [him]128-hendon through [the assembled nobility of [England]2-england]2795-the assembled nobility of england , then made a bow , reminded [him]128-hendon to take [his]128-hendon hat off , and left [him]128-hendon standing in the middle of [the room]507-the room , a mark for all eyes , for plenty of indignant frowns , and for a sufficiency of amused and derisive smiles . [Miles Hendon]128-hendon was entirely bewildered . There sat [the young King]2308-the young king , under a canopy of state , five steps away , with [his]2308-the young king head bent down and aside , speaking with a sort of human bird of paradise -- [a duke]3892-a duke , maybe . [Hendon]128-hendon observed to [himself]128-hendon that it was hard enough to be sentenced to death in the full vigour of life , without having this peculiarly public humiliation added . [He]128-hendon wished [the King]294-the king would hurry about it -- [some of [the gaudy people near by]2801-the gaudy people near by]2800-some of the gaudy people near by were becoming pretty offensive . At this moment [the King]294-the king raised [his]294-the king head slightly , and [Hendon]128-hendon caught a good view of [his]294-the king face . The sight nearly took [his]128-hendon breath away!--He stood gazing at the fair young face like one transfixed ; then presently ejaculated-- “ [Lo]133-lo , [the Lord of [the Kingdom of Dreams]3597-the kingdom of dreams and Shadows on [his]294-the king throne]4560-the lord of the kingdom of dreams and shadows on his throne ! ”[128-hendon] [He]128-hendon muttered some broken sentences , still gazing and marvelling ; then turned [his]128-hendon eyes around and about , scanning [the gorgeous throng]2803-the gorgeous throng and [the splendid saloon]2804-the splendid saloon , murmuring , “ But these are _ real_--verily these are _ real_--surely it is not a dream . ”[128-hendon] [He]128-hendon stared at [the King]294-the king again -- and thought , “ _ Is _ it a dream . . . or _ is _ [he]294-the king [the veritable Sovereign of [England]2-england]4562-the veritable sovereign of england , and not the friendless poor [Tom o ’]90-tom Bedlam [I]294-the king took [him]294-the king for -- who shall solve [me]294-the king this riddle ? ”[294-the king] A sudden idea flashed in [his]128-hendon eye , and [he]128-hendon strode to the wall , gathered up a chair , brought it back , planted it on the floor , and sat down in it ! A buzz of indignation broke out , a rough hand was laid upon [him]128-hendon and a voice exclaimed-- “ Up , [thou mannerless clown]4563-thou mannerless clown ! would’st sit in the presence of [the King]294-the king ? ”[128-hendon] The disturbance attracted [[his]128-hendon Majesty]3254-his majesty ’s attention , who stretched forth [his]128-hendon hand and cried out-- “ Touch [him]294-the king not , it is [his]294-the king right ! ”[2807-the throng] [The throng]2807-the throng fell back , stupefied . [The King]294-the king went on-- “ Learn [ye]4565-ye all , [ladies]254-ladies , [lords]343-lords , and [gentlemen]3872-gentlemen , that this is [[my]294-the king trusty and well - beloved servant]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant , [Miles Hendon]128-hendon , who interposed [his]128-hendon good sword and saved [[his]128-hendon prince]4427-his prince from bodily harm and possible death -- and for this [he]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant is [a knight]930-a knight , by [the King]294-the king ’s voice . Also learn , that for a higher service , in that [he]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant saved [his]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant sovereign stripes and shame , taking these upon [himself]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant , [he]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant is [a peer of [England]2-england]4573-a peer of england , [Earl of [Kent]40-kent]4574-earl of kent , and shall have gold and lands meet for the dignity . More -- the privilege which [he]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant hath just exercised is [his]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant by royal grant ; for [we]4575-we have ordained that [the chiefs of [his]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant line]4576-the chiefs of his line shall have and hold the right to sit in the presence of [the Majesty of]4577-the majesty of [England]2-england henceforth , age after age , so long as the crown shall endure . Molest [him]4569-my trusty and well - beloved servant not . ”[294-the king] [Two persons , who , through delay]2809-two persons , who , through delay , had only arrived from [the country]1030-the country during this morning , and had now been in [this room]4355-this room only five minutes , stood listening to these words and looking at [the King]294-the king , then at [the scarecrow]2813-the scarecrow , then at [the King]294-the king again , in a sort of torpid bewilderment . These were [Sir Hugh]132-hugh and [the Lady Edith]137-the lady edith . But [the new Earl]2815-the new earl did not see [them]2809-two persons , who , through delay . [He]2815-the new earl was still staring at [the monarch]1136-the monarch , in a dazed way , and muttering-- “ Oh , body o ’ [me]2815-the new earl ! _ this _ [[my]2815-the new earl pauper]4578-my pauper ! This [[my]2815-the new earl lunatic]4579-my lunatic ! This is [he]4579-my lunatic whom _ [I]2815-the new earl _ would show what grandeur was , in [[my]2815-the new earl house of [seventy rooms]4230-seventy rooms and seven - and - twenty [servants]363-servants]4580-my house of seventy rooms and seven - and - twenty servants ! This is [he]4579-my lunatic who had never known [aught but rags for raiment , kicks for comfort , and offal for diet]4583-aught but rags for raiment , kicks for comfort , and offal for diet ! This is [he]4579-my lunatic whom _ [I]2815-the new earl _ adopted and would make respectable ! Would God [I]2815-the new earl had a bag to hide [my]2815-the new earl head in ! ”[2815-the new earl] Then [his]2815-the new earl manners suddenly came back to [him]2815-the new earl , and [he]2815-the new earl dropped upon [his]2815-the new earl knees , with [his]2815-the new earl hands between [the King]294-the king ’s , and swore allegiance and did homage for [his]2815-the new earl lands and titles . Then [he]2815-the new earl rose and stood respectfully aside , a mark still for all eyes -- and much envy , too . Now [the King]294-the king discovered [Sir Hugh]132-hugh , and spoke out with wrathful voice and kindling eye-- “ Strip [this robber]4584-this robber of [his]4584-this robber false show and stolen estates , and put [him]4584-this robber under lock and key till [I]294-the king have need of [him]4584-this robber . ”[294-the king] [The late Sir Hugh]132-hugh was led away . There was a stir at the other end of [the room]507-the room , now ; the assemblage fell apart , and [Tom Canty]90-tom , quaintly but richly clothed , marched down , between these living walls , preceded by [an usher]2820-an usher . [He]90-tom knelt before [the King]294-the king , who said-- “ [I]90-tom have learned the story of these past few weeks , and am well pleased with [thee]90-tom . [Thou]90-tom hast governed [the realm]3233-the realm with right royal gentleness and mercy . [Thou]90-tom hast found [[thy]90-tom mother]3070-thy mother and [[thy]90-tom sisters]3076-thy sisters again ? Good ; [they]4588-they shall be cared for -- and [[thy]90-tom father]3066-thy father shall hang , if [thou]90-tom desire it and the law consent . Know , all [ye]4590-their that hear [my]90-tom voice , that from this day , [they]4590-their that abide in the shelter of [[Christ]102-christ ’s Hospital]4591-christ ’s hospital and share [the King]294-the king ’s bounty shall have [their]4590-their minds and hearts fed , as well as [their]4590-their baser parts ; and [this boy]829-this boy shall dwell there , and hold the chief place in [its honourable body of governors]4594-its honourable body of governors , during life . And for that [he]829-this boy hath been [a king]390-a king , it is meet that other than common observance shall be [his]829-this boy due ; wherefore note this [his]829-this boy dress of state , for by it [he]829-this boy shall be known , and [none]3179-none shall copy it ; and wheresoever [he]829-this boy shall come , it shall remind [the people]244-the people that [he]829-this boy hath been [royal]4598-royal , in [his]829-this boy time , and [none]3179-none shall deny [him]829-this boy [his]829-this boy due of reverence or fail to give [him]829-this boy salutation . [He]829-this boy hath the throne ’s protection , [he]829-this boy hath [the crown]4600-the crown ’s support , [he]829-this boy shall be known and called by the honourable title of [[the King]294-the king ’s Ward]4602-the king ’s ward . ”[90-tom] [The proud and happy Tom Canty]90-tom rose and kissed [the King]294-the king ’s hand , and was conducted from the presence . [He]90-tom did not waste any time , but flew to [[his]90-tom mother]287-his mother , to tell [her]287-his mother and [Nan]92-nan and Bet all about it and get [them]2824-them to help [him]90-tom enjoy the great news . { 1 } Conclusion . Justice and retribution . When the mysteries were all cleared up , it came out , by confession of [Hugh Hendon]177-hugh , that [[his]177-hugh wife]2825-his wife had repudiated [Miles]128-hendon by [his]177-hugh command , that day at [Hendon Hall]41-hendon hall -- a command assisted and supported by the perfectly trustworthy promise that if [she]2825-his wife did not deny that [he]177-hugh was [Miles Hendon]128-hendon , and stand firmly to it , [he]177-hugh would have [her]2825-his wife life ; whereupon [she]2825-his wife said , “ Take it!”--she[2825-his wife] did not value it -- and [she]2825-his wife would not repudiate [Miles]128-hendon ; then [the husband]2826-the husband said [he]2826-the husband would spare [her]2825-his wife life but have [Miles]128-hendon assassinated ! This was a different matter ; so [she]2825-his wife gave [her]2825-his wife word and kept it . [Hugh]177-hugh was not prosecuted for [his]177-hugh threats or for stealing [[his]177-hugh brother]1215-his brother ’s estates and title , because [the wife]3947-the wife and [brother]4261-brother would not testify against [him]177-hugh -- and [the former]619-the former would not have been allowed to do it , even if [she]2825-his wife had wanted to . [Hugh]177-hugh deserted [[his]177-hugh wife]2825-his wife and went over to [the continent]2832-the continent , where [he]177-hugh presently died ; and by - and - by [the Earl of Kent]159-ken married [[his]177-hugh relict]2833-his relict . There were grand times and rejoicings at [Hendon]128-hendon village when [the couple]2834-the couple paid [their]2834-the couple first visit to [the Hall]914-the hall . [[Tom Canty]90-tom ’s father]2836-tom canty ’s father was never heard of again . [The King]294-the king sought out [the farmer who had been branded and sold as [a slave]2839-a slave , and reclaimed [him]2838-the farmer who had been branded and sold as a slave , and reclaimed him from his evil life with the ruffler ’s gang , and put him in the way of a comfortable livelihood from [his]2838-the farmer who had been branded and sold as a slave , and reclaimed him from his evil life with the ruffler ’s gang , and put him in the way of a comfortable livelihood evil life with [the Ruffler ’s gang]2840-the ruffler ’s gang , and put [him]2838-the farmer who had been branded and sold as a slave , and reclaimed him from his evil life with the ruffler ’s gang , and put him in the way of a comfortable livelihood in the way of a comfortable livelihood]2838-the farmer who had been branded and sold as a slave , and reclaimed him from his evil life with the ruffler ’s gang , and put him in the way of a comfortable livelihood . [He]294-the king also took [that old lawyer]2841-that old lawyer out of [prison]2106-prison and remitted [his]2838-the farmer who had been branded and sold as a slave , and reclaimed him from his evil life with the ruffler ’s gang , and put him in the way of a comfortable livelihood fine . [He]294-the king provided good homes for [the daughters of [the two Baptist women whom [he]294-the king saw burned at the stake]2844-the two baptist women whom he saw burned at the stake , and roundly punished [the official who laid the undeserved stripes upon [Miles Hendon]128-hendon ’s back]2845-the official who laid the undeserved stripes upon miles hendon ’s back]2843-the daughters of the two baptist women whom he saw burned at the stake , and roundly punished the official who laid the undeserved stripes upon miles hendon ’s back . [He]294-the king saved from the gallows [the boy who had captured the stray falcon]2846-the boy who had captured the stray falcon , and also [the woman who had stolen a remnant of cloth from [a weaver]2247-a weaver]2847-the woman who had stolen a remnant of cloth from a weaver ; but [he]294-the king was too late to save [the man who had been convicted of killing a deer in [the royal forest]2850-the royal forest]2849-the man who had been convicted of killing a deer in the royal forest . [He]294-the king showed favour to [the justice who had pitied [him]294-the king when [he]294-the king was supposed to have stolen a pig]2851-the justice who had pitied him when he was supposed to have stolen a pig , and [he]294-the king had the gratification of seeing [him]294-the king grow in the public esteem and become [a great and honoured man]2852-a great and honoured man . As long as [the King]294-the king lived [he]294-the king was fond of telling the story of [his]294-the king adventures , all through , from the hour that [the sentinel]2854-the sentinel cuffed [him]294-the king away from [the palace]425-the palace gate till the final midnight when [he]294-the king deftly mixed [himself]294-the king into [a gang of [hurrying workmen]2857-hurrying workmen]2856-a gang of hurrying workmen and so slipped into [the Abbey]2585-the abbey and climbed up and hid [himself]294-the king in [[the Confessor]2859-the confessor ’s tomb]2860-the confessor ’s tomb , and then slept so long , next day , that [he]294-the king came within one of missing the Coronation altogether . [He]294-the king said that the frequent rehearsing of the precious lesson kept [him]294-the king strong in [his]294-the king purpose to make its teachings yield benefits to [[his]294-the king people]3151-his people ; and so , whilst [his]294-the king life was spared [he]294-the king should continue to tell the story , and thus keep its sorrowful spectacles fresh in [his]294-the king memory and the springs of pity replenished in [his]294-the king heart . [Miles Hendon]128-hendon and [Tom Canty]90-tom were [favourites of [the King]294-the king]2862-favourites of the king , all through [his]294-the king brief reign , and [[his]294-the king sincere mourners]2864-his sincere mourners when [he]294-the king died . [The good Earl of Kent]159-ken had too much sense to abuse [his]159-ken peculiar privilege ; but [he]159-ken exercised it twice after the instance [we]2865-we have seen of it before [he]159-ken was called from [this world]1024-this world -- once at the accession of [Queen Mary]201-queen mary , and once at the accession of [Queen Elizabeth]202-queen elizabeth . [A descendant of [his]159-ken]2867-a descendant of his exercised it at the accession of [James I.]203-james i. Before [this one ’s son]2868-this one ’s son chose to use the privilege , near a quarter of a century had elapsed , and the ‘ privilege of [the Kents]204-the kents ’ had faded out of [most people]2869-most people ’s memories ; so , when [the Kent of that day]2870-the kent of that day appeared before [Charles I.]205-charles i. and [[his]205-charles i. court]659-his court and sat down in [the sovereign]2872-the sovereign ’s presence to assert and perpetuate the right of [[his]205-charles i. house]2873-his house , there was a fine stir indeed ! But the matter was soon explained , and the right confirmed . [The last Earl of the line]2874-the last earl of the line fell in the wars of [the Commonwealth]2875-the commonwealth fighting for [the King]294-the king , and the odd privilege ended with [him]2874-the last earl of the line . [Tom Canty]90-tom lived to be [a very old man]2877-a very old man , [a handsome , white - haired old fellow , of grave and benignant aspect]2878-a handsome , white - haired old fellow , of grave and benignant aspect . As long as [he]90-tom lasted [he]90-tom was honoured ; and [he]90-tom was also reverenced , for [his]90-tom striking and peculiar costume kept [the people]244-the people reminded that ‘ in [his]90-tom time [he]90-tom had been royal ; ’ so , wherever [he]90-tom appeared [the crowd]416-the crowd fell apart , making way for [him]90-tom , and whispering , one to another , “ Doff [thy]90-tom hat , it is [the King]294-the king ’s Ward!”--and[244-the people] so [they]244-the people saluted , and got [his]90-tom kindly smile in return -- and [they]244-the people valued it , too , for [his]2881-his was an honourable history . Yes , [King Edward VI]192-edward vi . lived only a few years , [poor boy]2882-poor boy , but [he]192-edward vi lived [them]2883-them worthily . More than once , when [some great dignitary]2884-some great dignitary , [some gilded vassal of the crown]2885-some gilded vassal of the crown , made argument against [his]192-edward vi leniency , and urged that some law which [he]192-edward vi was bent upon amending was gentle enough for its purpose , and wrought no suffering or oppression which [any one]2886-any one need mightily mind , [the young King]2308-the young king turned the mournful eloquence of [his]2308-the young king great compassionate eyes upon [him]2308-the young king and answered-- “ What dost _ [thou]4604-thou _ know of suffering and oppression ? [I]2308-the young king and [[my]2308-the young king people]3156-my people know , but not [thou]4604-thou . ”[2308-the young king] The reign of [Edward VI]192-edward vi . was a singularly merciful one for those harsh times . Now that [we]2888-we are taking leave of [him]192-edward vi , let [us]2888-we try to keep this in [our]2888-we minds , to [his]192-edward vi credit . FOOTNOTES AND TWAIN ’S NOTES { 1 } For [Mark Twain]206-mark twain ’s note see below under the relevant chapter heading . { 2 } [He]192-edward vi refers to the order of [baronets]2889-baronets , or [baronettes]2890-baronettes ; [the barones minores]2891-the barones minores , as distinct from [the parliamentary barons]2892-the parliamentary barons -- not , it need hardly be said , to [the baronets of later creation]2893-the baronets of later creation . { 3 } [The lords of [Kingsale]73-kingsale]2894-the lords of kingsale , [descendants of [De Courcy]140-de courcy]2895-descendants of de courcy , still enjoy this curious privilege . { 4 } [Hume]207-hume . { 5 } [Ib]208-ib . { 6 } [Leigh Hunt]209-leigh hunt ’s ‘ [The Town]1411-the town , ’ p.408 , quotation from an early tourist . { 7 } Canting terms for various kinds of [thieves]291-thieves , [beggars]849-beggars and [vagabonds]1545-vagabonds , and [[their]2894-the lords of kingsale female companions]2900-their female companions . { 8 } From ‘ The English Rogue . ’ [London]1-london , 1665 . { 9 } [[Hume]207-hume ’s [England]2-england]2901-hume ’s england . { 10 } See [Dr. J. Hammond Trumbull]210-j. hammond trumbull ’s Blue Laws , True and False , p. 11 . NOTE 1 , Chapter IV . [[Christ]102-christ ’s Hospital Costume]2902-christ ’s hospital costume . It is most reasonable to regard the dress as copied from the costume of [the citizens of [London]1-london of that period , when long blue coats were the common habit of [apprentices]2904-apprentices and [serving - men]472-serving - men]2903-the citizens of london of that period , when long blue coats were the common habit of apprentices and serving - men , and yellow stockings were generally worn ; the coat fits closely to the body , but has loose sleeves , and beneath is worn a sleeveless yellow under - coat ; around the waist is a red leathern girdle ; a clerical band around the neck , and a small flat black cap , about the size of a saucer , completes the costume.--Timbs ’ Curiosities of [London]1-london . NOTE 2 , Chapter IV . It appears that [[Christ]102-christ ’s Hospital]4591-christ ’s hospital was not originally founded as [a _ school _]2907-a _ school _ ; [its]4591-christ ’s hospital object was to rescue [children]1018-children from [the streets]261-the streets , to shelter , feed , clothe [them.--Timbs]2910-them.--timbs ’ Curiosities of [London]1-london . NOTE 3 , Chapter V. [The Duke of Norfolk]3358-the duke of norfolk ’s Condemnation commanded . [The King]294-the king was now approaching fast towards [his]294-the king end ; and fearing lest [Norfolk]122-the duke of norfolk should escape [him]294-the king , [he]294-the king sent a message to [the Commons]2913-the commons , by which [he]294-the king desired [them]2913-the commons to hasten the Bill , on pretence that [Norfolk]22-norfolk enjoyed the dignity of [Earl Marshal]211-earl marshal , and it was necessary to appoint another , who might officiate at the ensuing ceremony of installing [[his]294-the king son [Prince of Wales.--Hume ’s History of]2915-prince of wales.--hume ’s history of [England]2-england]2914-his son prince of wales.--hume ’s history of england , vol . iii . p. 307 . NOTE 4 , Chapter VII . It was not till the end of this reign ( [Henry VIII]105-henry viii . ) that any salads , carrots , turnips , or other edible roots were produced in [England]2-england . The little of these vegetables that was used was formerly imported from [Holland]24-holland and [Flanders]74-flanders . [Queen Catherine]212-queen catherine , when [she]212-queen catherine wanted a salad , was obliged to despatch [a messenger thither]2916-a messenger thither on purpose.--Hume ’s History of [England]2-england , vol . iii . p. 314 . NOTE 5 , Chapter VIII . Attainder of [Norfolk]22-norfolk . [The House of Peers]2917-the house of peers , without examining [the prisoner , without trial or evidence]2918-the prisoner , without trial or evidence , passed a Bill of Attainder against [him]22-norfolk and sent it down to [the Commons]2913-the commons . . . [The obsequious Commons]2920-the obsequious commons obeyed [his]294-the king ( [the King]192-edward vi ’s ) directions ; and [the King]294-the king , having affixed the Royal assent to the Bill by [commissioners]2922-commissioners , issued orders for the execution of [Norfolk]22-norfolk on the morning of January 29 ( the next day).--Hume ’s History of [England]2-england , vol iii . p 306 . NOTE 6 , Chapter X. The Loving - cup . The loving - cup , and the peculiar ceremonies observed in drinking from it , are older than English history . It is thought that both are Danish importations . As far back as knowledge goes , the loving - cup has always been drunk at English banquets . Tradition explains the ceremonies in this way . In the rude ancient times it was deemed a wise precaution to have both hands of [both drinkers]2923-both drinkers employed , lest while [the pledger]2924-the pledger pledged [his]2924-the pledger love and fidelity to [the pledgee]2925-the pledgee , [the pledgee]2925-the pledgee take that opportunity to slip a dirk into [him]2924-the pledger ! NOTE 7 , Chapter XI . [The Duke of Norfolk]3358-the duke of norfolk ’s narrow Escape . Had [Henry VIII]105-henry viii . survived a few hours longer , [his]105-henry viii order for [the duke]2510-the duke ’s execution would have been carried into effect . ‘ But news being carried to [the Tower]3064-the tower that [the King]294-the king [himself]294-the king had expired that night , [the lieutenant]2931-the lieutenant deferred obeying the warrant ; and it was not thought advisable by [the Council]1204-the council to begin a new reign by the death of [the greatest nobleman in [the kingdom]2242-the kingdom , who had been condemned by a sentence so unjust and tyrannical . ’--Hume ’s History of [England]2-england]2933-the greatest nobleman in the kingdom , who had been condemned by a sentence so unjust and tyrannical . ’--hume ’s history of england , vol . iii , p. 307 . NOTE 8 , Chapter XIV . [The Whipping - boy]1252-the whipping - boy . [James I.]203-james i. and [Charles II]213-charles ii . had [whipping - boys]2936-whipping - boys , when [they]2936-whipping - boys were [little fellows]2937-little fellows , to take [their]2936-whipping - boys punishment for [them]2936-whipping - boys when [they]2936-whipping - boys fell short in [their]2936-whipping - boys lessons ; so [I]0-my have ventured to furnish [[my]0-my small prince]2938-my small prince with one , for [my]0-my own purposes . NOTES to Chapter XV . Character of [Hertford]107-hertford . [The young King]2308-the young king discovered an extreme attachment to [[his]2308-the young king uncle]2180-his uncle , who was , in the main , [a man of moderation and probity.--Hume ’s History of]2941-a man of moderation and probity.--hume ’s history of [England]2-england , vol . iii , p324 . But if [he]2180-his uncle ( [the Protector]2412-the protector ) gave offence by assuming too much state , [he]2180-his uncle deserves great praise on account of the laws passed this session , by which the rigour of former statutes was much mitigated , and some security given to the freedom of the constitution . All laws were repealed which extended the crime of treason beyond the statute of the twenty - fifth of [Edward III]214-edward iii . ; all laws enacted during the late reign extending the crime of felony ; all the former laws against Lollardy or heresy , together with the statute of the Six Articles . None were to be accused for words , but within a month after [they]2943-they were spoken . By these repeals several of the most rigorous laws that ever had passed in [England]2-england were annulled ; and some dawn , both of civil and religious liberty , began to appear to [the people]244-the people . A repeal also passed of that law , the destruction of all laws , by which [the King]294-the king ’s proclamation was made of equal force with a statute.--Ibid . vol . iii . p. 339 . Boiling to Death . In the reign of [Henry VIII]105-henry viii . [poisoners]3764-poisoners were , by Act of Parliament , condemned to be _ boiled to death _ . This Act was repealed in the following reign . In [Germany]53-germany , even in the seventeenth century , this horrible punishment was inflicted on [coiners]2947-coiners and [counterfeiters]2948-counterfeiters . [Taylor]215-taylor , [the Water Poet]2949-the water poet , describes an execution [he]215-taylor witnessed in [Hamburg]75-hamburg in 1616 . The judgment pronounced against [a coiner of false money]2950-a coiner of false money was that [he]2950-a coiner of false money should ‘ _ be boiled to death in oil _ ; not thrown into the vessel at once , but with a pulley or rope to be hanged under the armpits , and then let down into the oil _ by degrees _ ; first the feet , and next the legs , and so to boil [his]2950-a coiner of false money flesh from [his]2950-a coiner of false money bones alive . ’--Dr . [J. Hammond Trumbull]210-j. hammond trumbull ’s Blue Laws , True and False , p. 13 . The Famous Stocking Case . [A woman]1101-a woman and [[her]1101-a woman daughter]2952-her daughter , _ nine years old _ , were hanged in [Huntingdon]76-huntingdon for selling [their]2953-their souls to the devil , and raising a storm by pulling off [their]2953-their stockings!--Dr . [[J. Hammond Trumbull]210-j. hammond trumbull ’s Blue Laws]2954-j. hammond trumbull ’s blue laws , True and False , p. 20 . NOTE 10 , Chapter XVII . Enslaving . So young [a King]390-a king and [so ignorant a peasant]2956-so ignorant a peasant were likely to make mistakes ; and this is an instance in point . [This peasant]2957-this peasant was suffering from this law _ by anticipation _ ; [the King]294-the king was venting [his]294-the king indignation against a law which was not yet in existence ; for this hideous statute was to have birth in [this little King]2959-this little king ’s _ own reign _ . However , [we]2960-we know , from the humanity of [his]2959-this little king character , that it could never have been suggested by [him]2959-this little king . NOTES to Chapter XXIII . Death for Trifling Larcenies . When [Connecticut]77-connecticut and [New Haven]78-new haven were framing [their]2961-their first codes , larceny above the value of twelve pence was a capital crime in [England]2-england -- as it had been since the time of [Henry I.--Dr . J. Hammond Trumbull]216-henry i.--dr . j. hammond trumbull ’s Blue Laws , True and False , p. 17 . The curious old book called [The English Rogue]2962-the english rogue makes the limit thirteen pence ha’penny : death being the portion of any who steal a thing ‘ above the value of thirteen pence ha’penny . ’ NOTES to Chapter XXVII . From many descriptions of larceny the law expressly took away the benefit of [clergy]4213-clergy : to steal a horse , or a _ hawk _ , or woollen cloth from [the weaver]2964-the weaver , was a hanging matter . So it was to kill a deer from [[the King]294-the king ’s forest]2966-the king ’s forest , or to export sheep from the kingdom.--Dr . [J. Hammond Trumbull]216-henry i.--dr . j. hammond trumbull ’s Blue Laws , True and False , p.13 . [William Prynne]217-william prynne , [a learned barrister]2967-a learned barrister , was sentenced ( long after [Edward VI]192-edward vi . ’s time ) to lose both [his]217-william prynne ears in the pillory , to degradation from the bar , a fine of 3,000 pounds , and imprisonment for life . Three years afterwards [he]217-william prynne gave new offence to [Laud]218-laud by publishing a pamphlet against [the hierarchy]2968-the hierarchy . [He]217-william prynne was again prosecuted , and was sentenced to lose _ what remained of [his]217-william prynne ears _ , to pay a fine of 5,000 pounds , to be _ branded on both [his]217-william prynne cheeks _ with the letters S. L. ( for Seditious Libeller ) , and to remain in prison for life . The severity of this sentence was equalled by the savage rigour of its execution.--Ibid . p. 12 . NOTES to Chapter XXXIII . [[Christ]102-christ ’s Hospital]4591-christ ’s hospital , or [Bluecoat School]79-bluecoat school , ’ [the noblest institution in [the world]1021-the world]2970-the noblest institution in the world . ’ [The ground on which [the Priory of the Grey Friars]2973-the priory of the grey friars stood]2972-the ground on which the priory of the grey friars stood was conferred by [Henry VIII]105-henry viii . on [the Corporation of [London]1-london]2974-the corporation of london ( who caused the institution there of [a home for [poor boys]2976-poor boys and [girls]2977-girls]2975-a home for poor boys and girls ) . Subsequently , [Edward VI]192-edward vi . caused [the old Priory]2978-the old priory to be properly repaired , and founded within [it]2978-the old priory [that noble establishment called [the Bluecoat School]2980-the bluecoat school]2979-that noble establishment called the bluecoat school , or [Christ ’s Hospital]4591-christ ’s hospital , for the _ education _ and maintenance of [orphans]2982-orphans and [the children of [indigent persons]2984-indigent persons]2983-the children of indigent persons . . . [Edward]192-edward vi would not let [him]2985-him ( [Bishop Ridley]219-bishop ridley ) depart till the letter was written ( to [the Lord Mayor]220-the lord mayor ) , and then charged [him]2985-him to deliver it [himself]2985-him , and signify [his]2985-him special request and commandment that no time might be lost in proposing what was convenient , and apprising [him]2985-him of the proceedings . The work was zealously undertaken , [Ridley]219-bishop ridley [himself]219-bishop ridley engaging in it ; and the result was the founding of [Christ ’s Hospital for the education of [poor children]2987-poor children]2986-christ ’s hospital for the education of poor children . ( [The King]294-the king endowed several other charities at the same time . ) “ [Lord God]221-lord god , ”[219-bishop ridley] said [he]219-bishop ridley , “ [I]219-bishop ridley yield [Thee]221-lord god most hearty thanks that [Thou]221-lord god hast given [me]219-bishop ridley life thus long to finish this work to the glory of [Thy]221-lord god name ! ”[219-bishop ridley] That innocent and most exemplary life was drawing rapidly to its close , and in a few days [he]219-bishop ridley rendered up [his]219-bishop ridley spirit to [[his]219-bishop ridley Creator]2989-his creator , praying [God]221-lord god to defend [the realm]3233-the realm from [[Papistry.--J. Heneage Jesse]222-papistry.--j. heneage jesse ’s [London]1-london]80-papistry.--j. heneage jesse ’s london : [its]1-london Celebrated Characters and Places . In [the Great Hall]904-the great hall hangs a large picture of [King Edward VI]192-edward vi . seated on [his]192-edward vi throne , in a scarlet and ermined robe , holding the sceptre in [his]192-edward vi left hand , and presenting with the other the Charter to [the kneeling Lord Mayor]2992-the kneeling lord mayor . By [his]192-edward vi side stands [the Chancellor]3876-the chancellor , holding the seals , and next to [him]192-edward vi are [other officers of state]2994-other officers of state . [Bishop Ridley]219-bishop ridley kneels before [him]192-edward vi with uplifted hands , as if supplicating a blessing on the event ; whilst [the Aldermen]2995-the aldermen , etc . , with [the Lord Mayor]597-the lord mayor , kneel on both sides , occupying the middle ground of the picture ; and lastly , in front , are a double row of [boys]2997-boys on one side and [girls on the other]2998-girls on the other , from [the master]3699-the master and [matron]3000-matron down to [the boy]520-the boy and girl who have stepped forward from [their]3002-their respective rows , and kneel with raised hands before [the King.--Timbs]3003-the king.--timbs ’ Curiosities of [London]1-london , p. 98 . [[Christ]102-christ ’s Hospital]4591-christ ’s hospital , by ancient custom , possesses the privilege of addressing [the Sovereign]2872-the sovereign on the occasion of [his]3006-his or [her]3007-her coming into [the City]370-the city to partake of the hospitality of [the Corporation of [London.--Ibid]81-london.--ibid]3009-the corporation of london.--ibid . [The Dining Hall]3010-the dining hall , with [[its]3010-the dining hall lobby and organ - gallery]3011-its lobby and organ - gallery , occupies the entire storey , which is 187 feet long , 51 feet wide , and 47 feet high ; [it]3010-the dining hall is lit by nine large windows , filled with stained glass on the south side ; and is , next to [Westminster Hall]82-westminster hall , [the noblest room in [the metropolis]3013-the metropolis]3012-the noblest room in the metropolis . Here [the boys]331-the boys , now about 800 in number , dine ; and here are held the ‘ Suppings in Public , ’ to which [visitors]3015-visitors are admitted by tickets issued by [the Treasurer]3016-the treasurer and by [the Governors of [Christ ’s Hospital]83-christ ’s hospital]3017-the governors of christ ’s hospital . The tables are laid with cheese in wooden bowls , beer in wooden piggins , poured from leathern jacks , and bread brought in large baskets . [The official company]3018-the official company enter ; [the Lord Mayor]597-the lord mayor , or [President]3020-president , takes [his]3020-president seat in a state chair made of oak from [St. Catherine ’s Church]84-st. catherine ’s church , by [the Tower]3064-the tower ; a hymn is sung , accompanied by the organ ; [a ‘ Grecian , ’ or head boy]3022-a ‘ grecian , ’ or head boy , reads the prayers from the pulpit , silence being enforced by three drops of a wooden hammer . After prayer the supper commences , and [the visitors]3023-the visitors walk between the tables . At its close [the ’ trade - boys ’]3024-the ’ trade - boys ’ take up the baskets , bowls , jacks , piggins , and candlesticks , and pass in procession , the bowing to [the Governors]3025-the governors being curiously formal . This spectacle was witnessed by [Queen Victoria]223-queen victoria and [Prince Albert]224-prince albert in 1845 . Among [the more eminent Bluecoat boys]3026-the more eminent bluecoat boys are [Joshua Barnes]225-joshua barnes , editor of [Anacreon]85-anacreon and [Euripides]226-euripides ; [Jeremiah Markland]227-jeremiah markland , [the eminent critic]3027-the eminent critic , particularly in Greek Literature ; [Camden]228-camden , [the antiquary]3028-the antiquary ; [Bishop Stillingfleet]229-bishop stillingfleet ; [Samuel Richardson]230-samuel richardson , [the novelist]3029-the novelist ; [Thomas Mitchell]231-thomas mitchell , [the translator of Aristophanes]3030-the translator of aristophanes ; [Thomas Barnes]232-thomas barnes , many years editor of [the [London]1-london Times]3031-the london times ; [Coleridge]233-coleridge , [Charles Lamb]234-charles lamb , and [Leigh Hunt]209-leigh hunt . [No boy]3032-no boy is admitted before [he]3032-no boy is seven years old , or after [he]3032-no boy is nine ; and [no boy]3032-no boy can remain in [the school]3034-the school after [he]3032-no boy is fifteen , [[King]3155-king ’s boys]3036-king ’s boys and ‘ Grecians ’ alone excepted . There are about [500 Governors]3037-500 governors , at the head of whom are [the Sovereign]2872-the sovereign and [the Prince of Wales]3050-the prince of wales . The qualification for [a Governor]3040-a governor is payment of 500 pounds.--Ibid . GENERAL NOTE . [One]3093-one hears much about the ‘ hideous Blue Laws of [Connecticut]77-connecticut , ’ and is accustomed to shudder piously when they are mentioned . There are people in [America]86-america -- and even in [England!--who]235-england!--who imagine that [they]3042-they were a very monument of malignity , pitilessness , and inhumanity ; whereas in reality [they]3042-they were about the first _ sweeping departure from judicial atrocity _ which [the ‘ civilised ’ world]3043-the ‘ civilised ’ world had seen . This humane and kindly Blue Law Code , of two hundred and forty years ago , stands all by itself , with ages of bloody law on the further side of it , and a century and three - quarters of bloody English law on _ this _ side of it . There has never been a time -- under the Blue Laws or any other -- when above _ fourteen _ crimes were punishable by death in [Connecticut]77-connecticut . But in [England]2-england , within the memory of [men who are still hale in body and mind , _ two hundred and twenty - three _ crimes]3044-men who are still hale in body and mind , _ two hundred and twenty - three _ crimes were punishable by death ! { 10 } These facts are worth knowing -- and worth thinking about , too . * * *
